I have bought several children's books that I read to my 11-month-old daughter and unfortunately, this is one of them. My daughter does not like this book at all. I have tried to read it several times and she loses interest immediately. She LOVES books and doesn't lose interest in her favorites. The illustrations are okay, but the "rhymes" (if you want to call them that) do not make any sense whatsoever. They are completely nonsensical. If I'm going to read my child a book, I want it to be something she will grow to understand, as that's an important part of reading and comprehension. Another thing I really disliked: The author appears to have overstepped some important boundaries by mentioning mothers and babies kissing "long and slow." (And so on.) That just weirded me out. This is not how I kiss my daughter, and I'm sure it's not the way most parents kiss their children. I'd like to think that isn't what the author intended, but it comes off that way and because of that, is inappropriate. My daughter doesn't like this book, I don't like it, and now it's pretty much a book we only flip through once in awhile (without reading). The illustrations are the only redeeming quality. You win some, you lose some, and this one was a loser. Not recommended.

reviewText: Grand baby will love it with matching stuffed animal. Bought for her 1st birthday party and she will love it.

How do you say goidnight to your parents? Do you read books and say goodnight, love you?

The author, Ann Whitford Paul, has written a lovely book about goodnight rituals. The little girl wonders how to giraffes saybgoodnight, sloths say goodnight, theyvare so slow, and any animal you can think of. My granddaughter has 3 books read to her, a little talking, then a big hug and kiss goodnight. This is after brushing her teeth and flossing.  It is a wonderful thing to wonder how everyone says goodnight.

Adults will enjoy reading this book to their children. The family can discuss their goodnight rituals, and how it makes them feel. Children will,have many questions. The illustrations by David Walker are bright, vivid and colorful. They depict the rituals and the goodnight times of people and animals. Thus is a lovely book for all to read, and to havebit as part of a goodnight ritual.

Recommended. prisrob 05-04-17

reviewText: books are the best present

Let me start by saying I'm obsessed with children's books! I wanted all the classics that I loved as a child and I wanted to find some new favorites for our family. I was searching for best selling children's books and came across this one. So pleased that I decided to buy it, this book is the cutest! The illustrations are amazing!! I love the colors and all of the sweet animals. I can't wait to read this to my little one.

I thought this was a very sweet story; not at all strange as 1 or 2 reviewers wrote. This is probably better for a preschool child with an attention span suitable to the length of the story rather than for a toddler. I bought it for an 18 mo old toddler, and it turned out not to be suitable to her age now, but hopefully she will enjoy it when she is a year or two older.

It's a decent book but wordy. My 2 year got bored with it. Graphics are similar to the one on the cover. The story just walks through animal pairs as they kiss goodnight. I did appreciate that the animals kissed both the mom and dad throughout the story (vs the mom only which seems to be the case with most books).
summary: A little wordy but still a good book.

Our grand daughter is transitioning into chapter books. She's 5 1/2 and starting kindergarten soon - just like Junie B. She also sometimes forget to use her inside voice and says and does things that get her into trouble. She identifies being a bit afraid of new things, was fascinated by hiding out in the school all alone, and by having friendships that sometimes are a bit fractious. She loved the other chapter about the cute little monkey baby brother.

She enjoys the book very much and is able to practice summarizing the plot and predicting what will happen next - skills she will need as her reading develops. Barbara Park captures the voice and thoughts of a little five-year-old who is beginning to make her own way in school. There are a few pictures but mostly kids have to use their own imagination to follow along. There are many things to identify with.

One criticism is that Park could use fewer expressions like - stupid smelly bus, or big fat Jim. Although that's how kids sometimes talk, it might be better to model better ways of expressing themselves.
summary: She's 5 1/2 and starting kindergarten soon - just like Junie B

We are reading the books and using them as a learning tool of how NOT to behave and my kids give examples of what they could/should do instead. reviewText: As described

I love readying to my boy before bed and these are fun books that follow a troublemaking girl named Junie B. Jones. She does a number of things that she shouldn't through out the book and the books work through the consequences of her choices. This makes for great conversation around right and wrong and how to treat people with my boy. We read all the books in this box set and he continues to beg me to buy the next ones which I will be doing soon.

My daughter's teacher recommended these as good first chapter books.  So, I ordered this little set.  She loves them and is able to read them fully on her own.  She is going into 2nd grade this fall and I'm so glad I bought these to help keep up with her summer reading.

I got this set because my 6 year old has really taken off reading and has all but flown through The Princess in Black series, so we needed a new collection of her to try. She's able to read these (I think the reading level is the same or slightly easier than the Princess in Black series, though the book itself is lengthier). But, we aren't thrilled with the tone and word choices. Our kids haven't started talking about "hating" things or things being "stupid and dumb," etc, and while I'm sure that day will come, I don't want to rush it. Also, there are made up words in the books (and not in a funny way, but as in everyday usage) - I assume mimicking little kids, but that isn't that helpful when trying to teach actual reading and early grammar.  We only got through the first book in this set and added the box to our donation bin.
summary: Not thrilled with the tone and word usage for little kids

reviewText: The series teaches life lessons.
Love Junie B. Jones. I ordered this set for my granddaughter.

I'm reading the reviews and some parents really just need to get over themselves!! If you can't handle a fictional character--how can you teach your own children life lessons?

Junie is curious and investigative. She's moving through childhood trying to figure it out and sometimes she gets it wrong. Terribly wrong. But she's hilarious and the joke often ends up on her. Kids with "good behavior" (who have already figured out the whole sharing and respect thing) will be left wide eyed and open-mouthed at Junie's antics (they know she's acting inappropriately--but it's so much fun to be the voyer and watch Junie learn her lesson), and kids who have behavior challenges--well, they'll find comfort in a friend like Junie and know they're not alone in trying to make sense of and navigate the differences between "mine" and "mindfulness of others," manners, mischief, and maliciousness (Junie never acts in the later intentionally).  And if you've never had a kid like Junie, you've missed out on some awesome (albeit awkward) parenting moments!

This is a series that can promote independence among young readers because of it's easy reading level, but as with anything that your children read and watch, it's a great adventure to share and talk about together. Junie is not a brat--she's lively, spirited, and navigating the world of elementary school and sisterhood.
summary: Mischief and Marvel Make Reading Junie Fun!

reviewText: Junie B. is my granddaughter's hero

I really wanted to like these but I just couldn't. Junie says stupid a lot, calls other kids dumb, and other inappropriate behavior I won't allow my 7 year old to do. (And with pretty much no consequence.) We've turned reading these into a discussion about how she's not a very nice girl and how could we do or say nicer things. I suppose that's not all bad but I'd prefer books that set a good example. And I'm a pretty open-minded mom when it comes to a lot of things but respect and kindness are important and Junie B. needs some work there.
summary: Junie B. sets a poor example. Learning opportunity I guess.

reviewText: Not a fan.  One of my daughters teachers recommended these stories so I ordered a set.  The main character has an attitude problem.  We ended up using them as a teaching tool as how not to behave/ speak to adults.  My daughter is a young/ early reader so she is still pretty impressionable and I prefer her to read things that are more positive.
summary: One of my daughters teachers recommended these stories so I ordered a set

reviewText: Great series for my 2nd grader

Honestly, I have never heard a early elementary aged child say they didn't like Junie B Jones books.  I was a kindergarten teacher for many years, a mom of three,  and now, substitute teach  in elementary school. Teachers often leave a Junie B book in the plans for 'read aloud' time as the chapter book.  They usually assign a few  chapters for me to read the class. Invariably, when I finish,the students are saying, "Read more!"  Most of the students can read these books on their own, but they like being read to, with the teacher or parents doing the various, funny voices.
For those who are concerned that Junie B will teach kids to use words like 'stupid, dumb and stinky', I have never noticed that being a problem at school, or with my own kids.  Students are smart enough to know that Junie B is a silly, fictional, character and that is how she talks. If you are a very serious minded person, then maybe these books are not for your family.  But, if you and your children like 'laugh out loud' comedy, then give this series a try!  Both boys and girls are fans.

We read quite a few of the books, and would always talk about what Junie B was doing wrong, why she should be nicer, etc. Instead of reading this and telling my daughter what NOT to do, I'd rather read a book that models good behavior and being a kind, caring friend. In one of the books Junie B calls her grandmother a loser... what kind of example is that? Sorry, we couldn't take it anymore and gathered up all the Junie B books to donate. My daughter is an avid reader, and burned through this entire series. She was excited to be able to talk about the books with her friends on the playground. She soaked it all up like a sponge: and then, every other sentence out of her mouth began incorporating Junie B.'s immature grammar. Barbara Park definitely gets how kindergarteners and first graders talk and think, and as a first-person series, dialogue as well as narration is all from Junie B.'s perspective. It's HORRIBLE. If the narration were written properly, it might combat the "spoken" language a bit; but it's not. I'm not even covering the questionable situations and motivations in the books. I call the series the Twinkies of children's literature because sure, kids love it, but is it really what you want them to be reading?

Our kids will have grammar, spelling, and sentence structure pounded into their heads for decades and they will either get it or not.  They learn their morals from their parents and friends.  But who will teach them to laugh and to love reading.  I'm in my 50's and I love reading these books to kids.  Thank you Barbara Parks for reminding me what is was to be 6 again.

reviewText:
My 1st grade son mentioned he had read one of these books at school and that he enjoyed them. I quickly purchased more for him to read, and then I saw the way they were written and the content. Is this a joke? The book is written from the perspective of a mischievous kindergarten age girl, but the author uses words like "bestest" and "hided". I was appalled! I don't know any children that age who actually spoke like that and even if they did, it shouldn't be reinforced in books! I found my self stopping a lot to remind my son that that was not correct grammar, even though he already knew- I just wanted to re emphasize it.

I also thought that her behavior went beyond mildly mischievous. She is downright naughty and disagreeable.

reviewText: Today I finally decided to take away all my son's Junie B Jones books. I attempted to use these as a teaching tool of things to NOT say and things to NOT do. I gave this time and lots of chats because I know he does enjoy them (even I enjoy them sometimes to be honest, she can say some really silly things!). However having to cut out numerous words "hate", "dumb", "stupid" just to name the MOST frequent, throughout every chapter of every book just became a thorn in my mind. The other part of the books that I can't stand is that Junie B. seems to always get away with her disobedient, rude and mean behavior. I could stomach them if she received consequences that presented a lesson but she does not. I wanted to write this to any parent wanting to start their child on QUALITY reading- save your money and skip Junie B.

If my five year old were writing this review then Junie B would have five stars.  She finds it incredibly entertaining and has giggle-fits over Junie's antics.  Ms. Park's writing is not on par with other children's classics (like Beverly Cleary or George Selden or E. L. Konisburg), which is why I've only given it four stars.  In comparison to classics, Park's writing is a bit formulaic, the characters are flatter and more stereotypical, and the stories lack depth, but what they lack they fully make up for in comedy.

Junie B is such a fun character.  Barbara Park must enjoy writing her and I think that is conveyed in the stories.  Junie's grammar is atrocious and I've seen several reviews where parents are upset by this.  Folks, have no fear, your kiddos are much smarter than you give them credit for.  If you're worried, simply laugh with your child about how Junie phrases things.

I like that Barbara Park does not shy away from hitting, spitting, and references to shows that Junie has peeked at that are age-inappropriate (for example "Attack of the Killer Ponies").  All of it is mild, but such a relief in a literary world that has been so dulled-down as to not give our kids any bad ideas, we've created worlds that just don't resemble reality.  Junie B's world is hyperbolic, but is more real to me--full of mistakes, misunderstandings, some good and bad teaching, and some good and bad parenting--that I think it's a pleasure for me to read as an adult.  I believe children's entertainment should be just that.  Entertaining.  Not a constant barrage of pseudo educational material. There are plenty of lessons to be learned in fiction that is not educational.  Children are fully capable of understanding why Junie's mistakes are mistakes rather than things to be emulated.  Even more important is their appreciation of an author who understands the absurdities of the adult world as seen through children's eyes.
summary: Wonderful Entertainment for the Preschool and Kindergarten Crowd

reviewText: Great.

These "literary works" are mind-bogglingly stupid, truly breathtakingly awful. These are chock-full of bad grammar, words you'd rather not hear a six year old use, attitudes which drive most well-adjusted parents up the nearest wall. As I flipped through the pages I kept imagining all the pauses I'd have to make while reading this to my kid ("well, Junie B does this, but we know it's not okay to [headbutt someone, use the word stupid, be disrespectful to teachers, etc]"). Every page would require such a detour and adjustment to make sure the kid gets the message one wants to deliver. And I don't know about other kids, but at least with my little once you give him a stupid idea (to use a word which shows up repeatedly in this series), it is really darn hard to get him not to act on it at some later time, no matter how much coaching goes with it. These books are filled to the brim with such bad ideas and attitudes. I am dumbfounded that these books are so popular in schools; but I'd  rather have my precious snowflake learn these bad things in school from other kids rather than enable him to be the instigator and *teach* bad behaviors to others in school. For one non-trivial thing, the former gets me fewer calls from the principal.
summary: A prime example of what a children's book should not be

reviewText: I read with my 5 year old and we wanted to add another series to our nightly reading and this series was recommended by some website so I got a few and we just finished the 1st one.  Should've known better when the title had the word "stupid" in it.  I had to skip that word and "dumb" so many times and correct incorrect grammar all throughout the book.  My 5 year old doesn't speak that way and the author dumbs down 5/6 year olds in the series.  I wanted to give another book a shot but again there are too many grammatical mistakes like "I runned over."  Plus she wants to beat up other kids and hates a lot of things. Just not very realistic of a 5 or 6 year old.  It's just not a positive reading material.  Thank goodness I didn't buy them and only borrowed from the library.  I don't get why this series is popular.  I will be sticking with the magic tree house series which is wonderful.
Great collection of Barbara Park's Junie B. Jones series. Read from my iPad, these stories bring joy and laughter to the students I read to, and I will read them over and over for years to come!

It's been said before: if you don't want your young, developing children exposed to hostile, erratic, inexplicably hostile and premature behavior and language, then you should skip Junie B. books.

I agree that this is for much older kids (8+) who have a good grasp of right and wrong as well as a fair handle on our language. A book like this will set you back three steps.

What troubles me is that first graders simply aren't like this at all. Even Kindergartener's behave better and don't fuddle the language so much. I understand these are meant to be a first person narrative from a precocious, over-imaginative  first grader, but the character and her lines always seem forced, trite, unimaginative and, well... fake. The plots do lead to surprise conclusions but getting there is just too painful and, i believe, too damaging for children. I mean, too damaging for my child. If you don't mind your kid believing that teachers are scary, school is terrible, most problems can be solved with violence, kids (peers) are to be trusted more than parents and language is flexible enough to just throw out the rules all together then this is the series for you.

I have not purchased any Junie B books, and this is to say I never will.  My 2nd grade granddaughter and I snuggled up to read a Junie B together (this was my first exposure) and I naturally expected this to be a special time.  Well, I guess it was...grandma was made aware of the decline in standards of what defines good reading for children of this age.  As I took my turn to read aloud, I couldn't believe what I was haltingly trying to read...bad grammar and examples of terrible behavior!  Neither my granddaughter nor her mother get much of a thrill out of these stories either.  When I asked why they read them, I was told the books are part of the school's attempt to have children practice reading skills.  Come on, educators!  We can do better than this!  And parents, you don't HAVE to have your children read these or any other trash for that matter.  You are ultimately responsible for what your children are learning, and there's far more to it than basic skills.
summary: Glad I didn't spend money to find out about Junie B!
