I give this book 3 stars for the number of flaps, which for some reason my kid loves to try and rip out of this book, and this book only.

The writing is lackluster and the characters poorly fleshed out. I found it off putting that the adult characters are not fully realized as individuals, but rather are extensions of their children, never earning names pasts the titles of "Elmo's mommy" and "Albie's mommy". I'm aware that this is normal in some cultures, but here becomes cumbersome to read. The story also jumps from play to potty, with little in between. It felt disjointed when Elmo decides to use the potty and suddenly, there he is. It probably doesn't matter to my kid, he doesn't have much of an attention span anyhow.

Prior to buying this book, I had not read the description advising it is a open-flap book. It was an excellent surprise to see it had the fun open-flaps! This is a cute little book. It doesn't talk as much about using the potty as I thought it would, but one page does give a description of the sequence of steps to follow when going to the bathroom. The story line is Elmo's two cousins come to his house. One is a baby still in diapers, the other is in training pants learning to use the child's potty. On one page Elmo tells his cousin Albie how to use the potty (wipe, flush, wash hands). Albie chooses not to go and then has an accident later when they are playing. Elmo's mother tells Albie that Elmo had accidents, too. Then Albie uses his potty. My child loves the flip ups, although many of them are very small and harder to lift if a child's fine motor skills aren't good. A couple of the flip up pages don't even change. On most flaps, there is a new picture. Example: You lift up the cover on the toy box and see the toys inside. However, one example is a lamp; you flip up the flap and it is just another picture of the lamp. My child is engaged and can get useful information from it, so works for me!

reviewText: I truly love The Wonderful Things You Will Be. It is unlike all the other affirmation books available to children. The wonderful messages are given in a warm. loving and gentle way. A lovely book to read anytime but especially at bedtime. The illustrations are simply glorious. This is a must have picture book.

I loved this book!!  It is beautifully written and illustrated.  The story is sweet and simple and easy to read.  I also own this author's other books "Dream Animals" and "Day Dreamers" and I like this third book MORE than the first two.  I think that this would be the perfect book to give as a gift for a baby shower or a first (or second/third) birthday gift.  My son is 5 and he loved it.  After reading it we talked about all of the things he wanted to be when he grows up.  One awesome thing I noticed in this book is how gender neutral it is.  There are both boys and girls depicted in the book, but it is a boy having the tea party, a boy using the sewing machine, a girl on the tree swing, and a girl as a superhero.  I love how the author didn't stick to awful stereotypes of boys being super heroes and girls being princesses.  This is one of the first children's books I've ever seen that shows the REALITY of little kids....that boys and girls do all sorts of similar things.  You will NOT be disappointed with this book.  Highly recommend!
summary: Beautiful book for boys and girls....highly recommend!

reviewText:
I purchased this book, The wonderful Things You Will Be is an awesome book.  It is a hard cover and one of the best ever children's books.  I have purchased it several times as gifts for little ones.  there are plenty of wonderful self-affirming positive messages for young ones to be able to absorb.  In the day of so much negative and wrong messages in the world for children today, this is refreshing to have them repeat and hear positive messages.  .I love how the book is illustrated with great art work that is absolutely gorgeous.  Soothing & rhyming..  Delightful details and lively scenes.  this stunning book makes a great baby shower gift.  retro -- nostalgic -- sweet style.
EXCEEDED EXPECTATION & HIGHLY RECOMMEND
summary: GREAT BABY--  BOOK RETRO SWEET STYLE

Even though I loved the artwork I previewed, I was a bit hesitant to buy this book because my daughter has a rare chromosome disorder that may immensely impact her life... to the point where she may not walk, talk, or be a functional, independent adult.  I was afraid this book would focus on "the wonderful things you will be," as in particular careers, activities, or things that required a lot of ability.  Much to my delight, this book instead focuses less on specific activities and more on being kind, loving, adventurous, creative--things my daughter could still be, despite any limitations and obstacles she may face.  This book emphasizes being UNIQUE, not necessarily being "able."  I really appreciate that.  This book makes me cry because I don't know what will happen to my daughter (nobody does--because her condition is so rare), but I love her and she is wonderful, and this book lets her know that!
summary: Great book even for the chromo cuties

I was searching for a book to give to a mom-to-be for her baby shower, but had a hard time finding what I was looking for: a book that conveyed the love any parent has for their child. I came across this book, but hesitated for a minute to purchase it because I feel uncomfortable buying books sight unseen (especially if they're a gift). The positive reviews for this book finally convinced me, and I was not disappointed!

This book is simply gorgeous. The message is simple, and one I believe any parent (or grandparent, or really any other family member) would understand and want to share with their children: "No matter what you choose to do or who you choose to be, I will always love you." It is a beautiful message about unconditional love. Paired with beautiful and whimsical illustrations of children expressing their creativity, this book is touching without being ridiculous or too cutesy.

While this book doesn't contain a "story" that would excite a young child and keep them captivated, I still think it is a great book to read together with your child, simply for its beautiful message. It's a message every child should frequently hear. In fact, I love this book so much I'm about to order a copy for my own children!

Love this story! Beautiful illustrations and wonderful words of encouragement. Would recommend for anyone!

Reading books to my children is my absolute favorite part of our day.  Every evening and most rainy days, my two youngest children and I cuddle up on the couch and together we read stories.  Our collection is ever growing and I am always delighted to find a book that I am genuinely excited to add to our shelf.  Their current ages are three and five so we spend a great deal of time enjoying picture books.  We received our copy of The Wonderful Things You Will Be by Emily Winfield Martin as a birthday gift.  This quickly became our favorite picture book and here is why.

Illustrations:
Before even beginning the story, I fell in love with the whimsical illustrations.  The pictures are so unique, soft, precious and warm.  I found myself so captivated by the magical images on each page that I paused long after the words were read to absorb the beauty and detail. The children in the story are drawn with such care and each one is so individual and incredible.  Its  almost too wonderful to keep on the bookshelf and deserves to be framed and hung on the wall.

Originality:
As I said before, we spend a significant amount of time reading in our family and its always a treat to find something completely new and original to add to our collection.  Emily Winfield Martin has blessed us with just that.  The Wonderful Things You Will Be stands out in a category of its own by combining outstanding, one of a kind artistic beauty with an encouraging and heartwarming message.  There isn't another book on our shelf that compares.  Her style is truly her own and greets readers with an individual experience they will want to reread over and over again.

Message:
The message of the tale is in the voice of a parent to their child.  It starts with the parent wondering aloud about who their young child will grow up to be.  From the very beginning, it portrays a strong message that, as a parent, they are certain that their child is someone they want to know.  Other childrens books do a great job of reassuring love between a parent and child but this adds another beautiful element to that message. Not only does it affirm that the parent will love the child, whoever they grow up to be, but it puts a great deal of excitement on all of the possible ways they can become their very own person.  It encourages adventure, taking care of others, individuality, wholesome character traits and creativity.  It says to go be everything you were created to be and I will love you with wonder and admiration.  What a powerful and uplifting message to children of any age.  Heck, what a powerful message for adults!

Story Flow:
When reading aloud, it is always enjoyable to be able to read a story with a steady, easy to follow flow.  This story is laid out in a comfortable progression of rhyming phrases without being sing-songy.  Each page contains a small amount of script while the captivating illustrations tell the story right along with the the written word.  The language is vivid, fun and adds character and creativity to this wonderful story.

It Doesnt Get Old:  I like Dr. Suess and admire his work, however, I can only read the tongue twisting silliness so many times before my head starts spinning.  How refreshing to have a story that you and your children can enjoy over and over again.  My kids have their favorite stories to listen to that aren't always my favorites to read repeatedly.  Its a blessing to have this book as a family favorite.  Each time I turn the page the kids point to the children in the illustrations and pick which one they want to be.  Its an easy choice and enjoyable for all us.

The Wonderful Things You Will Be has become my go to baby shower gift.  The last mom-to-be I gifted it to admitted to crying the first time she read it.  Perhaps it was just the hormones, but I venture to say that she truly appreciated the beauty and sincerity of this wonderful book.  Your family library is not complete without this gem.  This is a story book I cherish and long to share with every other child I hold dear.
summary: Reading books to my children is my absolute favorite part of our day

We received this book from an aunt as a birthday gift for my daughter's first birthday. She had not read it in person, but purchased based upon the thousands of reviews giving five stars. While I appreciate the gesture, I don't believe she would have selected it had she read it in person, and it is not a book I want to keep for my children (as my one year old also has a three year old sister, also interested in any books we read together). As many others have stated, in the first place, this book is problematic because it has easily tearable pages--not ideal for a young toddler, such as my one year old. For example, I can't return the book now, because she accidentally ripped the cover within minutes of opening the book. However, the words content to lend themselves to a younger audience, birth to aged 3 or 4 at most, and would be better as a board book for that reason. In general, the content provides the same generic "I love you so much" content as many other books, many of which are better because they are more simple and concrete/specific. I LOVE the whimsical and vintage-y style of the illustrations, however I felt there was some unappreciated subtle messaging present about gender. I also thought the following lines were a bit dark for a young audience: "When nights are black and When days are gray -- You'll be brave and be bright So no shadows can stay." And finally, I thought it was odd that the line "And become anybody That you'd like to be" opens up to pages of children in party costumes (animals, a tree, a moon, fairytale characters)... I know I could be WAY over-analyzing here, but if there's one thing I dislike about my millennial generation, it's the way so many of us "put on a mask" via social media to present how we'd like to be seen, rather than being genuinely who we are. I am ALL for kids growing up to be ANYTHING or anyone they want to be, but why weren't these pages illustrated with kids dressing up in clothing representing careers (scientist, mathematician, author, politician, teacher, etc) or representing more characteristics (kind, honest, generous, compassionate--perhaps because that would be redundant after the rest of the book?)?  This book almost feels like... a mishmash of random, beautiful illustrations that the author couldn't quite assemble into a coherent book. In some ways, it is very much like "Oh the Places You'll Go" by Dr. Seuss, but written unsuccessfully for a toddler audience.
summary: BEFORE YOU BUY AS A GIFT...

Great book for any kid under 10.

A book that showcases the love, awe and wonderment from parent to child. The words and illustrations fill you with deep emotion that can be understood from any point in the parental journey. Simply stunning.

There are a great many positive, self-affirming messages in this beautiful book for youngsters to soak in - nice little antidote against some of the other messages out there that children are exposed to!  Sometimes, I feel a little fearful when I think of how children can't help but be exposed to the negative influences in the world at much younger ages than ever before, no matter how much we try to protect them.  At the same time, there are so many BEAUTIFUL and good influences in the world as well, like this book, and I truly believe that keeping a steady diet of healthy, positive "mind food" going into a youngster's brain can go a long way in equipping them to counteract the junk that creeps in from time to time.

This precious book is such a great tool to help them begin... soft illustrations complementing simple words, a book that encourages a youngster to use his/her imagination and think of all of the possibilities in answering the age old question adults pose to them, "So... what do you want to be when you grow up?"  There are SO many things I like about it.  Many of the children's books we've accumulated over the years for our grandchildren go into possible occupations - but life is so much more than occupations, isn't it?  "Who" you become is so much more than that, and the pages reflect that sentiment with deeper questions, one of my favorites being, "Will you tell a story that only you know?"

You'll find that so many of the pages contain encouraging and supportive statements of belief in a child's capabilities, i.e. "I know you'll be..." (kind/clever/bold/brave/bright), with the last page assuring him/her "And I'll love you, whoever you've grown up to be."  I really believe books like this can be so instrumental in promoting a good self-image, as a child's rapidly developing mind soaks in positive messages.  Think youngsters will especially enjoy a 2-page spread toward the back that has flaps opening up into a full 4-page spread, with children dressed in various Halloweenish-looking costumes (isn't that what they're actually doing while they're tricking-or-treating... an early testing out imaginative possibilities?), and the diversity of the children depicted is a nice plus.

I doubt there's a parent or grandparent out there who hasn't gazed at the face of a newborn cradled in their arms and not dreamed of "the wonderful things you will be"?  At our Christmas gathering this year, it was so terrific for my husband and I to look at all of those beautiful little faces and think about the wonderful things they will all be!  This was one of the gifts for our 2+ year old grandson, but I know his two older brothers will enjoy it as well, along with his baby sister one day.
summary: Such a poignant book - brought a catch in my throat and a joyful tear to my eye!

Bought as a gift
Purchased for travel bedtime reading. Grandsons requested to hear it three nights in a row.

It's hard for me to know what rating to give this book. On one hand, the illustrations are lovely. On the other hand, the content of the book itself is not that great. I decided upon five stars for the illustrations and three stars for the writing, averaging my rating out to four stars.

This book is basically about a parent looking at his/her child and wondering what the child will grow up to be. It is written in a rhyme, which I like and appeals to my four-year-old daughter, but the writing is too simplistic and not very exciting at all. I mostly bought this book based off of the illustration on the cover and the ones on the preview of the book and I was not disappointed in that regard. The illustrations are whimsical and darling. My daughter loves looking at the pictures and they always bring up questions about what the children are doing, so the book, though lacking in written content, allows us to have good conversations.

Note: If you bought this book and didn't like the content or if you're planning to buy this book based mostly on the illustrations, I want to tell you not to give up on the author (Emily Winfield Martin) because she can and has done better. I also purchased her book called "Dream Animals" and the content is much better (wonderful, really) and the illustrations are even much better than the ones in this book, so please don't give up on her until you have seen and read that book. Dream Animals is one of my and my daughter's favorite books in all of our bookshelves.
summary: Beautiful Illustrations | Okay Writing | Not the Best Book by the Author

reviewText:
The Wonderful Things You Will Be, written and illustrated by Emily Winfield Martin delivers a message every one of us needs to hear: I wonder what wonderful things you will beand Ill love you, whoever youve grown up to be. Martins delicate, multicultural illustrations convey an air of  fantasy and dreaminess that suits the inspirational thematic message well.

Regardless of age, we all benefit from regular infusions of this idea: that each of us is unique, has purpose and deserves love. I assert that both reader and listener will enjoy reading and rereading this book, time after time. And every time, they will experience a thrum of warmth. Five Stars!

Adoption-attuned (AQ*) Lens This book is a wonderful stepping stone to conversations. It can both explore the childs dreams and discuss the historical patterns in the familyadoptive as well as biological. This affirms the childs fundamental right to bloom into the person potentiated by both nature and nurture. Such a conversation reassures children that they have permission to follow their North Star and relieves them of the notion that they must become their parents fantasy child. This is an essential message which adoptive families must deliver convincingly and repeat over time. --Gayle H. Swift, "ABC, Adoption & Me: A Multicultural Picture Book"
summary: The Wonderful Things You Will Be

My son received this book as a 1st birthday present and it has become a favorite in our home. The Wonderful Things You Will Be is a softer, sweeter take on Seuss' Oh the Places You will Go that focuses on the adventure of personality rather than place. The artwork is adorably whimsical. This book expresses all the tender wonder that every parent feels when considering his/her child's future. If I were to make a complaint at all about the text it would be that I sometimes find it difficult to read the words to my son without getting choked up!  This is a must-have for every child's library and a go-to for gifts.

reviewText: Oh my gosh I love this book!!!! My son loves ponies and the color pink, and he has expressed some concern that he isn't like other boys. I wanted to find a way to tell him how perfect he is to me just the way he is. The illustrations are absolutely gorgeous from cover to cover. The story is beautifully written and I cried when I read it to my son. He loved the little boy having a tea party and the little boy who was sewing. He pointed out all the fun kids doing different things and how they all were so happy because of it. I love this book for celebrating the children we love, just as they are. Thank you for a beautiful addition to our little library.

reviewerName: Mundie Moms & Mundie Kids Book Reviews
reviewText:
"I'll love you, whomever you're grown up to be."

I have long been a fan of Emily Martin's whimsical artwork. I have a couple of her prints hanging up in my library that I purchase years ago from her Etsy shop. I absolutely love that her work is now featured in children's picture books. The Wonderful Things You Will Be not only show cases what I love about Emily's artwork, it also captures the joy, the innocence and the marvel of a child's world. To match it's beautiful illustrations, this picture book also has an equally beautiful, moving message that children can be anything they'd like to be, and can go anywhere they'd like to go. I love this book's message. As a mother that's one of the best messages that we can teach to our children. The Wonderful Things You Will Be is simply lovely. It's one of those books that belongs in every baby nursery, and on the bookshelf in every child's room.

Oh I absolutely love this book. I bought it as a gift but decided to keep it after I read it to my daughter. It made me teary at the end. A beautifully written , sweet and poetic book. An absolute must read for all children.

reviewText: Just discovered this beautiful book through a customer review from another vendor (sorry amazon, but I bought it from you!) and purchased a copy for my grandniece's first birthday.  I think it will become one of her very best favorite books, as she loves looking at pictures of babies, and she already has quite the library.  The sweet, gentle message and illustrations are perfect for very young children through pre-K and beyond, and I'm sure it will make parents and grandparents teary-eyed as they read it to their children.  I call it this generation's version of "I Love You Forever;" it  might even make a sweet gift for a high school or college graduation a la Dr. Seuss's "Oh the Places You'll Go!"  I collected children's pictures books when my nieces and nephews were young; now that there are young children in my life once again, I'll add this to my own library.
But I cry every time I read this....

My son and daughter adore this book.  It is beautiful, fosters deep imagination, and most importantly speaks wonderful affirmation into their lives.  It teaches them to love themselves as we do - for who they are and for all the potential of who they can be.  I nearly cried when I read some of the first words:

When you were too small
to tell me hello,
I knew you were someone
I wanted to know.

That is the love of a parent, grandparent, sibling.  That is affirmation that will stay in your child's heart and promote a wonderfully positive self-image.  After buying this for my own kids, this is my new go-to baby shower gift.  Absolutely wonderful.

The reason I am not giving it to the 5 year old, is because I want to keep it here at Grandma's house so I can read it to all of my grandchildren.  To me this book just seems like it needs to be read TO a child and not necessarily handed to the child to read by herself.  I also think it should be read to the very youngest children and maybe it would be nice to have it as a board book.  Excellent addition to any home library.

reviewText: very cute book
Beautiful book,
VERY POSITIVE FEEL GOOD BOOK:  FOR CHILD AND GRANNY

"PreSChildhood is a time full of potential, and Martin celebrates this promise in this work. The general premise of Dr. Seuss's classic, Oh, The Places You'll Go is pared down to elegant simplicity. "Will you stand up for good/By saving the day?/Or play a song only you/Know how to play?" While the rhyming text falters a bit in spots, the word choice overall is spare, inspiring, and accessible to preschoolers. Children are encouraged to be kind, clever, and bold, to take care of the small, and to help things grow. Martin's oil paintings have the same retro, mid-century feel as her other illustrations, with large-eyed children of many ethnicities playing, gardening, and sharing together. VERDICT A go-to gift for new parents, and a potential bedtime favorite for many children. Martha Link Yesowitch, Charlotte Mecklenburg Library, NC"

Yes M'am you are correct in only that you are from Charlotte.  Rhyming makes little difference to my kids I read this, and they sad as well.  To diagnose a Children's magical book is blowing a Southern dart at the magical Red Ballon.  This is a wonderful story with amazing illustrations.  We as a society need to remember how it was not to judge a book we cherish, we need only to teach them to enjoy reading a page turner, and not a click the mouse to find the next page.  Thank you M'am for your surveillance on children's books..we couldn't have the stern Librarian cartoon without your insight.
summary: A Librarian reminds us of why the Dewey Decimal system is out of date.  Wonderful Kids book..

reviewText: What a super cute book.  It is very similar to Oh the places you will go by Dr Seuss but it is much simpler for little ones to follow and understand.  It teaches young children that they can grow up to be whatever they want and do whatever they want and that their parents will still love them.  The illustrations are adorable and it is very well written <3
Emily Winfield Martin writes the most beautiful stories. I am such a fan. The illustrations are so beautiful. My daughter loves these books.

"When you were too small

  To tell me hello,

  I knew you were someone

  I wanted to know.

  "For all of your tininess

  Couldn't disguise

  A heart so enormous . . .

  And wild . . .

  And wise."

The Wonderful Things You Will Be (2015) by Emily Winfield Martin is the rare picture book that truly has something for everyone. This thoughtful, quiet story imagines all of the things little ones (both babies and bigger kids) will grow up to be including creative and clever as well as brave and bold.

Martin's rhyming text moves the narrative along with lyrical narration reminiscent of a poem or a lullaby. Although this book is an obvious choice for parents to read with their children, it can also work just as well in a story time program. The text is just a tad too long for a baby story time but I could see toddlers or school age children being drawn in by the bright colors and rhymes.

This picture book also add just the right touch of whimsy with subtle touches including children dressed as animals and other fantastical aspirations. Each page has ample white space for text combined with bright, colorful illustrations. The Wonderful Things You Will Be includes children from a variety of backgrounds as well as boys and girls. It also thoughtfully circumvents many gendered or cultural stereotypes to create sensitive depictions of each child.

The Wonderful Things You Will Be is a subtle, charming picture book sure to appeal to readers of all ages. A joy to read.
Xmas gift for 3 yr old...I'm sure she'll love it.

Upbeat and optimistic book about all of the possibilities a child can experience while growing up as to what they might be.  Its message is altruistic, hopeful and tender.  Illustrations portray the gamut of options children can be and things they can do.  Of course, it assures them that their parent will love them no matter what they decide to be.  Fun book to read with a child and talk about what THEY want to experience in life.

A teacher could read it to a class of kindergarten or first grade students, then write a class story on what each child wants to experience or do, and then draw a picture of it and put it on the bulletin board.

Can't think of a better book to read before tucking children into bed.  Beautifully illustrated.

reviewText: It's a sweet book that will be a gift for a two year old child.
Love this book!

This book would be a great gift for a new baby or as a baby shower gift. It captures the awe and wonder that a parent feels when he/she looks at their baby- daydreaming about who they will become. The focus is more on personality and character traits and less on profession. For example- being kind and helping others. This makes sense since above all I would love to see my kids grow up to be kind, loving, caring adults.

The illustrations are whimsical and flow on the page. Very dream-like. The text is relatively simple and has a nice rhythm and rhyme to it. It would be great as a bedtime story for a young child to prompt a discussion of hopes and dreams for the future, as well as a conversation that no matter what the future holds, parents will love you no matter what. A cute idea would be for a loved one to add a short note to the inside cover with their thoughts and wishes for the future of the book owner.

My 2 1/2 year old son adores this book. The whimsical drawings and limited text inspire us to fill in the story with the terms that we use at home. We have several of Patricelli's books, and this one is just as great as the others. The last page with the "undies" has especially helped with some of his unease about big boy underwear. We haven't started training yet, but I hope this book is a good companion. I definitely recommend this gender-neutral book as an addition to any toddler's library.

We just purchased 3 books from this author for our grandson, and he LOVES them (we purchased Binky, No No Yes Yes, and Potty)!  The instant he saw them he laughed out loud at the baby and was begging us to read them to him.  We've read them over and over and over and over again!  He seems to really identify with the baby in the book, moreso than any book he has read to date.  He is just barely starting to show an interest in potty training, but you can tell he's really thinking it over when we read Potty to him.  I think his curiosity has been piqued.  You will not be sorry if you purchase this book!

My daughter loves Leslie Patricelli's "Blankie" book so I purchased this one to help her feel motivated to stay on the potty.  She likes to listen to this book and look at the pictures on her own.  As usual, the dialogue is fun to read not just for the toddler but for parents as well.

My son loves this potty book, and so do I.  Unlike everybody poops and similar books this one actually shows the child what needs to be done...sit on the potty and wait!  This was the fist book that my son actually got really engaged in, laughing at funny parts, responding to questions the little kid asks, and best of all asking "again?" when I get to the end.  We just bought another of Leslie Patricelli's board books (Yummy Yucky) and the same result.  She does really well in targeting the 18+ month super active kids, because the stories aren't too involved language-wise for them to follow, and really comes at it from their point of view.  Will be getting more of her books.

We already had a potty for each 21-month old, each with her own color. Here's the potty: BABYBJRN Potty Chair, Blue. We weren't making much progess yet with that, and my friend told me that his daughter learned how to use the potty from a book. That's what inspired me to get this book. It has the right title. Then the day the book arrived, the babies spend some time with it and later that evening they used the pottys perfectly. I still cannot believe it. Since then they've continued to learn, and they're continuing. I think it was this book that broke the ice and got things going.
summary: My Twin Babies Used the Potty Correctly

reviewText:
When I first read this book I was like "what"????? This is ridiculous I don't even want to read this to my kid! Imagine it reading like this "see baby, see baby need to potty, see baby go potty."
But seriously my 18 month old daughter was like "ok, read it again, 1 more time, um ok let's do it..."

I literally think Leslie Patricelli is a secret potty training genius - I credit this book with my babies early potty training.

reviewText: Perfect for my potty training son. He loves the book and screams potty everytime he sees it. Great durability.

reviewText: This book has few words, but teaches more through pictures. The child realizes he has to go potty, but what should he do? He sees how the cat goes potty, and then how the dog goes potty. He decides he will try his own potty, but when he sits, nothing happens. He waits and waits until finally he "tinkle, tinkle, toot"s and his family celebrates. I do like that it teaches a child they might have to sit a while before the potty happens. Overall, it's a good book. I bought this in combination with the Elmo potty book, which has more words and flip tabs. I think both will be helpful together.
summary: Good book. More pictures than words, but gets the message across

reviewText: This really helped in the first few days/weeks of potty training! My girls loved all of the underwear at the end and how the parents come to celebrate with toilet paper! haha
summary: My girls loved all of the underwear at the end and how ...

reviewText: This is another board book series that you just cant go wrong with. Toddlers love Patricellis comical baby. In this installment, the baby needs to go to the bathroom. He doesnt want to go in his diaper, so he investigates what the household pets do then decides to attempt his potty. After waiting a long time, something finally happens and he and his family celebrates his success. The last two-page spread reveals his next big decision, what type of underwear to get. Simple language, bright background, and slight humor make this book a winner. I read this book when potty training both my son and daughter and it was a definite favorite of theirs.
summary: Can't Go Wrong With This Series

reviewText: My 13 month old granddaughter loves this book, and I hope it sinks in!

It starts of with the baby saying he really has to go, and wants to see how the cat and dog does it, really?  Complete waste of money and pointless.

reviewText:
We have read this a million times since this summer. My daughter loves all the books by this author that she has read and this is his all-time favorite potty book. It's important to have a favorite potty book! She gets very invested in the protagonist baby's adventures figuring out whether or not to use his potty, and when he finally does, she gets super excited and yells YAY while clapping enthusiastically. It helps that that page has stars (he loves stars) all over it and it says "I DID IT!" which is one of her favorite announcements, potty or not. Oops, is that a spoiler? Sorry. We definitely recommend this one to all babies becoming interested in potties.

With bright colors, a cute character and a very funny story little ones learn that there is a better way than pooping in a diaper. Theres the Potty! Not only, no more diapers, but big kid underpants with all sorts of fun pictures on them. This is the perfect book for toddlers and even those tough-to-train kiddos. By showing what can sometimes be a whole lot of waiting, but a very big kid thing to do, toddlers soon realize this may be something worth trying out. Without a doubt this would be my first recommendation when it comes to potty training books for kiddos. A fun story with a great way to teach little ones basics!
summary: We definitely recommend this one to all babies becoming interested in potties.

reviewText: Love this book. Emphasizes that potty training has an element of choice (on behalf of the toddler,) and that it takes patience. My son loves the cat and then dog pages, which emphasize that they don't use diapers, but designated potty spaces.
My daughter was so happy with this book. She loves the little baby. And I feel it really helped push her to want to potty train.
Definitely a great book to normalize potty training and get my little guy ready to use the potty. He loves the pictures and talking about how kitties and doggies go to the bathroom.
summary: Definitely a great book to normalize potty training and get my little ...

reviewText:
My son is obsessed with this book. We haven't started potty training yet, but I bought this book when he was 17 months to start getting him in the potty mindset. He regularly brings this book to me to read, and through it has learned the word "potty." He also enjoys interacting with the book. When I read "Should I go in my diaper?" my son responds with a loud, drawn out "noooo" and he loves yelling out "bye bye diaper" when we turn the page to where the baby tries out the potty. He also regularly takes this book to bed and I hear him interacting with it as he flips through the pages.

Now at 19 months my son is showing a lot of interest in the potty (we'll start potty training soon), and I can't help but think that "Potty" has played a big role in that.
summary: One of my son's favorite books!

reviewText: At first I only gave it three stars because the story seemed not so exciting at first but now my son loves it and he actually says the story as he's going potty which is totally adorable so even though I don't get it my son loves it

This book can not be used to show biology, the process of going to the potty; it can only show that it takes a little courage along with patience. The book I recommend is once upon a potty by alona frankel. If you want to see if it's a good fit, I recommend searching for read alouds on youtube of this book and the once upon a potty. best of luck with toilet training!

reviewText: We all love this book! Our son started showing interest in the potty at around 18 months, so we bought this book as a way to introduce him to the concept. He recites portions of the book, his favorite being "aaa, oooo, haaa, eeeee!" when the baby is doing the pee-pee dance. In terms of teaching the potty concept, it shows a cat using a litter box, a dog peeing against a tree, and a baby using a potty chair - no mention of regular toilets, pee/poop (other than "tinkle, tinkle, toot - I did it!"), or toilet paper. But it is a fun and lighthearted book about the potty, which is exactly what we were looking for at his age.

Story shows a little baby in a diaper deciding to use the potty. Has a pet cat and dog. Adorable art. Full page art with bold color and simple first-person dialogue from the child. Got it for our daughter when she was 1.5 yrs old to help introduce the concept. She still loves reading it and she is potty trained now at 2.5 yrs old. Found it very helpful for the potty training process.
This book is excellent for teaching baby to use potty. My grandson loves it.

I get a little annoyed by another potty book we have that says "only big boys wear underpants". Nothing wrong with being a baby who wears underpants or diapers. Kids grow up too quick these days. Let them be little! They'll grow up soon enough.
summary: I like that it's simple and non-gender specific

HINT

reviewText: prefect

This is the best, simplest, and most adaptable potty book I've used with any of my kids! Some potty books go into too much detail that may not be applicable to your kid's situation, which lessens their ability to relate to the book (which is the whole point of potty books, for toddlers to relate to the character and want to copy the behavior.) But this one is super simple and straightforward. The baby is gender neutral, so you can call it a boy or a girl, whichever your kid prefers. I currently have several books for my last potty training toddler, and this one is her favorite!

reviewText: This is a great potty training book, and for kids just starting to learn to read. It's simple, and witty. I love the comical nature of it and I love making a baby voice to read it to my potty training toddler. I think it's his favorite potty book!

With my oldest child, I introduced every topic with books. The dentist, a new brother, the potty - we had stacks of them. But I'm on kid 5 now and I've slacked off. Shortly after I started my littlest one (18 mo) on the potty, I impulse bought this book and it was a fantastic decision. My daughter is delighted with this baby who uses the potty too!

The book features what I would call a baby - small, not gendered, a sprig of hair - wearing a diaper and deciding not to use it. Baby watches a dog and cat use a litter box and tree, respectively, and decides to try her potty. I change the text a little to suit our diaperless situation, but I really appreciate the emphasis on how long it takes baby to go and also that it doesn't show toilet contents. Now to find a good book about the dentist...
Super cute and fun. Baby loves the potty book.

It's very cute, and I definitely recommend it in your arsenal of potty books (you know, the ones you end up reading 100x while crouching on the bathroom floor next to a plastic potty chair).

Book shows cat in a litter box and dog outside near a tree.  Because there are only a few words on each page, we are able to use our imagination and expand on the story.  I like asking my little one "what is the kitty thinking?"  This way my son takes his time talking about each page.

reviewText: Cute potty book. My kids have me reading it so much I've memorized the whole book!

My 2 and a half yr old nephew is nuts about this book. Some reviewers have shown concern about not having a pet, but a youtube video or the example of friends' pets would work too. My sister doesn't have pets, but his dad has a cat, and we, his aunt and uncle have a dog. It was enough for the little guy to imagine the scenarios where the pets went to their respective and appropriate areas to relieve themselves. The thrill and joy on this face when he gets to the page where the child accomplishes a successful uh, elimination, is his favorite. His little fist flies into the air, and "I did it!!!" he trills in glee :) Relatives and friends abroad have been made to hear his version of the story on the Skype. Not sure what they understand about the book - he cannot yet pronounce l,s,r, and a few other consonants - but they did get that this is his favorite book. Now when I see him on FaceTime - he has the book somewhere within reach, or already in his little armpit. And he is getting successfully and enthusiastically potty-trained! Get this book, even if like me, you groan inwardly that 'this' will be his/her first favorite book - a potty book :D
summary: This 'disgusting' book is my 2.5 yr nephews favorite. And it works!

reviewText: This is a great "potty" book. We used this to encourage potty training, and would read aloud while our 2 year old was sitting on the potty. Although the illustrations in my opinion, (and possibly the opinions of other adults as well) are mediocre/very simple, and the words are very few, that is OK. It is simple enough to keep the attention span of a tiny tot, and the pages are colored bright enough to invoke interest. The words are few and easy to remember and quote along to. Also, the great thing about this little book is the hard material used for the cover and pages. These books are virtually indestructible and while not 100% waterproof, they can rather easily be cleaned. So many books during the terrible twos are torn apart or crumpled to no saving. This book is built to last for a toddler. It is admittedly not my first choice or favorite book, but I'm not the main audience. Sometimes, what appeals to adults, is not the same as what appeals to kids. The is just the reality of life. The main audience is the kiddo, so on that note, this was a definite winner!
summary: Winner, my kiddos love this book!

reviewText: Good book.

Been reading this book to my son since he was 1 year old.  Now he's almost 28 months, and asks to read it almost every time he sits on the potty.  I believe it's really helped him understand the potty and what it's for.  He loves the part when the baby is successful and says, "I did it!"  And I think he'll enjoy picking out undies when the time comes, since he tells me which ones in the book he likes the best.
summary: " And I think he'll enjoy picking out undies when the time comes

reviewText: This is a great book if you were trying to teach your toddler how to potty train. My son loves this book and always reaches for it at bedtime. I would highly recommend this one!
summary: I would highly recommend this book for a parent who is working on potty training

reviewText: Cute, my son loves it. He can easily relate to the story, and even 'read' or rather understand it with just following the pictures so it seems to build a bit of confidence as well.  I looked at many potty books (friends, library, online) and this is the best I've seen a far as teaching the process of what the kid should expect while potty training.
summary: Great potty book, best I've seen so far

reviewText: We read this when we're on the potty :) She loves books and this is just for that!

Gosh, considering what a HUGE milestone it is for a child to learn to use the potty (both for the child AND his/her parents!), it's no wonder it's such an emotional process (both for the child AND his/her parents!) as well.  It's actually the first activity a child learns that only he/she can do that no one else can do FOR them!  Have to admit that I can't recall going through the training process with my own sons - it was just TOO long ago! - but I was babysitting our oldest grandson fulltime when he was going through it so it's fresh in my mind, and I will never forget the first time he succeeded in pooping.  His eyes widened at that little "plop" sound, and I exclaimed "AIDEN!  I'M SO PROUD OF YOU!!!", to which he replied, "I'M SO PROUD OF YOU TOO, GRANDMA!"  Sometimes you just want to wrap yourself up in their cuteness, don't you?

I missed out - oh darn ;-) - on most of the process with our middle grandson since my daughter-in-law became a stay-at-home mom as he was almost ready to begin, and now it's coming time for the youngest grandson to start.  I truly love everything about this darling little board book - not only the cute illustrations (author/illustrator Leslie Patricelli does such a super job capturing the baby's expressions!), VERY simple words that a 2 year old can relate to, and the nice thick pages on this 7" x 7" book (perfect for a youngster to hold while waiting for something to happen on the pot), but ALSO how terrifically it reflects the growing awareness a child must have before he/she is ready to begin the process.  Being able in his/her mind to connect the physical sensation with how to respond, decide what he/she wants to do (go in the diaper or on the potty?), get there, take the diaper off, sit and stay there long enough to finish - for a youngster, that requires a LOT of memory/concentration, and being able to combine physical/cognitive skills.  The final pages do a super job of positive reinforcement - from his own sense of accomplishment, to his parents praise, to the reward at the end... "UNDIES!"

It's so sad to think that - according to the American Academy of Pediatrics - more abuse occurs during toilet training than at an other stage of development, with parents'/caretakers' expectations sometimes exceeding a child's abilities/understanding, mistaking a child's imperfect attempts for acts of willful disobedience.  Wow - when you talk about early opportunities to BUILD a child's self-esteem, to REWARD each progressive positive step, to cement the bonds of trust between child/parent by treating relapses as not a failure, but part of the learning process, just as with any skill we develop!  Not all kids are ready at the same time, and trying to force it too early is going to backfire in terms of stressing a child out and prolonging the process.  Yes, it's a stressful (and usually messy!) period, but positive reinforcement and patience - whether you're a child or an adult - always gets better results than negative reinforcement and exhibited/sensed frustration.  This is such a simple yet excellent little book to give to some little person in your life to help "psyche themselves up" for independently managing one of their daily bodily functions!
summary: Here's a positive & cute little tool to use in prepping a youngster for taking the big step!  Or, if you prefer, the big sit!

reviewText: My kid gets so excited when we reach the "Tinkle tinkle toot" page. She screams, "I DID IT!!!"

A true literary work of art. Never before have I read such profound and paradigm shifting work. What does kitty do? Spoiler alert: She craps in a litter box.

All joking aside a great book for a potty training toddler.

The elation of the parents and the subsequent use of big kid undies is also a nice touch. reviewText: We purchased this book a year ago when our twins were just starting to show some interest in the potty. I wanted to get a few books that would be fun tools to help teach them how to use the potty and this book seemed very popular with good reviews, so we ordered it along with a few others. Potty is a short story with few words about a young toddler who wonders if he or she should go to the potty in a diaper or in the potty. The tiny human thinks about how cats and dogs go to the bathroom and if using the potty is the right thing to do. The pictures are pretty cute and my twins, who are now three-and-a-half, still enjoy looking at the pictures. This book measures 7 inches by 7 inches, has 28 pages and is a board book with thick pages so it's very durable in case your kids are still in the very destructive stage! The little person is also gender neutral so this book would be good for boys or girls. This book is very cute but, if you decide to purchase it, you will probably need to do a lot of explaining as to what is going on in each picture. That doesn't bother me too much but some people may prefer books that have more words and tell a story. We also have Potty Book for Girls, The and The Potty Book: For Boys (I have boy/girl twins) and those have more of a story so if you prefer a potty book that has more words, I'd recommend either or both of those. This book would probably be more appropriate for children in the one to two year age group but older children might not find it interesting. My kids still like to look at the pictures but we don't use it much anymore although we read it a lot when we got it last year. I gave this book four stars because my kids really liked it, even if I am not too thrilled with it. It's still so reasonably priced that I don't regret buying it since my kids liked it and it helped them learn to use the potty!
summary: Very Simple Book About Potty Training and is Probably Best For Younger Children

reviewText: Great little book

I purchased a bundle of potty training books and this one surprised me as our favorite. I initially flipped through it and wasn't all the impress. But after a few weeks of reading it a few times a day (when my son is on the potty) I can definitely say that it's awesome.

This is the most simple out of all of our potty training books. Each page has a sentence, phrase or jus pictures. We use a lot of voice infliction and funny faces when we read it and my son laughs so hard. The page where the little baby has to go and is making sounds "oooh" "mmmm" "haaa" "eeee" is hilarious when read with fun sounds and inflictions. My son loves the comic strip looking page. We narrate it ourselves. The faces on the baby are hilarious. Then when baby thinks "What's that?" and gets big eyes we make a big production about it. He's nearly fallen off the toilet laughing.

The fact that it's so short makes me not dread reading it, like a couple others we have. The humor we find in it makes it special. My son has about 4 potty books in a basket next to the toilet. This is always the first one he picks up. He's about 33 months for reference.
summary: This is my son's favorite potty training book. It's short, easy to read and funny. Definitely a keeper.

Cute simple book for my almost 2 year old.

At potty time, down comes "Potty." It's made toilet training a cinch and my son has memorized every word of the script like it's a Hollywood movie, complete with epic conflicts -- do we tell the cat or the dog? -- and surprise endings. He sings, "Tinkle, tinkle, toot!" with all the bravura and excitement of a young Frank Sinatra.

As far as Mommy and Daddy are concerned, Leslie Patricelli is an honorary member of the family for creating a comical board book we have read a hundred times already and not grown terribly sick of. It's the perfect length to convince a little bum to stay put on the toilet. He enjoys the hilarious images and the misadventures of another toddler trying to decide how to shun his diapers. My little guy was on the late end of adopting toilet training (close to 34 months when he finally got around to it) at home. He was fine at daycare. We couldn't figure out why.

Turns out he needed a little incentive to stay put and a new strategy (child's toilet seat vs. a training potty). The two of them came together. We brought out 'Potty.' A match in heaven was made and he's been solid ever since that first weekend. This is highly recommended for the 2.5 to 3 years range, especially for its sense of humour.
summary: The only book needed in the bathroom!

reviewText: Very simple book that is about potty training. This is the only book of three that our son responds well too. He likes seeing where the dog goes , then cat goes, and then how the toddler decides to go on the potty, but forgets to take off his diaper. Insert toddler (mine) laughing historically.  He then sees that the toddler is successful with his tinkle tinkle toot and the parents are thrilled.  We reenact this as a family and then put our own stickers on my sons chart.  Five starts for us!  Good luck parents :-)

reviewText: The book is colorful, uses simple words, and is made of card stock so it's easy to turn pages.  However, there isn't enough description for what baby does after using the potty, like wiping, flushing, washing hands, etc.  I also don't like the very brief introduction into the potty.  I do enough to try and teach my kid about all the things not shown in the book, but I was hoping this book would help encourage the things I talk about.  I am looking for a better book to be honest.  I don't recommend people add this book to their collection unless it is given to them as a gift or they get it for free.  I'm not impressed as a parent with it overall.

My son really enjoys this book.  Parents need to understand that this very cute book is not indicative of how babies actually learn how to use the potty.  The number of kids who spontaneously decide they "don't want to go in their diaper" as this book suggests is incredibly low but unfortunately most parents think that like in this book, their kid is going to magically decide one day that they need to use the potty.  Nope.

If you want actual potty training advice you can use then buy the book "Oh Crap, Potty Training".

If you want a fun little book for your kid to look at while they are on the potty then this, or really any of Leslie Patricelli's other books are excellent choices.  We have pretty much all of them.
summary: Fun book, not potty training advice.

reviewText: ok

We got this book to super preemptively prepare her for the idea of potty training, and just stashed it along with all her other books. For some reason, she was drawn to this one and constantly brought it to us to read. Every day, she gives us the book to read to her at least three times.

I think what she really likes it is the element of surprise (e.g. how the kitty goes potty, how the dog goes potty and finally the baby -- "WHATS THAT?"). She gets so excited by the tinkle tinkle toot surprised and claps when the baby goes potty. Since we've read it so much, I've pretty much used it as my script when she watches me go on the toilet. Now that she's 18 months, she's shown interest in both my and her potty, and smiles whenever I follow the script.

An excellent starter book on the concept of pottying!

reviewText: I bought this hard book for my 2 year old. She loves the book! Still doesn't love to go on the potty yet. There are some grey pictures in the book that really show the process of how to "potty". My 21 month old really enjoys this book. She has a potty and likes the cute pictures of the baby and animals and the page of all the different undies at the end. I don't know if it makes my little one use the potty, but she brings the book to me a lot so we can look at the pictures and talk about the potty.

We started potty training at around 18 months old, with a stack of children's books about the topic in hand this one and "Big Girl Panties" Big Girl Panties are by far the favorite ones. The story is simple, breaking down the varying aspects of using the potty into short statements paired with illustrations on each page. In fact, it's not much of a "story" but rather a listing of the sequential steps ("i have to pee should i use my diaper i can use the potty waiting for the pee to happen tinkle, tinkle toot (a favorite page in the book) etc.) which may not seem as sophisticated to an adult, but for a toddler this seems to be exactly the right developmental level to break down the process into buzzwords and statements, rather than elaborate sentences. This is one of those children's books that I didn't quite click with right away, but after my toddler kept pulling it out time after time, I started to appreciate the simple effectiveness of this storytelling approach. Especially during the more challenging potty training moments, when my toddler would refuse to look at other potty training books entirely, she still got a laugh out of this one, so I would say this book was a great tool in keeping my toddler interested in potty training by making it more fun.
summary: Great, developmentally appropriate book for the aspiring potty-using toddler

This book shows (so you can decide if it matches your needs):
- A gender-less baby character (12 months to 24 months max)
- Child using a toddler potty (not the regular toilet)
- A naked baby with privates cleverly covered; one image of a bare butt (see pic)
- A dog and cat going potty outside and in cat box
- No actual poop or pee
- Baby running with toilet paper in celebration at the end (see pic)

The story, in a nutshell [I say he, but baby could easily be a girl]:
Baby has to go potty and wonders where he should go (in diaper or somewhere else). He asks where the animals go to the potty and sees where. He decides to try going on his toddler potty. You see a sequence of the steps (remove diaper, sit, read book, wait, wait more) before he succeeds ("Tinkle, tinkle, toot... I did it!"). He celebrates with his parents. Last page spread just depicts all kinds of underwear, presumably to help your little one can get excited about wearing them (boy and girl styles shown).

Verdict:
The book is adorable and I love the art. This book has short, simple sentences and clearly target the younger potty training crowd (definitely for under 2, though older toddlers may still enjoy). I'll working on potty training soon (hopefully around 18 months) so I really appreciate a young character. I don't see my son relating as well to preschool age book characters. We are reading this now, ahead of time to familiarize him with the concepts and he loves this one. I wish the baby in the book asked where his parents go potty and not just the pets. Though parents are easier to make a direct relation to, the plot does allow conversations about everyone/thing having a place where they go potty, and baby's place is on the little potty. Since we have dogs, that may help.

I'll be reviewing every potty training book I can get my hands on in the near future as I find the ones I like best so stay tuned!

Was this review helpful for you? If so, please click the "Yes" button below. If not, feel free to let me know why and I'll do my best to improve it. :)

reviewText: Really dumb.

This is a great book. It captured my sons fellings and fears perfectly so he really related to the chuld and i swear it made him less fearful when we started the 3 day potty training method.  Several times during the training when he started geting anxious and wanted his diaper back to poo I would say lets read the book and I would change the words to go along with his pooing anxiety and he instantly felt better and would try.
My only complaint is the child depected in the illustrations is a baby nit a toddler so it was very confusing at first because I had been telling him diapers are for babies and hes a big boy now. So we had to get over that . We have several other pottyfir boys books and the boys in the other books definitely look grown.
The others he did not relate to at all and would most if thr time not want me to read those books. This one was simple direct and all about his fears and anxiety with a little humor abd great praise. I feel like it was a huge oart if our success.  We are 100 percent trained in just 3 days and its been a week now and we are on our first trip away since starting.

reviewText:
My grandson is in the midst of being potty trained and, while he is not adverse to the process, he doesn't quite seem to understand what is going on.  Because of the other reviews for this book and because he really enjoys a number of Leslie Patricelli books that I have purchased, I picked up this book in hopes that it will help him along the way.

He loves reading the book just before potty time - which gets him ready for what is coming next.  I also show him his special undies that are waiting for him once he is officially trained.  He loves the Thomas the Train and the Cars characters, so those are the ones we have.  There is a page in the book that shows the reward of big-boy (or girl) undies, so he is really looking forward to it.  I've included a couple of photos his favorite pages..
summary: A really fun little book for helping during the potty training process

reviewText: We have a love/hate relationship with this book in our house.  On the one hand, our toddler loves it.  It has a permanent place in our bathroom, and he will march in, sit on his potty, and demand to hear it.  He claps every time the toddler in the book uses the toilet.  On the other hand, the Leslie Patricelli books are some of the more annoying ones to have to read repeatedly.  I have a personal aversion to talking about flatulence as "toots" (I'm just not convinced it needs a cutesy nickname . . .), and the androgynous kid is downright creepy.  But it works - it's honestly the best potty book out there, and the one we recommend to friends.
summary: Toddler loves it, we tolerate it.

reviewText: I love this author for children's books!  She did a great job with the potty book as well. I would highly recommend if you're looking to provide reading material for your children when learning how to use the potty.

reviewText: Quick easy read, great book to keep in the bathroom while talking about going potty. We read it so much while potty training, my toddler will jump to the end of the story before I even get there...

My daughter loves this book. She especially gets so excited at the different animated faces that the baby makes when he has to potty and when he wakes up to go tinkle. We bought this book as an incentive to sit on the potty for my 2 year old who is potty training. This book stays in the bathroom and we only read it when she sits on the potty. It works most of the time because she likes the book. And usually when we get to the "tinkle tinkle" part of the book I tell her "can you also tinkle like the baby?" and most of the time she pees even if she was saying she doesn't need to (these 2 year olds are stubborn). I also like that it's very pressure free, there don't seem to be any underlying messages to pressure kids into pottying or shaming them if they don't or have an accident, etc. Very happy with this purchase.
summary: Great book and incentive for going potty

We loved the Binky book so I went for this one when I started potty training my son.  Here's the thing, I am just going to be honest....it's a great story, I read it with funny voices and always get my kid to laugh, but there is no POOP in this story.  He is sitting on the potty, and then he tinkles and toots, and then he is doing the happy dance with his parents, great...but in our case we need to SEE it.  Seriously.  I am going back to Alona Frankel's book which I used for my others kids.  In that one you SEE the poop in his diaper, on the floor and in the potty and it is more of a story (because isn't that how it goes??).  Don't get me wrong, my son really likes this book, and he picks it up to read all the time, he also pees like a champ....but I need a book that shows him poop in the toilet. If you do too, you won't see it in this book. The last page with all the cool undies however, is quite motivating, especially if you have a bunch in real life you can't wait to give your kid. Cheers! :)

reviewText:
After a false-start and several frustrating setbacks it became clear to my wife and I that we needed back-up to help potty-train our 2.5yr old little boy. We never wanted to make potty time something intimidating but we both felt that we'd reached the end of our ability to keep the stress factor low.

Potty, by Leslie Patricelli, came recommended by a family friend with a few kids of her own. Honestly, I was a little skeptical that a book would do much. My son has hordes of other books that he loves and I figured this would just be added to the pile. Well, this book isn't a panacea for you potty-training angst. But it is such a fun, cute little book that my son adores. We read this book probably 5 or more times a day and he cracks up every time. We've even convinced him (with the help of this book, of course) that it'd be more fun to read the book on the toilet!

The book is short, very colorful, and extremely easy to read. My son adores this book and reads along (as much as he can). We're still making steady progress on the potty-training front but we're close! Definitely recommend this book and my wife has already picked up copies for our friends with small children.
summary: Making Potty Time a Fun Read-Along Adventure

reviewText: Used this book and another one when trying to potty-train my little one. She would get so excited when we read it. She would respond when the baby asked "Should I use my diaper? Should I use the potty?" Very simple book, but very helpful and encouraging for little ones learning to go. The last page says "undies!" and has pictures of all different kinds of underwear...underwear was a big motivator for my daughter, so she loved that page.
Yes! Sent it along to my two-year old grandson's parents and they enjoyed it.

If you are going to get only one potty time book for your toddler to read, this would be the one. I bought three of the highest rated books for my little girl through Amazon and after receiving them, I realized this was the only one I needed. Too bad I didn't look through these at a bookstore before buying so I wouldn't have wasted my money on the other two (not that they were bad, just not as good as this one), but they will make good supplemental reading. This story follows the baby first hand through its journey to a successful potty. My daughter could relate, making this book almost a step by step process for her. In fact, she sat on her potty and flipped through this book over and over again until she pooped! I'm extremely pleased with this book!
we love this book
Very cute and fun book.  My grandson is 2 1/2 and beginning potty training.  We read this book several times when he first received it.  He laughed at the fun pictures.  Nice book!!

reviewText: We've read it a million times and he loves it. The child in this book could be a boy or a girl (doesn't specify) and the end page with "undies" has boys and girls underwear.  Highly recommend!!

reviewText: I bought this book along with a potty seat to put on our toilet.  Turned out to be a nice combination.  The book is very simple and a little silly, but it works.  From the first read my son was interacting, answering the questions asked in the book.  It briefly references how cats and dogs go potty - we have both, so this helped my son relate even more.  I am so pleased!

This is a cute potty book. I was looking for a version of "Once Upon a Potty" I had a few years ago when potty training my (now) 6 year old, but couldn't find it. This was a second choice but doesn't hold the interest of my little one the way the other one did years ago :(
Super cute book!

Ok, I just have to say it ~ my girl, now 2, is obsessed with poop.  Unfortunately she has had severe constipation problems, which led to withholding, which led to encompresis (look it  up, ewww...) She HATES TO POOP.  BUT this has become one of her favorite books, we read it all the time, and we  talk all day about how everybody poops.  She runs to grab this book many times a day, since she chooses her own.  And recently, VOILA, she is pooping, (under protest still), but without withholding, and they are normal, semisoft, toddler poops.  Not severe, huge, hard golfballs, from encompresis.  So, go figure.  What came first, the book or the growth out of encopresis???  It's a hard thing to work on as a parent, and i am completely covinced, and also grateful, that this funny and engaging little book has helped us get through things.  So to speak.  If you know what I mean.  Anyway......yeah.  When you are a scared parent, poop rocks.
Bought this in conjunction with a potty training toilet for a nephew.  It does the job.

This is a really cute book, my daughter loves the illustrations and immediately recognized it as a going potty book. We've been gearing up for potty training by just practicing and looking at potty books and explaining how to go potty so this is great way to illustrate it and the baby is really cute!
Awesome!!

reviewText: My diapered kiddo LOVES this book & requested I read it 5 times the 1st time I gave it to him.  It is simple with the wording, has cute pictures, & sturdy being a board book.  I see this one being a fave potty book fast!  It is good for boys & girls.  My DS still doesn't want to go on the potty, but it will happen.
Apparently a toddler is supposed to understand what "tinkle tinkle, toot toot" means, because the book doesn't show it. God forbid you actually show that poop goes in the potty.

This book arrived today and my little guy, nearly two, loves it already.  When I got to the page "Should I go in my diaper?" he shook his head and said "Nooooo" which I thought was comical since we haven't officially started training. Leslie's books are a hit in my house and this one delivers more of the same.

This book is one my favorite potty training books. The simple, almost childlike pastel drawings have a charm that hooked my daughter and me. The bright colors and simple message gave us a lot of bedtime and potty time reading enjoyment. My favorite part is when the main character mentions that he COULD go to the bathroom, but after seeing what the cat and dog do, HE DOESN'T WANT TO. It's a good approach and it sums potty training up. Diapers can be easier, but potty training is a goal worth pursuing.

SPOILER: The underwear page at the end really shows your child the promised land of potty training; The fun underwear you get to wear once you've learned how to use the bathroom.

Finally, my daughter thinks the "tinkle, tinkle, toot" part is the height of comedic writing. I highly recommend this book.

My grandson likes the simple picture-centered book but there were a couple places in the book I wasn't pleased with. He didn't notice, and loves to hear the story - I change it a little for him each time, but the pictures work for him. It helps entertain him while he "sits".

I just don't get all the positive reviews and would not recommend this book at all.

This book has very few words, so if you're looking for a story with a plot, then this isn't for you.  However, you're shopping for a board book for your potty training 2-4 year old, so this is probably exactly what you need; a simple story, cute illustrations, with a positive end result of using the potty and getting rid of diapers.  My 2YO son is just starting to think of using the potty, and he LOVES this book.  He makes me read it multiple times in a row.  It has convinced him to sit on his training potty with his diaper on, and he recites a part of the book as he does it, "I can try!"  So while he hasn't actually successfully used the potty yet, he is excited to get to that point thanks to this book.  His favorite of our potty training "library" of resource books :)

reviewText: My sixteen-month-old has just begun early potty training, and we bought her this to celebrate her first pee in the potty. I like that this attaches no shame to using diapers, but shows that there are more appropriate places for kitties, doggies, and babies to go, too. Patricelli's style is simple and classic, though I do find myself adding some context and explanation, particularly around the final line--"Underpants!"--because we call them panties in our household, instead. But I appreciate that this simple board book is gender neutral and judgment free.
summary: A gender neutral celebration of potty success!

reviewText:
This book is one of the least useful books I've ever seen. Mr. Rogers' book "Going to the Potty" is a real book about children's potty training. If Ms. Leslie had read Mr. Rogers' book, I don't think she could have published this one. Mr. Rogers' book is a paperback and you can see parts of it here on Amazon. The introduction about why toilet training is important and the serious attention that can be paid to the unspoken needs of children is clear. Leslie, you should have done your homework and if you were just writing to make a few bucks, you should still have done your homework.

Btw, Fred Rogers received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, 40 honorary degrees and had the longest running public television show of all time, over 30 years. He also got a Lifetime Emmy Achievement Award and helped public funding and laws about recording programs when he appeared before the Congress and was quoted by the Supreme Court.

"Going to the Potty" by Fred Rogers.
summary: This is not a Mr. Rogers book.

summary: I appreciate that it addresses potty-training in a fun, family friendly manner and even that the main ...

reviewText: This is my sons favorite potty book. He loves the simple and colorful illustrations on each page. One thing to note is some pages don't have many words or any words at all. I change the words in the story to be a little more detailed and to relate to what we are working on. For example on the page when the child is on the potty and is very sleepy there are no words so I tell my son "We even use the potty at night when we are sleepy"  or on the page where the cat is using the little box and page where the dog is peeing on the tree all it says is "oh" on those pages, so instead we say "Cats go poop in the litter box" and "Dogs go poop outside". Adding/changing the words on those pages has actually helped with working with nightime potty training and poop potty training. I also like that this book is not gender specific. I highly recommend this for potty training.

there are better books out there. this doesn't say a whole lot. 1-3 words on a page. more like a baby book than for a toddler that is potty training. I guess if you kid is one of those gifted kids that is potty-trained at an incredibly young age... there are better books out there. we read this but made up our own story - added much discussion to each page.

So as a pediatrician I should understand why this book works.  In all honesty it is like toddler voodoo.  The author knows kids and has created a book with images and dialogue at a very appropriate level for their understanding.  I can tell you though when it arrived and I read it myself I thought Amazon had led me astray.  However the first time I read it to my toddler I noted weird lights going on in his head.  I saw them.  He was very interested in this book immediately although I found the story ridiculous.  Like other reviewers I thought what does a cat peeing in a litter box have to do with him potty training?  We kept the book next to his potty and anytime he would sit there, even underwear on I would read it to him.  He loved it.  Prepare yourself people to read this horrible yet effective text over and over.  This book helped him slow down and wait and created a consistent dialogue for us to use as parents.  He potty trained with this book just before he turned 2 years old.  Has consistently stayed dry since about 26months.  There is no one answer for potty training as all kids are different.  For us this book absolutely worked to help him develop the patience he needed to wait for business to happen.  The reason I remembered to leave this review almost a full year later is because he and my husband were reading the book together at bedtime last night.  He still likes this boring story!  Be warned.  You will read it again and again.

reviewText:
This book has more flaws than benefits.  Here are my problems with it:

1. The kid seems stressed out and alarmed most of the book--do you really want to reinforce that this is stressful and uncomfortable?  I understand validating a toddler's feelings but why potentially feed their fears?
2. They equate going potty with a cat and a dog, but they don't show an adult, which would be the most logical.  Is showing a cat going in a litter box and dog going outside really relevant?  Are we trying to teach our kids to go in a box or outside?  Just weird as a parallel.
3. They never say what they need to do.  Does the author think it's not relevant?  Uncouth?  We're talking about this at home--it is exactly what should be in the book.
4. Where's the talk about cleanup (wiping, etc).

I found this book more troublesome than helpful.
summary: Look elsewhere if you want a great book for potty training.

He still felt a little awkward doing it himself until I got him this book. He loved being able to see a child like him using the potty and made him feel more comfortable. This isn't a magic wonder book where your child is just going to automatically be potty trained from reading it, you still have to work with them, but it helps comfort them that its not just for grownups (especially if they are an only or oldest child).
