reviewText:
Probably perfect for many children, particularly those already resistant to the idea.

"Potty" details the dilemma of an adorable round-headed youngster who during the first eight pages of this 14 page book thinks about whether or not to wet a diaper.  Kinda cute & Hamlet-like!  In the last pages, the child sits and sits and sits, a paragon of patience as the cat and dog fall asleep.  Then!  There's a "Tinkle, tinkle, toot" and great is the joy.

 "Potty" is a board book toddlers can hold themselves; the child is drawn cartoon-style with only a few words or no words on each page in primary colors but with such an expressive face, who needs a lot of words.  It is relatively inexpensive even new and there's a wild sense of humor that may appeal ("What does kitty do?")'

If your toddler is not resistant ("I don't WANT to") introducing so conflicted a star of the show may get into a drama mode.  If your toddler is apprehensive or resistant, and some perhaps many can be, then this book focusing  on feelings may be just the thing.
summary: "To potty or not to potty?  That is the question" --perhaps just the book for a child already into "I don't want to"

It covers the little baby's reluctance to try using the potty at first, his frustration that nothing is happening when he uses the potty, and his and his parents' excitement when he actually goes potty. My daughter loves looking at the pictures and seeing what happens. It's one of our usual potty books that we read when we're practicing on the potty. Good buy!

This is a lovely book.  Daughter has been potty-trained for at least a year and she still occasionally wants us nearby and asks for this book.  Sometimes she reads it to us, and sometimes we read it to her.  On the page with the sounds "mmmmmm", "eeeeeee", etc. she has to read the words because she can't memorize the order of the sounds.
My grandson Sam really likes this book even though he goes in the big potty now!  He says "all kids should have this book"!

We bought this for my son when he was 16 months, and six months later it's still a favorite. He just thinks it's hilarious! I'm hoping it teaches him some useful ideas about using the potty, but so far it's just worked for comic relief :)
what a positive and fun book! it's simple to read and to memorize, so we repeat phrases - "hooray! undies!" - when the little one is using the potty. a great purchase.

This book is really great.  My little 2 year old loves it.  She pulls this off the shelf often for us to read to her.  Sometimes I have to read it to her several times a day.  She almost reads along with us making the sounds, ohhh, eeeee, ahhh.  She points to her diaper when it is mentioned.  I really recommend this book for those getting ready for potty training.

Really no need to add another 5-star rating after 500+ positive reviews. But this book just exceeds my expectation. Its drawing is so simple--almost abstract--that I was initially afraid that my 18-month daughter who typically likes photographic books wouldn't be interested in it. Obviously, I was wrong; there is something special about Leslie Patricelli's drawing. Even before she was introduced to an actual potty chair, my daughter was intrigued by the eyes-wide-opening baby on the page where s/he (gender neutral) finally "did it." She always pointed to that image with an "ah" when she flips through the pages. Then we bought a potty chair for her. My daughter didn't know what to do with it in the first place--she even tried to put her feet in the potty as her grandma does with a foot basin. But she immediately learned to sit on it for a reasonable length of time once I brought her this book.

Although I didn't use this book in the real sense of potty training--it is way too premature for my daughter to start the process, I'm pleased that it introduced the potty concept very nicely to a 18-month old. Now my daughter asks to read this book every time she sits on the potty. Or the other way around, she will sit on the potty every time I bring to her the book--I do this when I see signs of her bowel movement.

The only caveat, if one insists, is that my daughter picked up the habit of getting up to fetch another book to read when she is on the potty, because the baby in the book gets up to grab a book before s/he settles down. Not sure if all parents like this habit. For me, if that is the worst thing to happen during potty training, I won't complain.
summary: 18-month daughter loves this book and learned the potty concept

reviewText: My daughters would scream out, "I DID IT! HOORAY! UNDIES!" after each time she would go! We read it so much together in the bathroom, I think I need to get another copy for my son. I seriously LOVE this book.

My daughter is 17 months and we are in the early stages of potty training with her.  I sit her on the toilet and we read her special potty books.  This book is, by far, her favorite right now!  Because of her younger age, the simplicity of this book holds her attention well.  I love it because I don't mind reading it over and over and over and over.  It is wonderful to begin exposing her to the language and process of going potty!
summary: Perfect for the younger potty training months

reviewText:
...excellent shape.  Brought back lots of memories, along with ALL
the other books bought with this one. Great books 4sure...
A very cute book to read for a child who is potty training.  It is a very short and simple book.

My son asks for this book every time we take him to the potty. He loves all the colors, drawings, smiles, and even knows the story by heart now. This book does a good job of showing all the steps to pottying, including the waiting and end goal of undies!
My 18 month old loves this book! It's one of her favorites. She constantly goes around and says, "ahhhhhh, ehhhhhhhh. Ohhhhhh!" Lol
We have several from the author and I never get sick of reading them.  Very cute, and my daughter loves them.
My son loves to read this book and loves to say bye-bye to the diaper in the book.  It's a good walk-through showing both some frustration and a win at the end.

This is the first potty book I bought so far.  My grandson LOVES this book.  We read it over and over and over again!

He may be a little too young to understand the concept of a potty, but it keeps his interest when reading it.

I think it's a good starter book to read to a toddler.
Love this book and so does my 2 year old boy. Simple and funny with plenty of praise thrown in for the ultimate big event.  Hopefully this will translate to potty success...

NO joke. I am pretty sure she wants to pee just so she can have me sit in there and read. This book most of all.  For an adult it is rather horrible. Don't get me wrong, its cute and creative...but there is only so many times I can muster up enthusiasm for this one...especially since she wants me to read it EVERY time she uses the toilet!
EVERY. TIME.
She has it memorized.

PROS: Obviously interesting for a toddler. Cute and simple drawings. Colorful. Few words so we talk about the pictures and what is going on in them often. 23 month old orders me to read it. "mama sit, read potty book". Kid claps and laughs through the entire book...EVERY. TIME.
CONS: The words and pics are so simple that for the parent it gets VERY tedious trying to talk about the pictures 10 times a day...which is not the end of the world...though it might be the end of my sanity.
summary: Kid goes potty just to hear this

reviewText: I didn't think much of this book because it is short, not a lot of storyline and the images seemed immature and poorly drawn. HOWEVER, my son loves it! He will sit on his potty and flip through the pages and act like he is reading the words. Hey, if It encourages him to go potty, I'm all for it!
Bought as a birthday present for my 2 year old grandson. He sits and reads it as he is sitting on his potty. Just what it was meant for !
I bought this for my newest granddaughter who is learning to go to potty.  He mother told me she loves this book and talks about it to others who will listen.  I would recommend.
its not much of a potty book.  But it is cute and my son likes to look at the undies but overall not a great book for potty training or even just reading.

I got this book when my child was 15 months. The faces are appropriately expressive and the story is easy for a child to understand. I read this book to my son whenever he wanted. By the time he was 18 months, he was successfully using his potty chair 5-6 times per day. I didn't push him to potty train; from reading the book, he wanted to!
summary: Your child may just potty train himself!

reviewText: My daughter love this book- she hopes it will help with the potty training.  My grandson loves to look thru the book.

Our boys are only beginning their potty journey, but they really like the cute drawing and simple message in this book. The story takes a child through the process of deciding to use his potty by seeing how his pet cat and dog have their own "place" to go potty. It ends with a celebration of being able to use real undies.
summary: Very cute and to the point

reviewText: We are just beginning the potty training process (Yes, please pray and wish me luck!) and I thought books would be an added bonus.  He loves reading them. :)
My 8 month old loves this book. We read it when he's on his potty and he just laughs and laughs.
this book is great!  my 20 month year old daughter loves it, and takes it to the potty with her.  she has just started potty training, and i think this book was part of the reason she wanted to try.

My 22 month old daughter loves this book.  She asks for it every time she's on the potty, and will sometimes "read" it to me (she knows a couple words from every page).  Pulling a dog and cat in helps - she loves animals.  And the celebration of going on the potty at the end of the book is great.  We try to really animate it and pump it up, and give her the same reaction when she goes.
This book is cute but is very very simple. My little girl doesn't seem to interested in it and neither am I for that matter.
This is one she can have and carry around because it is a sturdy board book.  Lots of potty pictures!  She will love I'm sure!  Can't wait to hit the "choo choo" potty train!
Seriously, this book couldn't be cuter.  My two year old nephew was highly entertained by it.  Another good potty book is "Everybody Poops".  These books help pique his interest in using the potty.
This is a nice book, can't tear the pages, easy to read.  Would recommend it to every one interested in teaching children to go potty.

This book is great for "early" potty trainers! It has great pictures of the baby waiting on the potty, watching what the kitty and doggy do to go to the bathroom, and others. I like the language because it's very encouraging and positive and simple so he can understand it. I also like this because because it doesn't show anything about receiving awards for using the potty, it just treats it like it's normal and part of the routine. The last pages my son really likes because the baby is wide eye when he says "what's that?" and then there are a lot of undies on the last page. I wish there were more books like this for one year olds out there.

My 19 month old daughter loves this book. She wants to read it over and over and over.
I also enjoy it. It is simple and easy for toddlers to understand. The illustrations are simple, as well.

If your child is at all interested in the potty, I highly recommend this book.

We love all the Leslie Patricelli books and this one is no exception.  Although my son is not potty-trained yet, he really likes reading this on the potty and laughs out loud when the books says "where does the dog go" and "where does the cat go"?  It's also helped him understand the concept of potty training.
We aren't pushing the potty yet with our 18 month old, just introducing the topic. Our toddler was very interested by this book and requests for us to read it every day.
summary: Our toddler was interested by it!

reviewText: This book was very helpful in the training of my grandson.  He and his mother read this many times.  He has been going to the restroom on his own since he was two.

I wasn't overly impressed, but the boy loved it. It's simple enough and he could read it to himself because the pictures tell the story.  A great support tool for getting them motivated to use the potty.

but I really do think that the concept of where kitty goes and where doggy goes might have been one of the clinching things in our potty training journey. My daughter was already interested in the 'kitty potty', so it may have helped things click into place a little better.
summary: you'll get tired of reading it

reviewText: My 2.5 year old boy has started showing interest in learning to use the potty. I took a chance on this book, and I'm glad I did. He really enjoys reading it, and he has gotten even more interested in practicing "potty time."

LITERARY MASTERPIECE.  It's been 28 years since I first learned how to tinkle and poo poo in the potty.  My wife has recently been questioning my abilities in the bathroom, and claims she is tired of cleaning up after my messes.  At first I was hesitant to actually read a book meant for children, but after seeing the s*** -eating grin (no pun intended) on that boy on the cover, I decided to swallow my pride and take a shot at it (no pun intended).  I can honestly say I'm glad I did.  You won't catch me taking shots in the dark anymore!  Oh no, just like that boy and his cat, I now sit every time I make anything.  I'm a reformed man, and my wife is ecstatic.

My 18 month old likes the book too.
summary: I'm thirty years old, but needed a refresher....

reviewText: This a very simple book.  It's good for introducing the potty to a new goer.  However, I would have like a little more regarding pee and poo.  The book does say, "tinkle tinkle toot!" but a not too detailed picture of the wee and the poo in the potty would have been appreciated.  Overall my daughter and I like the book.
My girl loves this book. We keep it next to her potty and she reads it every time she goes. She loves to shout hooray and claps when the little baby goes potty. A big help.
Not quite clear what is the message of this book. My little one does not understand why he should go to the potty.
Bought it for our grandson. It's his favorite book. Relates perfectly to what a child is thinking. fun and enjoyable for adults to read to children.

This is such a positive message to kids as they are learning how to potty train.  It conveys that potty training is hard, but I feel like it perfectly describes the experience they will go through, especially the I DID IT part!

Bought this book to add to our potty book collection. Trying to find something that will motivate our two year old to want to get rid of her diapers.  This one is fun, though I do have to supplement the words on the page with my own story line since there are a few pages with minimal to no words to explain what's going on.  But at this point, most parents are fairly comfortable with modifying books on the go :)  Who hasn't skipped ten pages at bed time?

If you're looking for a true book with a story, look elsewhere.  There are just a few words, not much of a story to read.

With that said, I'm very happy with this for potty training.  I use hold it for my son to "read" while he's sitting on the potty.  He loves flipping through the pages and looking at the pictures.  There's also a cute few pages showing how bored the baby gets waiting for something to happen on the potty.  Adorable.
the words and story are simple enough for my little guy to memorize and he loves reading it back to me as he sits on the potty.

My 18 month old loves this potty book. The story is simple enough to keep his attention and he loves to flip through the pages. We're are just introducing the idea of a potty to him and this book is great at helping with that!
Very cute, gives little one something to read to keep her from standing up every 2 secs while on the potty.
summary: Cute, love it, not too many words, holds little ones attention

reviewText: This is my 18-month-old's favorite Leslie Patricelli book.  I think the book is a little bit confusing to her her, but her favorite page is the "what's that?!" page.  She imitates the baby's expression on that page.  Pretty funny.  Great in getting her interested in potty training.

"The potty book ! The potty book !" .

My kid never tired of this book that extolls the potty.  She loved reading along with me and answering the questions asked by the narrator "Should I got in my diaper ?"  "Should I go in my potty ?" .  The suspense as we wait on the potty -- what will happen ??  and the  (spolier alert) unbridled joy when all comes out in the end.

The pictures are simple and clean. the text is easy to memorize and the plot can't be beat.  It's a wonderful book for your child to read while waiting for somthing to go tinkle.
summary: Her favorite read for a long time

reviewText: My toddler son loves it. Asked us to read it over and over again for weeks. I think it is a good book to start introducing the idea of the potty. We are not potty training yet so can't say if it will come back into use.
We are potty training and used this book for weeks before we actually put on the underwear!  It is a good book for introducing the potty as an option for going the bathroom! :-)
I think this is one of the cutest potty books. It's straight to the point and simple. We get a good laugh over the pages about dogs and cats.

This book is so fun.  Very simple of course, not much reading to do, but nice pictures and the idea was even though he's just a baby, over time he can start to think about the transition from diapers.  Sort of get the idea in there early.
summary: Fun Book with a Good Purpose

reviewText:
It's mainly about the painted style images here -- stylized, cute, and easy for the parent to make up the narration as the baby reads along. I prefer this to My Big Boy Potty, whose images aren't as appealing and whose script lacks the charm and rhythm of a good children's book. Although in the end, he likes them both.

Update -- As our son as very slowly transitioning to potty use (1 year, 9 months) this books has become more beloved by parent and child than ever. It's his first book when sitting on the potty and the phrase "I did it!" has come to be more meaningful than ever....
summary: Our son loves the book (even though he's not ready for the potty)

reviewText: very simple narration of process for kids to digest. my child is still unsuccessful but that's not what this book is about. she actually asks for it when she sits on potty.
summary: excellent book for kids on potty training

reviewText: My 21 month old loves this book and think's it is HILARIOUS! It is very cute! I would recommend it...
My 2 year old son loves this book.  We read it over and over and he talks about it while on the potty.  A great tool.
This is such a fun book and keeps my little one on the pot a bit longer.  We read it every day!

This book is funny and adorable. My son laughed out loud several times (he's two). It was great to see references to where "kitty" goes potty (litter box) and where the dog goes potty (outside against a tree). I also like how the dog and cat both fall asleep while waiting for the baby to go on the potty because it's taking him so long.  I only wish the pages were sturdier. Although it's a board book, the pages are not thick and sturdy like most of our other board books. Just the same, the book is very entertaining.
summary: Adorable and funny but not terribly instructive.

reviewText: This is one of my daughter's favorite books. She now knows the language of potty training, even though we are still a few months from actually doing it. She loves pointing out the potty in the book and then running to the bathroom to show us the toilet. All of Leslie Patricelli's books are favorites in our house.

My 2 1/2 year old son thinks this is the best book ever.  He is always asking me to read him the "Potty book" and he "reads" along with me.  It has helped him be more in tune with what his potty is for, but it hasn't exactly helped us progress in the potty training arena.  However, I give it 5 stars because he adores this book so much.
I originally bought this for my daughter when she was potty training, and now my son loves to read it. It's a fun book.
My kids still LOVE this book and they have been potty trained a long time.  So cute and really got my two interested in using the potty.
summary: Great potty training book for little ones

reviewText: I'm not sure why, but my 28 month old loves this book. I'm hoping it will help prep him for potty training.  We don't have a cat or dog, so the pages where the baby wonders what the pets do to go potty are confusing.
summary: Not my fave, but my son loves it

reviewText: My baby loves to read this book.  I got it when she was around 12 months and we were starting to EC.  Six months later, this book is still in heavy rotation and our little toddler is making great progress with her toilet learning.  My favorite thing about this book is that it doesn't introduce any neuroses: no "I'm afraid of the toilet!" or "I don't know how to use the potty!" nor is there a subtext of shame around natural body functions.  This book is perfect.  Reassuring and informative, humorous and encouraging.  LOVE!
Soooo adorable - my 2 year old LOVES this book and reading about.  It is simple and such a fun little book to year.  Highly recommend for potty training
Anything that will explain, in pictures, how a toddler uses the potty is a good thing.  This one is simplistic and helpful.

This is a fantastic potty book. We started potty training our kid a little on the early side but now that he is 2 years old he loves reading this book! Even though he is not yet potty trained, he can say the words "undies,poop and potty" because of this book. He actually will pick up the book and read it himself in his own baby language. Also, he will ask us to read it and after we are done he will say "again, again" to read it to him again. Also because of this book he will sit on the potty occasionally.

I gave this book to my granddaughter for her 2 year old. The little girl loved the book and wanted it read over and over. She then decided it was time to try out what she was learning. She has been quite successful in her potty learning. I really recommend this book for all moms. This takes any difficulty out of training.
summary: Great book for toddler's potty training

reviewText: My grandson loves this book. Hopefully, he will potty train without much difficulty! Has short sentences for his short attention span. Very readable and to the point.

Apparently babies are supposed to be potty trained at 2 1/2 these days (per day care).  My daughter is almost 2 so we're working on this.  She loves this book (I don't know why she identified the androgynous baby as a boy, but I just read it to her as a 'girl' a few night in a row and that changed).  I read to her every night and this is one of her favorites, often we read this three times before she goes to sleep.  (Also 'Everybody Poops').  But 'Potty' is number one right now.
My kids have always liked books by this author. It's a good way to introduce potty-training and the concept of "undies."
This is a bright and cute book that my son loves we gave been reading it regularly to prepare him for potty training.
Love this book and my daughter really loves it! She doesn't like to sit on the potty much yet,but she'll sit while she "reads" this book to me a couple of times through.
My toddler loves it and thinks it is funny but it isn't the best for teaching about potty training. A good way to get him interested and laughing though!
summary: fun but not a great teaching book

reviewText:
We have the "No No, Yes Yes" Leslie Patricelli book, which my son loves.
So when I saw the Potty book in TJ Maxx (best place for bargain books) I snapped it up.

At 19 months we're just starting to potty-train. So each night he sits on his potty and we read "Potty". When I say the p-word he pats his potty, and the page where the baby is desparate to go potty "haaa, mmm, heee", my son joins in the noises with glee.

He loves the cat & dog in the book too, and the page where baby has succeeded "hooray", my son throws his arms up and cheers.

Basically he loves all the pages in the book and we don't get bored of reading it every night as it's nice & short.
There are a couple scenes where he laughs out loud.  This book more than any of the others got him really excited about learning to go potty!!
This book is so funny for both adults and kids!  What kid wouldn't love it?!  The cardboard pages are easy for my 2 year old to turn.
summary: Potty Book to Bring to the Potty

reviewText: Any kid could understand this one.  I liked the ones catering to boys specifically, but this certainly can be for either gender and is easy to understand.
summary: Cute.  Works well with young ones

reviewText: My grandaughter is in the process of just beginning her Potty Training and she absolutely loves books. This is the one for her. I am so glad I found this. It is so cute and well as a learning book!

Leslie Patricelli, Potty (Candlewick, 2010)

Of the batch of library books we got out this time (and as I write this, I'm three batches behind, I think), Potty was both my favorite and the Bean's. The illustrations are engaging and fun, our toddler narrator has a quick wit about him (and wonderful facial expressions), and the story is very simple without ever feeling like the author is talking down to her audience. We read this one at least a dozen times the first time we got it out of the library, and if it's as popular after a second round, we'll end up adding it to the permanent collection, even if the Bean is already well into toilet training at this point--we just plain like it at book time. Fun stuff indeed. ***
summary: I Can Do It All by Myself

reviewText: after reading all colourful and well illustrated animal and fish books, my son refused to go beyond the 2nd page in this book.  since then it is sitting on the shelf!  I tried to return but they were charging for return shipping!!  Such a boring and uninspiring and uninteresting book.

My son loved this book.  It was the only potty book that really caught his attention.  He is fully potty trained now, but he still likes to read it every once in awhile.  This was another book that we got from the library and hung on to until we couldn't renew it anymore.  There isn't a lot to this story, but you make up for that with expressive reading and talking to your kid about what is going on.  He especially loved the sequence where the kid sits on the potty and eventually gets the book and then peeks in the potty because he got tired of waiting for something to happen.  And of course, the underwear at the end.  He loves talking about all the underwear and the kinds that he wanted to have.
My neice was just getting started with potty training.  Her grandmother (my sis) purchased a pink potty and I purchased the book.  What a great idea!  Highly successful!
summary: My neice was just beginning potty training. Wow! Great book!

reviewText: We haven't used this book a ton yet, but it is cute.  The last page is a little creepy with the only word being "underwear" and lots of pictures of underwear.  We'll see if it's aw-inspiring for my toddler!
She's sitting in my lap right now saying "potty book!" Great for getting your kids ready for potty training. A+
My two-year-old loves this book and requests for it to be read all the time. I like the positive, empowering spin it puts on potty training.
Yep, while I was reading him this adorable book .. he pooped. Sorry! TMI!!!  Hehe.  Love Leslie Patricelli books :)  This is a MUST have on the potty training list.
This book is ridiculous! Cute pictures but terribly done "plot". I basically make my own story up when reading this because it's so lame. There are better potty books out there.
summary: What is the hype about over this book!?

reviewText: Adorable words. Fun read for grandbaby and grown-ups! Mt grandson isn't old enough to start potty training,  but he likes the pictures.

We've bought several potty books over the years and this one is by far the best and most to the point one out there.  We liked it so much that we even recommended it when we reviewed the bjorn potty chair we bought from Amazon.  This book is beautifully illustrated, and filled with light humor.  The best part is when it asks, "what's that" and the little characters face turns in to a surprised "o" mouth face- my husband and I make this face for our son when he uses the potty and he squeals with delight.  It really is great.  We look forward to adding all of the Leslie Patricelli books to our collection.  Thanks
We read this every night before my son went to bed and I think it really helped him get the message about going potty in the toilet and not his diaper.  All trained up now!
Got this for my daughter. She loves reading this book, however she still has no interest in actually being potty trained. But very cute book.
When I saw the book, I was a bit disappointed.  However, my grandson loves it and carries it around with him.  He wouln't let go of it!
summary: My two year old grandson loves this book!

reviewText: This book has much less words per page. I just starting to introduce the idea of potty training to my 2 years old kid. The bright colors and large, simple pictures are wonderful. My son immediately started to imitate what the baby is doing. So glad I decided on this book. Helpful book for potty training kid.
Once again, Leslie has the perfect words to fit the title of the book and is fun to read. The artwork is cute.

I've just begun reading this book to my daughter to introduce her to the idea of potty training.  We already have one Leslie Patricelli book, ("Yummy Yucky" to teach her what's okay to eat and what's not), which my daughter cannot get enough of, and this book is turning out to the be the same.  I highly recommend ANY of her books, based on the success of these two.
summary: Using this book to introduce potty training.

reviewText: Not necessarily a fun topic, but this book makes a lighthearted approach.  It's fun, and she actually enjoys the book.  It increased her awareness of the potty, and her interest level.  Not potty training per say, but a useful tool.
My 2 year old is starting to potty train, and we love the positive tone of this book. The illustrations are really cute, and my son requests it over and over.
grandson really like the potty book.  loves looking at the brightly colored pictures of the baby on the new potty.

We're not specifically potty training yet, but I thought I'd get a potty book to keep in the bathroom and read to my 15-month old when she sits on the potty whenever I (Mommy) go potty.  She loved it from the first reading, and actually spontaneously clapped to celebrate the baby's success.  The basic story is that the baby wants to go potty, and doesn't want to go in its diaper, so it checks how the kitty and doggy go potty (in a box and outside, respectively) and says 'oh' and then decides to try its own potty, and after a little waiting, is successful (tinkle-tinkle-toot!) and celebrates with mom & dad & kitty & doggy, and then celebrates undies.  The book is very cleverly written and illustrated, with few words that tell the story well, but would also fit with whatever patterns, reward systems, or such you plan to use.  Also, the way, the baby is cleverly illustrated to be either a boy or girl, so anything goes!  I wasn't sure what to expect since the 'look inside' images are limited, but this book is well worth every penny, and I'm so glad we have it!  My daughter is eager to sit and listen to it, and generally wants to hear it twice.
It had mre wear and tear than I would have liked, but it was a good price for the book.

This is the cutest book!
My 12 Year old son and husband read this to our 2 year old
and he loves it!

I checked this book out of the library for my first daughter and she loved it so much that I bought a copy. My second daughter loves it even more. We are working on using the potty at a younger age - this would not be much fun for a 3.5 year old, but it's great for a child into "Good Night Moon" or similar board books. Actually, my daughters love all of Leslie Patricelli's books, so I would recommend them all, but this is probably their favorite.

We have quite a few potty training books, but this one is by far my son's favorite. We keep it in the bathroom as a treat.  It's so simple and entertaining.  When my son first went pee pee in the potty in front of Daddy, he did EXACTLY what the characters in the book do.  Hands in the air, running around, screaming "I DID IT!"  And he gets excited about "UNDIES!" like it says in the book.  HIGHLY recommend.  (And also 3 Day Potty Training eBook for parents.  Awesome.)

My boy is a bit over three, and he used to scream when we tried to sit him on the potty. He will be in pre-school after the summer, and I wasn't too excited about him still wearing a diaper in the pre-school.

I found this book at TJMAXX, and had no idea the difference this book is going to make, and what a huge difference it had made! My boy love stories, and this story of the cute little boy with a cute butt seemed just for him. My boy loved to role play the little boy when I read the story to him, and sat on the potty. After he got used to the potty, he did his first pee-pee in three weeks, and did the first poo poo three days after! We also got his beloved Spiderman undies in the meantime, and he never went back to diapers. It has been two months since then, and he had only had two incidents earlier, and that is it. Now he loves going to bathroom. I am going to pay a bigger water and sewage bill this period, and it all worth it.

Another boy in his day care that is 8 months older than him is still wearing pull-ups, but he is already pull-up and incident free, and ready for pre-school!

This is a very cute book that we've been using to help mentally prepare our son for potty training. Although we're not quite there yet we've been reading books like this and talking about it so that we're not just totally springing the idea on him out of nowhere.

First of all, we are HUGE Leslie Patricelli fans, so when I saw she had a potty book, we had to get it. We started reading it to our son when he was about 15 moths old. He loves the pictures, and definitely saw the connection to his little potty. (We had his potty sitting out in his room from early on, long before potty training.) As he started to talk more, he would talk about the baby in the book, the potty, the cat, and dog. We have a cat who is usually in his room when he's on the potty, so that definitely resonated. It's true that this book doesn't talk about the mechanics of pottying, but it's cute and enjoyable and engaging. Our son is now 21 months old and potty training, and we still read this book. He cheers when the baby finally goes potty, and he LOVES the Undies page, especially the Superman undies. I think this book definitely helped make the potty seem familiar and non-threatening, and it definitely made undies a great incentive.
summary: Helped my child love the potty

reviewText: Though the kid refuses to use the potty (unlike his sister, who was almost fully potty trained at 13 months), he likes this book. It is a simple and illustrative way to make children more comfy with the idea of the potty.
My son loves this book!  Unfortunately it hasn't really helped him go potty, but he does love to read it, and gets very excited when the boy ends up going potty at the end.  (woops, spoiler! :)
Patricelli is some sort of mad wizard. The illustrations are so emotive, interesting, and relatable, this book is a favorite for my son even though it is a potty book. The gold standard.

this book is simple but very cute.  i like how the child in the story is independently working to become potty trained, but that his family appears in the end to celebrate -- very motivational.  because we have a dog and cat in the house i loved that it shows how they "use the potty" too.  my son grins at the illustrations.

This is a very simple book with very few words and my boys love it!  It has colorful oil paintings for the illustrations and my boys love the parts where they get to yell "I did it!" and "Undies".  However, there are a few pages told through pictures with no words and the boys didn't understand them, so I had to add my own script.  That's the only drawback I have found!

She loves this book!  You do have to make up some of the story behind it - like why doggie is using the tree, but she loves the animals and the little baby.  We are not potty training at this time, just starting to get some practice but it seems like a good tool to help her get used to the idea.

I thought this book was rather cute, and my child was nearing 2 years. I didn't expect it to be an in-depth how-to for my toddler, though apparently some reviewers did. I expected what I got: a very simple book to amuse my child about a topic we've been talking about.
This book is now kept in the car, as it's one of his favorites to look at during short car trips around town. We have many books for him, ranging from picture books to full stories, and his dad reads to him nearly every night as their part of the bedtime routine. This is the only "potty book" we have, as it's not exactly something they'll learn from a book, but it's amusing and entertains him.
This book seemed a little boring to me....but my daughter loves it and that is what matters! She reads it on the potty and loves the pictures.

This book is about a little kid who realizes he needs to pee.  He considers what animals do (kitty uses a litter box, while doggy pees in the yard), and debates what he should do himself. Should he go in his diaper, as he has in the past?  Or should he try to use the potty this time?  He decides to give it a go on the potty.  After sitting patiently for a long time, he is finally successful.  His mommy and daddy are excited, and presumably they live happily ever after, etc.

As a parent, I liked that this is a very child-centered book.  It is not about parents trying to potty-train a child.  It is about a child making deciding for himself that he would like to use the potty, working through the idea, giving it a try, struggling, and ultimately succeeding.  The parents are only shown at the very end of the book, celebrating the child's success.

This book is simple, colorful, and fun.  It addresses many concerns relevant to a child, including:
-Deciding whether to use diapers vs. potty
-Boredom associated with sitting on the potty while waiting for the pee or poop to come out.
-Humor.  The child initially sits down on the potty with his diaper still on, then remembers to take it off.  A toddler who has been introduced to how the potty works will be amused by this rookie mistake.
-More humor.  The child dozes off on the potty, only to be awakened by the noises "Tinkle, tinkle, TOOT!" as his pee and poop comes out.  If you are 2 years old, this is hysterical.
-The eventual milestone of getting to wear big-kid underpants

RECOMMENDED AGE RANGE: 1-2 years. Due to it's simplicity and the baby-like appearance of the protagonist, this is great book for younger potty-trainers.  For a child who is late to training (age 3), other books like Joanna Cole's "My Big Boy Potty" / "My Big Girl Potty" would be more appropriate.
summary: Positive, child-centered book for little kids who are considering the potty

reviewText: After purchasing 3 books for the potty training phase, this one is definitely our little darling's favorite!  She has memorized the pages already and loves it!  The sturdy pages hold up well with little hands.
My 20month little girl loves this book! She wants to look at the pictures while she sits on the potty!
Though my daughter is only 14 weeks I am already reading this to her. You can never start the potty training too early!
My son loves this book and looks at it often. I think it's a good starting point for introducing the potty.
It's a pretty cute book.  Our toddler likes it & smiles whenever we read it.  It's nice & simple with simple words so our small child can understand.

Our first experience with Ms. Patricelli's books was "No No Yes Yes". By far the best one of hers that I've "read" (Higher and Higher was pretty lame). You don't read these books so much as you make up your own story to go with the cutely drawn pictures.

Our twin boys enjoy No No Yes Yes and I feel they will like this one once we start potty training.
summary: I like it, I suppose the kids will too.

reviewText: My 4 & 2 year old loves it! It helped them to understand that everyone needs to do their thing appropriately into the potty in a fun way. Effective for parents who are trying to potty train their kids.

I was hoping for a little bit more.  Unfortunately the book is not what I expected. Additionally the book is not in the best shape mi had to check to see if I had ordered a new book, which I had. Disappointed. O

Most potty books that I've purchased for my daughter always include some mention of accidents and of accidents being "ok".  While having an accident is ok, and I'd never shame my daughter for having one, she took it as license to have "accidents" on purpose, laugh, and then repeat said line from various book.  There is NO mention of accidents in this book.  Phew!  If you read it in an animated tone of voice and talk about what's going on in the book, it helps to flesh out a rather simple story.  She has memorized the book as well so it's nice for her to use as "reading material."  She's 2.5 yrs old now and decided to potty train herself a couple of weeks ago (after a miserable week of potty training hell a few months ago).  She LOVES this book!

Got this for my nephew's second birthday. It was instantly his favorite book. He can "read" the whole thing by himself, and "Tinkle tinkle toot" is his favorite joke. He is eager to sit on his potty now on his own. Indispensable for any parent.
summary: Potty train your kid with this book

reviewText: I bought this for my daughter to help her to get interested in potty training. As soon as I got it out of the box she exclaimed, "Potty!" She loves to look at it and I do think it has worked to help her to be interested in her potty again.

I absolutely love this book! Every time we get on the potty, we read it. I change the wording up a bit depending on what my son is trying to accomplish. He loves it. He insists that we read it each time! It has really helped him to understand what's going on with the potty training business!
My son does like reading this book on the potty but I don't think he fully understands the potty training.  It's an easy and colorful read.
One of those books that you don't really expect to be such a wild success, but toddlers love. Great undies illustrations.
My son loves books and i leave this one out in the livingroom with his toys and he loves to open the book up. Hoping it will help

I bought this for toilet training my three-year-old, and he LOVES the book.  He made me read it six times the first night.  Now he quotes it when I ask him about going potty on the potty ("I could try!").  No real movement (pun intended) on the actual potty yet, but it's just a matter of time.  In the meanwhile, the book is cute and gets the conversation going.  Kindle formatting is perfect, no repeat pages or glitches.  The illustrations are easy to understand and the colors are vibrant.  My toddler gives it two thumbs up.
summary: Sparks a real interest in the potty

reviewText: This is a cute book to help introduce potty training to your little one. My toddler loves it and "reads" it to me.

A great way to have an entertaining interaction with our three young boys about potty time. It is so funny to see all three of our boys mimicking the potty dance with the boy in the story. As always, the simple, vivid coloring scheme is outstanding. Just a few words per page with big, vivid illustrations keep the children's attention well. Patricelli is a master of the children's book. Please keep more coming and make them all available digitally.
summary: Another masterpiece. Keep them coming Patricelli!

reviewText: My son is not yet old enough to care about the potty besides he doesn't seem to care about having a dirty diaper for any amount of time, but he has a fun time reading this book with me.

I purchased three books for my grandson's potty training and they were all good and explained things at a kids level which helped make the training an pleasant experience!  Keeps them busy while on the potty!

Daughter love this book!
Message of using potty has sunk in!
After using the potty my daughter now quotes the book of "tinkle tinkle toot I did it! Hooray!"

Before our daughter was potty trained, she enjoyed this book very much. It was clear that some of it help prepare her for the potty and underwear and other expectations.

You may want to preview the book to make sure it jives with your potty training method. The only negative thing for me was the depiction of time sitting on the toilet: reading, waiting, sleeping. Many people don't recommend letting or making the child sit like that. I didn't find that it affected our daughter's expectations, though.
summary: Engaging Book Preparing for Potty Training

reviewText: Not my favorite book. I think Yummy Yucky and BiG Little by the same author are great, but I am not so impressed with this book and would not buy again.

I was having a hard time finding an ungendered potty book, and we tried multiple. This one really gets the prize, a smiling baby that is easy for my daughter to identify with, and good language that she can read along with. I particularly like the inclusion of what the kitty and the doggy do (although now taking the dog for a walk includes very extended discussions of how he goes "pee pee potty"....) After 4 months, I now find her (at two) on the potty by herself reading the book - the pictures and accessible language are great.
This book cracks me up. It is super cute but also seems like it will be highly motivating and effective as a learning tool for my son as soon as he is ready to be potty trained.
summary: looking forward to using this book

reviewText: My 16 month old son loves this book. Got it a this week and I've probably read it two dozen times already. Whether or not it actually helps with going potty is yet to be seen lol.
Grand kids love this book. It's durable and stands up to having toddlers carry it around. They love the pictures and story line.
The book arrived on time and has good pictures.  Keeps the topic simple. I recommend this board book for babies

Our grandson is 2-1/2, will be 3 in May. I am hoping this will help him get in the mood - along with his Thomas the Train underpants he got for Christmas! He loves books and this one is simple enough that he will learn to "read"  it to himself.

My grandson tried out the potty right after we read this.  I recommend it for those youngsters in training.

Jackie
Just the inspiration needed.  Thanks.........and especially like the heavy-duty, boy-proof pages.  Who knew a toddler would need a "how to" manual to learn to use the potty.  Whatever works say I.

When we were looking at potty training books, this one came highly recommended. For the life of me, I can't really understand why. It isn't very interesting and the plot of the story makes no sense. The baby has to go potty really badly but then ends up falling asleep on the potty while he's waiting for something to happen? This book was only read a couple of times before ALL of use lost interest in it. If you're looking for a good potty book, get "Even Firefighters Go To the Potty. Its a much better book and certainly much more interesting.

I bought this along with a couple of other potty books to jumpstart potty training. We tried at 18 months but she wasn't quite ready and wasn't overly interested in any of the books. Now that she's turning 2 in a couple weeks, we're at it again and this book is the FIRST one she always picks out of her bathroom book basket, EVERY time she sits down. I don't mind reading it over and over again either since the words are simple and she laughs a the noises he makes when he has to go and when he finally goes. She has even started saying "I did it!" like he does at the end of the book. It's also nice to have a book that applies to either sex so it can be passed down to any future siblings. Love it!

It's a little short, but cute.
He likes then a by and how he follows the cat and the dog.
as a parent, not very good reading.  Also, the fact that the baby is butt naked doesn't help since my daughter copies and even when it's cold, if she tries the potty, she wants to strip down.

"I did it!" was my son's first sentence.  "I did it" is the bright exclamation this cheerful, wiggly toddler uses when he successfully uses the potty.  The potty training toddler in the book is not sure about ditching the diaper and using the potty so he tries to make sense of it by seeing what his dog and cat do when they use the potty.  He finally gets that everyone has their own routine and all he has to do is sit down on his own potty and be patient!  At the end of the book he gets his reward... UNDIES!!!!  Another of my toddler now favorite words.

I like the fact that this book is all hard pages. It's a very simple book. I bought it for obvious reasons. To show my 2 year old "where and how" to use the potty. I can't say this book helped with that. I bought 3 "poop" books. And this one he always grabbed last. And didn't even always grab it. So it must not have interested him. As an adult, I didn't really care for this book. I did like the simplicity of it. But the words in the book were much to be desired. There just wasn't much to read except ewwws and aahhhhs. Literally.

I got this for my toddler when she started to learn about potty training.  It's a really cute and fun book.  Even now at three we still quote parts of it "tinkle tinkle toot" and yelling UNDIES!  Fun!

Life is changing now when I take the three kids to the book store; even the one and a half year old wanders around and wants to pick her own books. This was the first book she chose to read. This book was a great read for her and for the older two. They remembered their training time. The story is a fun read and well written. The illustrations are fun and the bright vibrant pallet will appeal to the young readers. But only time will tell if it will help, but either way an entertaining book the family will read many times over.

I was disappointed on receiving this book because the drawings are too cartoonish for my 2 year old daughter to relate to.  She much prefers My Big Girl Potty which interested her in the potty much more, since she could see herself relating to the little girl in the book interacting with her mommy and daddy, and playing with her stuffed animals.
summary: drawings too cartoonish for my daughter to relate to

reviewText: Very clear and images are perfect for little ones. It has sturdy pages and an excellent book to compliment potty training/learning.

I do read this to my son, however I insert A LOT of my own words (and remove some of the authors) since there are hardly any in the book.  I like that this book is cute and gets the conversation of going potty going while being something fun to do (read).  However there are parts I really don't like.  The baby in the book says they don't want to go potty in the potty.  Why reinforce that in a book about potty training?!  My son wants to use the big boy potty so why would I read him a book that tells him he shouldn't want to?  But I can forgive this and use my own words since the pictures are cute.
summary: gets the conversation going, but this book is lacking

reviewText: My daughter is starting potty training now and she loves this book. She asks for it and laughs and points to the potty. It has really taken some of the fear out of her and opens the coversation up (as much as that is possible with a 2 year old). I suggest this book for all parents starting the process. Good Luck all!
For weeks and weeks, this was my toddler's favorite book. He loves imitating the various facial expressions and claps his hands with excitement. We bought it used for 5$ shipping included

Well we all know that toddlers have potty mouth.  My toddler started this book when he was one, and he loved it then.  Now at the ripe age of three and a half, a fully potty trained for a year, this book remains one of his favorites.  He was originally attracted to the gallery of underpants, and he still loves it.  In fact the early toilet training was his idea.  Now he"reads the book" to his little brother, eight months.  He points out the riches of underpants in store for the potty trained.  Little brother seems interested.  Great book.

I think that this book would be better in the hardback instead of the electronic version.  This book's illustration does not 'fit' on my ipad screen so it looks a bit off.  But, my son has had me read it to him a few times now so as far as the book goes it was cute enough.  He cracks up especially when the little kid leaves his diaper on when sitting on the toilet.  I recommend buying the hardbook instead of the electronic copy though.
Great Grandson has me read this over and over.  He is jut learning to use his potty chair and loves that some one else is too.
There was more to the description of the book than the book itself.  I felt like the child could have more written thoughts.

My husband and I both thought this book was a little strange, but the kids all loved it (aged 8, 6, 1).  Very quickly it became the 1 yr old's fave book and she memorized it and would "read" it to us, expressions and all.  We eventually realized that we adults thought it was strange for the very same reasons the kids loved it, it was expressive and left some pictures to the imagination... just the way a kid's book should be.  It helped hugely when our almost 2 yr old was ready to try the potty.  We have probably read this book over a thousand times, seriously.
summary: Weird book, but a HUGE hit with our toddler

reviewText: This is a great book that seems geared towards kids around 2 yrs old. I think it is probably too babyish for a child older than 3.  My daughter really liked this book when she was 18 mos old and it seemed to get her excited to use the potty. She would frequently ask for this book to be read to her while sitting on the potty. It has very few words so it is a quick read.

The first time my son read this he went right into the bathroom and demanded a turn to sit on the potty. I hadn't done any potty training, and he didn't actually "go." But he sat his bare bum on the toilet (stool and insert assisted) without much hesitation. He cried when I insisted he put a diaper back on (after 15 mins of climbing up and down from the potty).

He is starting to request this as a nighttime read. We dont' plan on potty training for another 2 months, (my son is only 25 months now) but this seems to be working really well as a pre-potty training tool.

My daughter loves this book. the colors grab her attention, the short, simple words/phrases keep her attention and get the point across. She reads it over and over and loves to get to the "hooray!" at the end

As with all of Patricelli's books this one does a great job of contrast and compare. Great way to reinforce potty training and keep it light/fun. My only problem was that this book, although purchased as a new book, it clearly has a printing flaw that was noticed and manually colored-in with what appeared to be a crayon! It was a small problem for a toddler's book that will take lots of wear & tear, but it made the new book appear to be used and for that I fault the seller who noticed or should have that the page was damaged. I could easily have returned the item but my grandson enjoyed it and the flaw was too small to justify a trip to the post office.

This is the only potty-related book we have bought our sixteen-month-old daughter (so far). We've had it for about two weeks. It sits on a stand right next to her Baby Bjorn potty chair (which she has already successfully used twice!). She sits on her chair and reads this book several times per day. She loves it!

Some things about this book:
The pictures are very simple, so they aren't overstimulating.
The child in the book is gender neutral. The author also doesn't use the words "she", "he", "boy", "girl". The story is written from the child's point of view, and the child always says "I". This makes it very nice if you have multiple children to potty train or plan on keeping the book for multiple children.
The sentences are all short and to the point, perfect for toddlers to understand.
This book doesn't use the words "poop", "pee", or anything like that. That makes it easy to teach your child the words you want him/her to say regarding bodily functions.
I love the final page of the book. The are tons of drawings of "undies" (the author's word) in boy and girl styles. We already bought our daughter some "big girl undies" (one pair sits with the book to help reinforce the picture).
There is just enough humor to keep the book from being too serious, but not so much that it makes the book completely comical.
This book will not potty train your child (that's your job), but it will help reinforce what you are trying to teach. Not to mention, it gives you both something fun to do while you are waiting.
This is one of those books that I don't mind reading to my daughter hundreds of times. It's easy to add some of your own dialogue to the book. That keeps it from getting boring, since I try to change it up every time I read it.

I got this Potty book for my 18 month old son along with 3 other books. I received all four books with the potty. I sat him down and read each book. He sat and listened to each story as I read and acted them out. At the end he selected this one for me to read again, and everyday since. I try to pick up the others and he takes them and tosses them aside. He brings this book to me every time he wants to sit on the potty. He loves this book. Don't bother with any other book, this is the one that they understand and enjoy.

I thought the book was cute, but it definitely could have been a bit more informative.  My daughter enjoys looking at the pictures and picks up this book often when sitting on the potty herself.  I only wish it addressed exactly what the goal was.

We got this when we started introducing our daughter (at 16 months) to the potty even though we thought it seemed ridiculous... She LOVES it! She insists on having this particular book whenever she sits on her potty, she "reads" it herself now and sounds it out (which is super amusing to us), and when she goes potty she now mimics the book by saying "hooray!" A simple book that is a great accessory to potty training.

I like most of this book. It's easy to read and the colors are nice. The issue I have is with the 2 page multi-box spread that is difficult to keep my little one engaged followed by two pages of a baby yawning and a dog snoring. So 4 pages with no words but multi pictures. I tend to skip over them altogether. My daughter is 15 months and loves when I read but when there is too much pic overload without words she can get distracted. But, I do like the concept and the rest of the book.

Unfortunately, this book hasn't helped in potty training, yet. But my daughter loves it and always tells the main character to not go in his diaper. If only she would take the same advice for herself.
summary: Cute book, great drawings, good conversation piece with your little one

reviewText: I bought this book along with a new potty training seat for my almost 2 year old daughter.  I thought it would be a great book to go along with the theme, and something we could start reading at bed time.  The book itself is great, my daughter loves the author's books.  The problem is that one of the pages in the copy that was sent to us is upside down, so it makes it very difficult to read together.  I will definitely be hesitant to buy another children's book online without being able to check for this again!

Absolutely adore this book!  It is very well written and ever so delicately handled on such a subject as potty training.

The illustrations are top notch and catch the eye of the child as he/she focuses on just the baby trying to figure out how to go potty.  No background distractions or bright colors to keep the child focused on what the subject matter is.

The book keeps the child's interest till the very end and yet the child knows what the author is talking about.  Very nicely done!!

My 20 month-old son's interest in the potty waxes and wanes, but boy does he love the 'Polly book!" He loves everything about this and so do I - illustrations and design are gorgeous and clear, and the story is great and leaves room for flexibility (and teaches NOT to imitate how the doggie pees).
My daughter loves to read this book. We are introducing the potty and this book seems to help. Simple graphics, easy read. I would recommend it for both boys and girls.

Leslie Patricelli is hit or miss with me. Some of her books are great, and others I think are really stupid (ie "Higher Higher"). At first this book fell into the latter category and I did not like it at all. It seemed way too watered down and simple with too many "vague" pages (like a two-page spread of the baby holding himself going "Eeee, Mmm, Ahh, Ooo") and not enough explanation about what is happening (example: no mention of the words `pee' or `poo' or any other words of the sort aside from "potty" which most babies are associating with the toilet seat themselves, yet there are FOUR pages on "Where does kitty go? [turn page] Oh. Where does doggy go?..." with simply a picture of the cat by itself and then the cat standing in a [liter] box. I mean, really? You have to come to so many conclusions on your own on so many pages, a toddler under two is not able to draw those when these are first time experiences). Anyway, sure enough, my little one (maybe 15 months at the time) didn't like it either at first. He became bored instantly. So I had plans to return it, but because I put it out of sight, it fell out of mind very quickly. So after finally printing the return packing slip and putting it in a box a couple months later, I thought I'd give it another whirl before shipping it off, and whaddayaknow, the tot loves it now! (17 months). And of course his favorite page?... the two page spread of the baby holding himself going "Eeee, Mmm, Ahh, Ooo". And now I just improvise with the words and take the liberties of adding my own explanations where one is lacking (the whole book) (final pages: baby sitting on potty trying, waiting, turn page, waiting, bored, asleep, turn page, perks up "what's that?", turn page, *tinkle tinkle toot* "I did it!" turn page, *undies*!)...weird. But he likes it and the pics are obviously cute, so I guess that's all that matters is that it's working.
summary: extremely simple, but add some of your own words and it's perfect

reviewText: The words are simple, the pictures are captivating, and the story is easy to follow for toddlers (in preparation for, during, and after potty training).  My son just turned two and he requests this book before bedtime more than any other book. I often add in my own words to explain more, but if you read the words given, it's still gripping enough to hold the attention of a small child. This is a great book to use when attempting to spark good, fun feelings about using the potty! Highly recommended!
summary: This book is a HUGE hit with my child!

reviewText:
We're doing EC (elimination communication) with our 5mo, and have recently started transitioning him from being held over the toilet to sitting on his own on the potty. This book has been keeping him entertained while he's getting used to the idea. Even though we're pretty sure he's nowhere near being able to follow the plot, he loves the pictures (the surprised baby especially makes him giggle). Alas, sometimes he just wants to chew the cover, and the book isn't waterproof enough to withstand that well.

Pros:
- great story (for a toilet book ;)
- beautiful drawings
- plenty of pages (long enough to work as relaxing distraction)
- comfortable to hold even for an infant
- plenty of emotions on baby's face - great for teaching feelings as well

Cons:
- easily damaged by water/saliva (but not really designed with orally-obsessed 5mos in mind, so that's understandable)
summary: Beautiful, funny, and our 5mo loves it

reviewText: While we loved Yummy/Yucky and Birthday Box, I'm just not sure what I think about this book.  The pictures are great and honestly they tell the whole story.  It's very cute and amusing.  There are almost no words, however, and no words at all on several pages so you have to kind of make it up as you go.  This is fine if you are that sort of parent but, for those of us Type-A types, it's a little off-putting.  We've only had the Potty book two days though so I'm willing to give it a chance and work on my storytelling and improv skills.
summary: Almost no words makes it a little harder to read to kiddos

reviewText: My son is being potty trained and achieving good results. This book has helped a lot in my opinion. It is durable and non-rippable.  Well worth the price !
summary: Has helped my 2 1/2 year old a lot !

reviewText:
Love the fact that this is a board book. We got it from the bookstore, and it was actually the only potty training book my husband could find. While this isn't going to tell your child step by step  on how to use the potty, it is quite entertaining if you can read it the right way to them.
When my daughter was potty training, she loved reading this book on the potty or just for bed time. The "bye bye diaper" in the book was a big deal to her, at that point she refused to wear diapers anymore.
One thing that we really enjoyed to do was while she was trying, we'd count the undies at the end of the book. Anything you can do to occupy your little one when they're on the pot trying will greatly increase their chances of going, well at least in my case! It seemed whenever she was occupied, that's when something would happen! We would count the undies, and also name the types of images, ie. polka dots, stars, super hero, colors, etc., that were on the undies too.
At a younger potty training age, this is a good book, it's tough, and not to say you should try this, but if it were to fall in, the book is pretty resilient against liquid!

It remains to be seen if this is at all helpful with potty training, but "Potty Book" is a current favorite with our 19-month-old, who would like for us to read it over and over ... and over and over ... again.
Best buy ever. I am introducing my twin 13 mo old boys to the Portugal they love this book! We read it on the lofty, they point at the pics and shake their heads. A must have in my opinion!
My 22 month old loves this book! She continually brings it to us to read to her. She also loves to read it on the potty. The book is very simple, but it does the job.

This is easily my 17 month old daughter's favorite book. She always wants to read it and I think she's starting to get the idea, pointing at her butt when we read sometimes, etc. I agree with another reviewer that there is not enough detail about wiping and hand washing. Also, maybe this would be gross, but "tinkle tinkle toot" are hardly explanations for what goes in in the potty. Kids need to SEE the wee and poop in order to know what they're supposed to be doing.
But the simple illustrations are great, and the baby and animals seem to fascinate my daughter.
The book is cute, but even my one year old has tired of it quickly.  Not one of her go-to books for the potty.
This is a great Book. My niece loved this book.  It really helped her along with her potty training. The book was in Excellent condition. Speedy delivery!

We have purchased over 5 different potty books for my 20 month old son, but none of them held his attention.. until this one!  My son loves the babies expressions, and loves following the baby while he makes the decision to use the potty.  When the baby actually uses the potty (it is a very cute and funny page), my son laughs every time!  I also enjoy reading the book... which makes a huge difference when you have to read it over and over.  My son asks for this book, which he has never done with any other potty book.

All of Leslie Patricellis books we've purchased so far have been big hits in our home!  I also highly recommend "No No, Yes Yes", my son absolutely loves it, which I find wonderful because it teaches some great lessons on what is and is not ok to do (color on walls, run away from a parent, ect.)
summary: The only "Potty" book my son likes

reviewText: this book is cute, and pretty straight to the point. My son has already asked us to read it multiple times since it arrived yesterday. It's a good book for introducing the idea of going potty.

My 26 mo. old son loves this potty book.  We put him on the potty and it's the only time he gets to read it.  Today, he went poo poo on the potty and looked a little worried until I pulled this book out and showed him the picture of the mommy and daddy celebrating.  He was so happy and ran around the house saying "no more diaper."  It's the first time he's confident pooping in the potty.
summary: Little man loves to potty with this book

reviewText: There are already a lot of reviews on this, but I just wanted to say this book is my favorite Leslie Patricelli book. Very cute and very funny. Buy this for your toliet training toddler!

My son of 1.5 years LOVES this book! The wear and tear on this book alone makes me happy that it is a hardbook. I read it over and over and over, he loves to see this little baby, and makes the surprise face the baby makes when he finally uses the potty for the first time :) Great book! No regrets!

This book is just not very good.  It did not hold my child's interest at all.  The illustrations aren't great and the explanation about how to use the potty is really lacking.  Also, as a parent, it is hard to read this book because there is not much writing . . . just the illustrations.

This book is a simple and effective way to slowly introduce children to the concept of potty. Bright, cheerful illustrations, clear text, and a simple message that is positive and easy for children to understand.

Highly recommend this book as an easy way to start talking about the components of potty training in a low-stress way.

We are just introducing the concept of potty training to my 19 month old daughter and she loves this book! I got it for her along with her new "big girl" potty chair Fisher-Price Cheer for Me! Potty. She hated her other potty chair Safety 1st Nature Next 3-in-1 Potty, Lime, but when I got both of these delivered to my door, she sat right down on her new potty and read this book. She has been reading it over and over and maybe one of these days we'll actually get some potty to happen :)
I'm starting potty training on the early side (15 months) and I really hope this will help us!  It's a cute, simple book.

My daughter is not quite ready for the potty yet but I saw this book and thought it would be good to get her at least familiar with the idea.  This book is adorable and definitely seems like a good starter.

My son is almost 16 months old and a little young for potty training.  However, he was showing some interest so I bought this book along with a potty.  He LOVES this book!  He will ask for me to read it to him every single day, 3 or 4 times in a row (one of the few books that he will actually sit through).  I don't know if it's due to the book, but he is also starting to use the potty more consistently as well.
Our 2 1/2 year old laughs out loud when we read this book!  It is very funny and gets the point across to our future potty trained son.

reviewerName: Only Because of the Grace of God
reviewText: I just borrowed this book from the library and I have to own it. My daughter is 3 and since I have been reading this book to her and she can read it to herself. She has improved pretty quickly. I bought her the book A Potty For Me but unfortunately my daughter seems to want to gravitate to the "I don't think I can yet" so I have stopped reading it to her. This book gets to the point and my daughter wants to hear it and read it over and over. I am currently expecting now 18 weeks...I know that this will be perfect for the new baby when its time for this baby to start potty training.
It was a fun little book and my grandson liked it.  We even took it into the bathroom with us.

I have purchased other books to inspire my 2 year old grandaughter to use the potty but this is the first that has gotten her to talk about it out loud and think how it all works. I love how it shows that the kitty and the doggie also go potty certain places too.

I ordered this based on the fabulous reviews (it's cheaper on Walmart.com just FYI), and I'm so glad I did! We are trying to introduce the idea of potty-training to our two-year-old, and this book did the job beautifully. I was amazed when after finishing this book my son immediately said, "Potty!" And went to the bathroom and wanted to sit on his new little throne. We got him all situated, and he demanded that the book be read over and over to him! He loved it. Such a fun, simple book. I highly recommend it!

I bought this for my two year old niece. She and I love this book. My sister, on the other hand, quickly pointed out to me that the little kid is naked in a lot of the book. That didn't bother my niece, but my seven year old niece giggled through all the pages where he is naked.

My 2 year old daughter really enjoys this book and asks for it often.  I love how it relates to what the doggy and kitty do -- it resonated with her.  I believe this book helped to spark interest in potty training in our house.

My 2 year old son enjoys this book. The pictures are simple but he finds them interesting and entertaining. I think this book has helped him with the whole potty concept. I would definitely recommend!

My son loves Leslie's books, especially the Yummy Yucky book. This book is cute and my son, who is almost 2, likes to giggle when reading it with me. His favorite part is the Tinkle Tinkle Toot. He cracks up every time.

I bought this book to read to my 2 year old daughter to start discussing potty training.  She loves the book, the pictures are cute, it doesn't get too graphic.  It's perfect for what I wanted it for.
summary: Great book to start potty training

reviewText: I bought this for great neice and nephew and we had a lot of fun with this simple and funny book. They enjoyed the illustrations and telling one another the story of the little boy going to the potty. Time will tell if it worked:-)

I bought this book along with 2 other potty training books. When I read this one, I was disappointed with how short it was. But my son loves it!!! He is only 2 so he can remember most of the words unlike the longer books. He uses his potty often when we read this book. It's worth trying- highly recommend!!

I looked at about 7 kids books in the book store about learning to go on the potty. I got this one (and only this one actually) because it's really simple and straightforward as well as being cute and light-hearted. I love that it shows how the cat and dog go potty because we have pets and that has really resonated with my toddler. The page with the parents being so joyful and all the different undies is really funny. I think this book is probably best for younger toddlers- 30 months and under.

Purchased for great-nephew who is potty training.  His Mom says he reads it over and over and he is currently doing very well potty training.  Did the book help?  Maybe so, but he did enjoy it either way.

I really love this sweet book.  We first checked it out from our local library on a whim, but my daughter (almost two) liked it so much that we went ahead and bought it.  Besides the fact that my daughter likes it so much, I love this book for the following reasons:

1. It shows just the right amount
Some potty books just go too far in how much of the body they show and it's just awkward to me.  Then there are other potty books on the other end of the spectrum that have kids wearing underwear while they're sitting on the potty.  Not helpful when you're trying to teach a little one how to use the potty.  This book shows just enough to be helpful and instructive, but there are no awkward moments in pointing things out on the little kid in the book.  And because it doesn't show any private parts, it's great both boys and girls!

2. The story is funny and true to life
Both my daughter and I love all the funny faces the kid in the book makes.  She'll copy the faces all the time and it cracks us up.  She also thinks it's funny when the kid forgets to take off his diaper before he sits on the potty.  I think, even though it's just something silly, it's also something she can really relate to and understand.

3. The artwork is charming
The illustrations are simply charming.  They have lots of great color and they're easy for my daughter to understand.

4. It's really engaging
We've checked out several potty books from the library for my daughter who's almost two.  She's shown interest in a lot of the books, but not for as long or as much as this book.  It's truly made her excited to use the potty and wear panties.  Half the time I think she just wants to try and go on the potty so she can read this book.

Hopefully this is helpful if you're looking at buying it online and haven't been able to flip through it before.  We love it!

Okay--this was offered as People who buy Potty Chair by this.

And I have to say I am surprisingly pleased. The art work and text are just right---and its funny as well.

Grand daughter loves reading it and I have it right by the Potty chair so she can sit and we can read it.

No pressure, just fun.

When to ditch the diaper? Only a toddler knows when the time is right, but when the time gets close Potty will be there to encourage our young future potty users along. Go along with Baby as he discovers what it means to go on the potty instead of outside like a dog or in a litter box like a kitty, but on the potty like a big kid. From potty time with book in hand and kitty and doggie napping at his feet all the way to Baby's first pair of underpants. Show your toddler just what it means to lose the diaper and make time for the potty.

You name it, we've tried it. Two different potty's, treats, cheerios, m & m's, stickers, many many books, and more. Nearly every trick you can think of to get our dear sweet Turkeybird onto the potty and out of the diaper, but no way. That is, until his little sister picked up this book and took matters into her own hands. Littlebug adores this book, and so do I.

In classic Leslie Patricelli form with bold illustrations and a funny story kiddos are introduced to a new world of possibility on their terms. Which is exactly what Littlebug loves about this book.
