reviewText: Cant wait to buy more if these.  Soooo educational

This book was too easy and boring for my 3.5-year-old. If your child has never done tracing activities and is still learning letters, numbers and shapes, then it might be ok. But otherwise I would look elsewhere.

The book starts out with tracing activities - drawing lines, following curved paths, etc. When my daughter had turned 2, I bought her the Kumon tracing book which has these same types of activities. I had also created tracing activities at home just with paper and pencil (I draw letters or shapes and have her trace them -- that was so fun for her a few months ago). I think the tracing section is probably good practice if a child hasn't already been exposed to that type of activity, but otherwise it's boring.

The book then moves into colors and shapes, such as "color the hearts red" or  "trace the rectangles." This might be good if your kid is still learning shapes and colors, but we have pretty much skipped all of those pages.

Then comes the alphabet section. Each letter has about 4 activities, and they are all the same! First the letter is introduced with a coloring page, e.g., letter C has a picture of a cat to be colored. Then comes circling words beginning with c. Then is a page with pictures and five hidden letter C's, followed by a maze. Some other letters have activities such as "color all the kites that have a letter k on them." There are way too many color pages, which just feel like filler material.

My daughter likes the mazes, so that's all we have done with the letter pages. Occasionally she will humor me into doing the activity to find the words beginning with a certain letter, but that's too easy for her.

The number pages feel less repeaty and are a little more fun since they involve counting. However, my daughter likes to count and is very into numbers and simple math, so maybe it's just based on child preference. Sample activities for the numbers are "color the rocket ships that have 3 windows" or "circle the aliens that have 3 eyes."

The activities that do seem to be challenging for her are the connect the dot pictures. I help her quite a bit with those.

In the back of the book are concepts such as same and different, finding matching images, finding images that go together, crossing out the picture that doesn't belong, etc. These are a little more fun, but again, that might be child preference.

This book would get more stars if such a large portion weren't devoted to repeat activities.

We like the Comprehensive Curriculum pre-k book better.

reviewText:
This book is nicely huge and has perforated pages that make it easy to remove a page if you want kiddo to work independently without writing in the entire book. I have a three year old that has never really been exposed to work pages before but she was very excited when I pulled this from the box and she couldn't wait to work on it... I helped her through a few of the trace mazes and she tried. She did get frustrated after a few pages because I would insist that she try to stay within the line and not just draw a straight line from place to place, but she will learn.
I do suggest that if your child isn't familiar with this type of stuff that you walk them through a few times before letting them try on their own.
Great summer workbook. Would purchase again.
This book has a variety of preschool activities inside that build upon prior knowledge. Great book.

This is my second time buying this book. I bough it four years ago for my son and just resently my four year old daughter. It is a great intro into preschool learning. Colorful pages. Easy to understand. Fun pictures.
i bought it for someone else i don't know how much they like it
summary: ... for someone else i don't know how much they like

reviewText: My preschooler loves the mazes and the games.  There are a lot of fine motor skills and coloring activities in this book.  Tracing lines and shapes before getting to letters. Every page has bright colors and pictures to keep them engaged.  I bought it for my older child when he was a preschooler and now purchased another one for my daughter. This is the best preschool workbook I have found.

Well thought out, fun ways to learn letters, letter sounds, writing, shape and color recognition, mazes, and more. Offers options for different types of learners. My boy often asks to do it.
I wish I had time to do some every day. We would both have a great time.

My daughter loved working in this book.  It allowed her to grasp the basic concepts that she needed to while still having fun.  This book includes several different ways for children to learn.  My daughter really loved the coloring pages, and I loved that she was still learning while she was having fun.  She really enjoyed the reward system too, and would often choose to wear her stickers rather than put them on the pages because she was so proud to earn them.  We did about 3 pages a day and this book lasted us for quite awhile.  I was thankful that the pages were easy to tear out because we often did the pages at the park or at other locations.  This is a great book and it will give your child a firm foundation for their future learning experiences.
summary: My daughter would wake me up early to work in this book!

reviewText: Good stuff. A couple pages we don't care too much about but overall very useable.

The pictures in this workbook are in full color, making it easy for kids to become engaged with the material. I have taken the book apart at the perforations and slipped each page into a page protector so kids in my preschool can use dry erase markers to write and wipe off, making this a book that will last for many years to come. There are letters, numbers, and colors and shapes children can work on. Highly recommend.
Love this book.
Pretty simple stuff- lots of mazes/trace the path.
i am a preschool teacher and i love this book. i use this workbook at home with my own daughter. it is fun, colorful, and a great resource.

reviewText: I bought this book for my 4y/o son so that we could work on getting used to "homework" plus he is really smart so I just want the wheels to keep in turning! The age range says 4-5yrs I believe and I think its perfect for him, there are activities that are easy for him as well as some areas he struggles in.  I think its a nice thing to do with your child, he learns to be patient and listen for the directions, there are a lot of search and find pages in here along with patterns and last night we did and activity were he has to circle the group of items that were "Less" or "Greater"! There are happy and sad faces in there that he would have to see the scenario and then choose what face goes with that scenario.  There are some coloring activities in there and to be quit honest I'm not fond of those he has coloring books so when we do our "homework" I am not preparing to color but still as an all around book its really nice!

I highly recommend this and all the BIG Workbooks in the series.

reviewText: I have been looking for workbooks to recommend for parents of preschoolers.  There are so many materials out about letters and numbers, little children need to see and talk about other vocabulary and concepts too, like the name and function of familiar things, "things that go together," same and different, early prepositions, matching, etc. This thick book has mostly letter, number, and color activities, with a slim section at the back illustrating some early concepts.  It is a disappointing purchase, but still works as a starting place for parents who need some help and confidence, knowing what to talk about with their little ones. It sells for about $10. at our local Walgreens (2 for $19.) and at Walmart, so I saved a little money buying them here.
summary: not as thorough as I'd hoped.

reviewText: Awesome workbook. It starts at the simpler level a child needs when beginning preschool, then expands to more difficult lessons they should be understanding at the end of the year. My 3-year-old daughter had problems just coloring and writing lines, but after a few weeks of working with this book (plus a little extra), she has both things down and can draw pictures and write beginning letter shapes.

A huge book full of a great variety of activities covering numerous preschool topics. I have several workbooks for my son, but this is by far my favorite. The bright colors and easy instructions appeal to him... he's always excited when I pull out the book for a lesson. I would highly recommend!

reviewText: As a homeschool mom, I try not to push my kids into anything they aren't ready for. I build skills slowly. My 3 year old has been asking for "school" because big sister has workbooks,  etc... Coloring books weren't doing it for my 3yr old anymore! So I purchased something at walmart on a whim (MEAD PreK). Total failure! Way too advanced! But after looking at amazon I found this workbook, I got immediately excited because I remembered using this brand for my eldest but in K! This is Perfection!!! It's starts out with TRACING LINES. I find it ridulous that other PreK books expect kids to trace letters when they haven't learned to draw a straight line or complete a circle! This starts slow, tracing lines, then tracing shapes, reviews colors, coloring by number, and it doesn't leave out letters and numbers! Colorful and engaging! Perfect for my 3 year old! We are doing a page or two a day and when we are done she says "thank you for my schoolwork mommy!" How great is that?!?!
summary: EXACTLY WHAT I WAS LOOKING FOR!!!

reviewText: I absolutely love this workbook. It is huge! There are so many activities, the pages are nicely perforated for displaying on the fridge, it is very bright and colorful, and there are a large variety of activities to try. My 3 year old loves it! If you only buy one activity book, buy this one.
My kids love these pages.
Great way to keep preschool learning ongoing over the summer.
My kids loved this book. I wish it had more pages to practice each skill. It moved too quickly through skills.
This was a fantastic and huge workbook; very comprehensive.

I love these books and for the price you cannot go wrong, my daughter wanted to do more and more and more and more. One day she did about 20 pages in one sitting. :) She had fun! I just have to tell her what to do and she goes for it.
Great product and great service.  Will do business again if necessary. Thanks Jake.

I was afraid this book might be boring like other preschooler books but it's not! The color pages definitely grab my four year old's attention and she loves the activities that build up to letters and numbers! It's great to practice with pencils and use dexterity before jumping into the hard stuff. She has been bored with other preschool books, so this was a huge relief and it's a great price!

I bought this to help my son practice holding and using a pencil. I like that it starts simple and adds difficulty gradually. He enjoys that each page is a little different. He actually gets excited when I pull out the book.
My 3-yr old great-granddaughter loved it. It kept her attention for longer than most things would. Are there not more like it?
Very educational.  Easy for a preschooler.  Good practice.  Would reorder.

Can NOT say enough good things about this book!!!  It is enormous and BEAUTIFUL.  Every page is in full color, (unless the child is supposed to color it him/herself) and it's so cute and happy and very cleverly designed to challenge and stimulate learning in a young child.  My preschooler LOVES it and begs me to get it out and let her do her "homework".  I did buy other books for her, but I'm so glad I got this one.  It was a PERFECT starting place.  My only complaint is that we need more! Even with 320 pages, she's blazing through and I wish I had 2-3 other books just like this one lined up behind it.  It is so WELL DONE and thoughtfully created.  The people who put this together definitely know preschoolers and how to get them learning!  I can't recommend it highly enough!
summary: MORE books just like this one, please!!

That being said, there was still material in the book to keep her interested & other things for her to learn, like differences in pictures, what item doesn't belong, how to draw letters, etc. I'd say it's a great book to keep them entertained if they like learning.

reviewText: I love this book. It has so many learning activities. Writing, math, spelling, colors, shapes and much much more. Very recommended for children that are preparing for school.

My grandson likes it ok. I find too much repetition. I would have preferred more variety in skills. He does use his finger instead of a pencil on many pages. This way he can do the activities again and again.

In only 2 days, my daughter has covered more than 10 pages of activities without any pressure in our side.  She is almost 3 and loves the idea of completing activities by herself with just some basic instructions.  The activities are very appropriate to avoid any frustration feeling but still are a little challenging for those growing minds!!! Totally recommended.

I first saw this book in a local grocery store, though found a better price on Amazon. The book is part of a series each geared towards a different grade level (i.e. Preschool, Kindergarden..etc). I have been looking for a book like this for my 3-year old daughter for some time and was glad to have found this book. I was first surprised by how many pages are included in this book (320). Each page has different activities on each side of the page ranging from tracing to shapes to number games. Each activity seems very age appropriate (3-5). I was also surprised by how many of the pages included color. I feel like this is a huge strength in the book as it helps keep the children more focused on the activity. Definitely worth the money in my opinion.

I ordered a few of these books. I am just repeating the review under all of them because they are all great. I used all of these books to teach my daughter at home instead of paying for preschool. I also used other hands on things to teach. These books helped a lot. She is now in 1st grade and a straight A student. When she entered kindergarten they gave a test to see if she was ready....she had surpassed their testing. These books along with other one on one teaching will really help you either homeschool your child or help your child if they need help in a particular subject. They are totally worth every penny paid for them.
My little one enjoyed this so much! I literally had to ask to save some pages for the next day. Loved it so much that it wasn't like work at all. Very engaging & would buy again.
I let my kids pick pages at random to do from this workbook and it has provided hours of fun learning for them.
summary: Covers a wide range of activities

reviewText: I flipped through the this, and it looks like an excellent activity book with great colors and characters. I'm sure my daughter will love it, and I will enjoy helping her with it. 2/13/14 My daughter loves sitting down with me and practicing on a few pages at a time. It starts with simple lines then progresses to letters and shapes. There are puzzles (what doesn't belong in this group, math, and much more. Great book.

reviewText: I bought that for my daughter year before we planned to put her in preschool. Great preparation, gives a great start to little preschoolers..

We got this for my daughter when she was about 3 1/2 and she's been working her way steadily through it. Good quality pages (that are perforated to tear out easily), colorful, with a great variety of tasks. Most of them she finds just a little challenging but enjoyable. Occasionally she finds something too hard (like making a check mark) but it's easy to adapt. We've bought a number of these kinds of workbooks and this one really is the best of the bunch.
i had a bad experience with my purchase, but the book itself was fantastic! LOTS of stuff for the kids to work on. REALLY recommend the book!

My 4 year old son enjoyed working in his workbook every day several times a day. Many activities to keep him busy. He has learned so much in a short amount of time using this workbook. He is way ahead of the game. I would definitely recommend this workbook.

Bought these for a preschool group, then had more kids join. The second "set" of books I ordered were different from the first, even tho the cover was exactly the same....down to the number in the top corner... Was really bummed! So be careful...if you need for a group...order them all at once! :(
This has letters, shapes, mazes, coloring... everything you need. I totally recommend it for your preschooler! I purchased this for a daycare and the children loved using these large books!
My grand daughter loves this book. It's engaging, entertaining and educational! And, the activities are right on for a preschooler!
I'm not sure how educational this 'workbook' is, but it is definitely a great coloring book!  My daughter loved coloring each of the pages, with total disregard for the instructions.

This book was half the size I thought it would be. Not worth it with shipping and handling charges. Wish I had went to a bookstore you could open up books and look at. Good book but not enough work.  Not worth price plus shipping and handling.  Book will not last long and I will need to buy much more material to teach them concepts they only introduce briefly.
summary: Very small and came with no stickers

reviewText: this is perfect my daughter who is looking for summer educational ideas to keep children occupied.  The perfect gift for all three of them.
This is a great preschool book that teaches the important things needed to know for kindergarten and is much cheaper than preschool!
I chose this book for my 4yr old child and other daycare children, it helps them out drastically!!! They will be well ahead of the other kids in their class once they begin kindergarten

My four year old son is not known for his patience and yet, with this workbook, he is all Mr. Serious.  The workbook contains multiple sections:

1. Basic Math
2. Tracing
3. Maze
4. Capital Letter writing
5. Coloring

It's a fun activity book, which lets kids work on a whole variety of topics and opens up their horizons.

What I think this book is missing - stickers.  Lots of kids LOVe stickers, especially as a reward.  For example, for each completed page, it would be nice to give them a sticker.  Another good activity:  say, there are pictures of various animals and you have stickers for 2-3.  Kids can do a matching exercise.  A perfect way to practice fine motor skills.
I am excited that my 3 year old likes this book and is working with it.  Of course I do it with her, but it is great to go over things she is already learning.

I have used these books with all 3 of my children and I have really loved them.  The books have changed throughout the years, but I have liked the changes.  The reason I like them is that the amount of writing is just right.  Kids can learn their colors, numbers and letters before they can write them.  I like that the book contains little writing and instead focuses on circling and a little bit of coloring.  I also like how the book is organized.  I pull one sheet from each color every time my son sits down to do the school work.  I also love the bright colors and pictures.  If a child does not know what a picture is than it is a good time to tell them what new things are.  My 3 yr old son begs to do school work.

I started these books with all 3 of my kids at 3yrs old.  My 3 yr old son (who is almost 4) is now about 1/2 way through the kindergarten book.  All of my children seemed to have similiar pacing.  The transition between preschool and kind books are perfect.  As he has been able to do it all without struggling and little help (except reading the directions and covering new concepts).  I think the ages are not quite right though, but that does not really matter to me.  It is really geared for 3 to 4 yr olds and the kinder book should be finished before starting kindergarten as our kindergarten expects you to know everything in it.  After the kindergarten book there is a big gap which i am not sure how to fill (they need a transition between the Kinder and 1st grade book) as my son understands the concepts of reading and can sound out very simple words.  He is still a long way from reading fluently.  My other son is doing well in 1st grade and is just now finishing the 1st grade book.  The have made the kinder and preschool books more user friendly and actually easier, but along the way they jumped too much from one age level to the next.

The preschool book is good for 3-4 yr olds
The kindergarten book is good for 4-5 yr olds
**School zone needs to make a book here!
The 1st grade book is good for 6-7 yr olds
summary: I love the school zone books!

reviewText: These were good, but a little too easy for even my 3 year old.  He needed a bit more challenge, but the kindergarten one seems to jump quite a bit. I wish it started easy and got harder, but its really the same level throughout the book.
This book is great to get the children practicing basic skills. I bought it for my 3 year old and he loves when we sit and complete pages together. Its fun learning!
This book came quickly and was as advertised!  We are homeschooling our children and this has been a great resource to help teach them!

I bought this for my 3 year old because he wants to "do school" like his big brother.  He was able to do maybe a third of the book.  The other 2 thirds are perfect for my 5 year old pre-schooler, so he does those sections.
My son loves activity books!! I try to get them in stores, but I can't. The product is like new.
This book was just what I was looking for.  Have a 3 1/2 year old granddaughter who wants to "learn" so bad.  Started her on pages from this book and "Wow", she doesn't want to stop her "homework"!
summary: Great Buy to help little ones learn before school!

reviewText: I bought this for my grandson and was disappointed with how little work really exists. Some of the exercises are good but many are page fillers
My son and I went through this book to do some of the activities. We were amazed at how fun it was. Thanks for the great product.
Good size, bright colors, lots of fun things for my preschooler to do to make her feel like a big girl while her big brothers do their school work too.

I saw this at a pharmacy and found it cheaper on here, but of course.  I love that it really is "BIG" and thick, FULL of bright and attention grabbing colors, and that it keeps a good pace.  I let our 3 year old do as many pages as she wants to in a sitting.  It's nice that it doesn't jump all over the place.  Toddlers need practice and it gives a few pages of the same general concept, although it is still different and keeps the attention.

I'm SO glad we got this!

I bought this for my 4 year old and it's aweseome. Great price and the activities range from stuff for 2 1/2 to around 5 (depending on child's level). I would recommend this to parents who want to prepare children for preschool or to support what your child is already learning in preschool.

My daughter just turned 4 last month.  This book was exciting for her because of the bright pictures and quality; however, the content was WAY TOO EASY for her.  Simple line tracing and coloring... picking out which picture is different from the other two... She whipped through each page in moments.

Good for self esteem I suppose.  I prefer the Brain Quest Pre-K workbook though... it's a bit more advanced.
summary: a bit too easy / but enjoyable and bright

reviewText: if anything it could be bigger. 4 yoa grand daughter loves the book and was able to enjoy it unassisted.

My 3.5 year old daughter loves this book.  Her tracing is getting better and she loves to work on her writing.  It is nice because you can jump to different topics and skills so that you don't burn your kid out.  My daughter loves to pick what thing we are going to do next so she feels like she is in charge of her learning and enjoys it even more

It does require you to sit and work with your child since they can't read, but it makes it fun to learn along with your kiddo.  My daughter has gone to a few hours of preschool a week for a year and we aren't going to be able to do that anymore so this will be our main school resource for her to learn from home.

The book is listed for ages 3 - 5, but for us, I think it would be better for someone closer to three than 5.  The pages are nice quality, easy to use both the left and right side of the book, and my 4 1/2 year old likes going through it on her own.  It's not challenging enough for me to go through it with her as I was hoping (at least at the beginning of the book), but there are definite skills that she can work on by using it.  A nice variety of skills, also - a LOT of tracing.  The skills do progress as you go through the book.

I ordered this for my 2 year old son, hoping he would enjoy it.  Since he's only 2, I put all the pages inside individual page protectors,bound them in a binder, and let him go to town on them with dry erase crayons.  He loves it.  With over 300 pages to choose from, he can use this book for a couple years & never get tired of doing the same thing.
The book is broken into sections.  There's a section where you "follow the path" starting from straight lines to curved lines, and ending with mazes.  Then there's letters (A is for...), numbers (Can you find 7 ____), colors& shapes (Color the triangles purple), along with other beginner things.

Overall it's an activity book that children will love without realizing that they are learning because it's so much fun.  I would recommend this book to anyone with kids aged 2-5.

I do like this book, and have found some things in it that will be valuable to my 4 year old son.  However, most of those pages are helpful because they are coloring, which he needs practice with.  He has known all of his letters and numbers since he was 2, so most of these skills were not helpful to him.  So if your child is already comfortable with recognizing letters and numbers, I think I would try to find something more challenging.  Most of the pages in this book are connect the dots or coloring.  It is helpful with letter writing skills, and with teaching him to follow directions.  I do wish it was more challenging, though.
summary: Good book, but better for younger kids.

reviewText: I am a stay at home Mom (SAHM) of 2 and we took my son out of private preschool because we were literally paying for him to get sick.  It was not cost effective for us.  He is very smart and I have taught him a lot using unconventional methods.  Now that he will attend public Kindergarten, I needed him to learn the way he would in school.  He enjoys this book but he isn't the type to love the coloring part and there is too much for him.  Other than that, he really does like it.  I bought another one for my youngest (22 months) and will let her use it when she gets a bit older.
summary: Great way to prep for Kindergarten

reviewText: My 3 year old wants to be big like her sibling.  So we got her this book so she can do homework too.  It's been great and my children have worked on it together and I have noticed some improvement on her letter writing skills.  Lots of fun too!
summary: Great to help little ones learn

reviewText: I bought several workbooks for my kids and they liked this one the most.  Lots of great lettering and numbering pages for them to work on.

I haven't used this book since when we discovered school zone my daughter was a bit past this(definitely will be picking it up for the next 2), but we use the kindergarten book and it is great.  It's huge, relevant, colorful, and thorough.  I definitely recommend the "big" workbook series from school zone!
summary: if it's anything like the kindergarten book

reviewText: Great beginner workbook for Very Young Children. Very Colorful. Goes thru teaching beginner writting skills, alphabet, numbers, colors, and shapes. You will not be disappointed as long as you are looking for a very beginners books.
Only buy this if you own a copier or you plan on buying a copier or even multiple copies of this book. This book us a random compilation of activities that didn't teach my preschooler anything.

I've really enjoyed using this workbook with my almost-3-year-old. It's a very thick book with tons of color printed, tear-out pages for your child to work on. My daughter loves coloring in it, but also enjoys sitting down with mom and learning. So far she hasn't made it past the tracing lessons in the beginning of the book, writing letters in the next section has proved to be a little too advanced for her. But I think this book is going to be a great starter textbook for her as she nears the pre-school age. We plan on homeschooling, and while homeschooling technically begins at the beginning of your child's life, this is a great "starter" work book for the 3 year-old.
Got for my grandchild for Christmas and she loved it!  Saw it later at a big box store for a couple dollars more, so I was pleased with the quality and the price.

My 2-1/2 year-old granddaughter loves this book.  She points to it on the shelf where I keep it and tells me, "Ready for school, Gamma."  This means she wants me to get it down and help her work on a few pages.  I'm always ready to quit before she is...she'd like to spend much more time learning.

I have been using this workbook with my 3 year old on days she doesn't go to preschool. They have some great activities, however I would suggest ripping the pages out because the book is so thick it makes it difficult to lay the pages out flat and get them to write or draw correctly. Some of the activities are way too easy but many of them are challenging.

Bought for $10 at Wal-Mart. Cheaper here if you get free shipping. As for the quality of the book, I don't know yet. We just bought it. I will say it's certainly BIG. Most of the other workbooks at Wal-Mart had closer to 100 pages.

My son just turned three in August, but he has already completed this book.  We did a few pages everyday - I think we spent a couple of months on it.  He is now able to write upper and lowercase letters, and can do simple math concepts, such as greater vs. lesser, which group has more...there are mazes, coloring activities, and a variety of lessons to teach shapes, sizes, counting, writing, etc.

What I liked best about this book is the different phrases that they use in the instructions.  My son learned the relationship between phrases "which ones match" and "where does it belong", "which one is different" and "which one is not the same"...just to name a couple.  My son immediately applied what he learned from the book to his everyday activities, so I know that he did absorb some, if not all, the lessons.

Since this book is a combination of smaller books from School Zone, it's not necessary to buy the others unless your child has trouble with a particular area.  My son struggled with the pages dealing with "beginning sounds," so I bought him the book that is just activities to teach beginning sounds.

I prefer School Zone to all other preschool workbook series, with the exception of Kumon.
I've been using this workbook to teach my daughter all sorts of preschool activities.  It's been wonderful!  She loves it as well!  Highly reccommended!

It doesn't matter whether your little one is going to grow up to be an engineer, artist, dancer, musician, etc.... The lessons in this book are powerful ones and they hit home.  Don't give up.  Count your successes.  Failure is a natural part of the process.  Don't be ashamed to dream.

Having read this to our daughter twice the same night, you can tell that it got her wheels turning.  I especially liked the reference to Rosie the Riveter (kids won't understand it, but I love the fact that the authors put the reference in there nonetheless).

The book is short enough for a 3-year old and yet may be captivating enough for a slightly older crowd as well.  We are very happy to have added it to our personal library.
summary: Great book. Our 3 1/2 year old girl loves it.  Good lessons.

reviewText: My 3-year old daughter and I have been anxiously awaiting a follow up to Iggy Peck, Architect.  And Rosie Revere, Engineer  doesn't disappoint.  Possibly the best illustrations from David Roberts and a wonderfully written story by Andrea Beaty with an important message to follow your dreams and persevere.  I highly recommend for any boy or girl (along with Iggy Peck, Architect).  I can't wait for more from this very talented duo.  Love, love, love!
summary: Another hit from author Andrea Beaty and illustrator David Roberts!

reviewText:
Iggy Peck, Architect is one of our family's most treasured books, so I had high, high hopes for Rosie Revere.

It not only does not disappoint, it knocked my socks off!

Rosie is a fabulous character and I love the "life lesson" she learns.  The tie-in with the historical Rosie the Riveter is the icing on the cake.

I will be giving this as a gift to many friends, as I have with Iggy Peck.

I sat down to read it to my 4 year old daughter because the cover looked fun. I wasn't prepared for the life lessons in it for her and for me. With an engaging story that kept her attention and illustrations you could look at over and over again, I found myself reading with a lump in my throat and tears in my eyes as Rosie battled her fear of failure to do great great things. This book is as much for mommies and daddies as their little ones. I may just read it daily.
Love this series.  I ordered a bunch for Christmas presents and they are all still in regular rotation at our house.
Great book to encourage children in regard to STEM.  My grandchildren (ages 4 and 7) really enjoy this book.
great book
A great book for little girls!  My 4 year old loves all of these books!
AAAAAA
I liked it more than my daughter
Love this book!
Great book!
Great book for elementary-age girls. I've purchased all 3 in the series.
No one should be limited to a culture norm. This book celebrates and encourages that.
Was requested as a Christmas gift.
Great story for any young woman to hear!

My husband is an engineer and so I got this book for our daughter. Its adorable and inspiring for a little girl to know she can aspire to be more than just your typical princess. The tale is great and I look forward to buying the other books in the series.
Everyone should get this book. Great story.
I got this for my two year old daughter for Christmas. Her dad is an engineer and I love the message behind it.
summary: Her dad is an engineer and I love the message behind it

reviewText: My 5 year old wants to be an aerospace engineer, so I am always looking for fun little ways to encourage his passion. This book brings him great joy. Ada Twist, Scientist and Rosie Revere, Engineer are always in rotation at our house. This book is a definite must have for your little future scientist!
summary: so I am always looking for fun little ways to encourage his passion

reviewText: Very cute story and really was a good, challenging read for my six year old niece. She is an advanced reader, so she can read it with some help. I think the story is great and encouraging.
summary: Cute, encouraging story for little girls

reviewText: LOVE LOVE LOVE these books they have such a great story and encourage inquisitive minds
Beautiful empowering book any child (and parent) would love.

This is such an empowering book. I love how things did not come easily for Rosie. She had fears, had setbacks, lost confidence for awhile, until someone showed her that even her so called failures are just opportunities to learn and do things better the next time. We had originally borrowed this book from the library and my 5 year old loved it so much. For months she said she wanted to be an engineer when she grew up. Santa gave her this book along with a Brio building set for Christmas. When she unwrapped the book, she exclaimed, My favorite book!
summary: Positive message for girls (and boys too)

reviewText: My daughter is in first grade and loves science. And I always love an opportunity to introduce her to STEM subjects that interest and empower her. I found this book some time back and patiently waited until she was old enough to enjoy them. And it was worth the wait- she loves this book and the others by Andrea Beaty.
Mom and baby love it :D positive female role model :D
My son likes to read it often. Its a cute and interesting story. Totally recommend it for any children
Ok I LOVE this book. I like how it rhymes (sp?) also. My daughter loves this book.
summary: Ok I LOVE this book. I like how it rhymes (sp?) also. My daughter loves this book.

reviewText: Great book as a gift for my niece.

Just read this to my 3 yo daughter and 6 yo son and they loved it. Thematically its perfect for kids who still must learn that failure is a step towards success and to try, try, try again! My son is at an age where he suddenly won't play with girl toys, even though he asked for Owlettes owl glider for Christmas (he got it and rejected it). So I thought he wouldnt enjoy a story with a female main character but he didn't pay attention to that, that the MC is a girl. Which Im glad for, because Id like him to come out the other side of this phase with the understanding that girls rock and can be his best allies. Anyway, I somehow wasn't expecting the Rosie the Riveter tie-in, so when the first hints of it showed up I loved it and loved the opportunity to talk to my son about the We can do it poster and Rosie the Riveter. To sum up, such a great story about both the impact of women in the engineering world and particularly flight, as well as how important determination is. And, though its neither here nor there, I had a really hard time not tearing up as I read it. Stories like this are so important for our kids, especially little girls, so they can see what possibilities there are in the world of STEM for them.
summary: Perfect for both girls and boys!

reviewText: Great addition to this series - both of my girls love to build and tinker, and I love these books to inspire and encourage them.
summary: Great addition to this series - both of my girls ...

reviewText: We need more books with smart girls at the forefront. We bought this for our son, and he loves it.
summary: We need more books with smart girls at the forefront

reviewText: Ok, some of my appreciation for this book attaches to it's connection to the cherished bygone. Rosie the Riveter, the original female who can get the job done and smash gender stereotype is re-introduced in a younger version of a science savvy girl who is equipped to deliver what is needed in today's world. It works. Great job, Andrea Beaty.
Niece loved it.
Great visuals. Great all around. Get it. The best book for 5 year olds. You will not regret it. Your kid won't either.

I'm always looking for books with great female protagonists and this one fits the bill.  Story is great and I love the cadence.  And the illustrations are fabulous.  I love everything written by this author/illustrator duo!
summary: Must-have book for any childrens library

reviewText: Love this book! We have an engineering unit at school and this fits in perfectly. Plus it changes the students view of a engineer just being a man. Shows the students you have to keep trying!

I am an engineer and a mom of two boys, so I had to read it to them. They loved the book! We reread some key life lesson sentences over and over so they would stick with them. Since we need more women in STEM professions, I also buy it for every girl birthday party we are invited to!
summary: A book full of valuable life lessons for girls...and boys!

reviewText: Not enough books like this out there. A bit of awesomely strange art, a bit of history, a bit of the strangely imaginative, and some great inventions. At some point, we will actually respect failure after effort in school, until then, at least in our personal lives, we can celebrate our 1st failures like Rosie discovers.
summary: Awesome to read for all! Great message for all (practical too!)

reviewText: Great book for my daughter.
What a great life story for driven little girls!
My granddaughter loves to make things and really loved this book!  She is six years old.
Very nice book - love it
Good STEM book that can lead to discussions about making things that work and meet a need.
This book is perfect. I love the message, the characters, the illustrations, and everything else. It's one of my favorite books to include in the bedtime rotation.
summary: This book is perfect. I love the message

reviewText: This is a wonderful book about never giving up!
My daughters and son love this book.  Try try and try again is the message.  Failure is an opportunity.  A great lesson with a sweet story and illustrations.
Love this series of creative and funny books
This was a cute story and our 7 year old liked it.

As I said a cute, but too too short. Maybe I did not read the books description close enough. Had I done so may not have ordered it.

Would imagine children would enjoy the booklet.
I thought it was good, not my level but funny,  rhyming, and good for beginner readers. About  A shy girl engineer who tries to help her aunt fly.
Well done book. Cute story, beautiful and fun pictures, meaningful message. I highly recommend!
summary: My fav book of the year!

reviewText: A book every little girl should read.
I purchased this book for my class and had to buy it again for my grandson!

We have all three of these books -- Ada Twist, Rosie Revere and Iggy Peck -- and we love all three. My daughter seems to really respond to emotion displayed by little Rosie, and was drawn to the elder Rose character more than I would have expected. I just love these as role models and interesting exposure to career paths and historical figures.
Read 100 times. I wish there would be more scientist / engineer role models for little girls.
My kids love it! Would strongly recommend this book!

I've said it before and I'll say it again. I applaud books that remind children (and especially young girls) that they can be and do anything they set their heart too. We adults also have to be mindful of our critiques and encouragement
summary: Another great book in this series

reviewText: My two and a half year old really enjoys this book. I don't know how much she understands but it's a great book that creates room for more intelligent and creative conversations.
summary: I don't know how much she understands but it's a great book that creates room for more intelligent and creative ...

reviewText: Rosie is wonderful. She deals with insecurities of being an inventor and overcomes them! The illustrations are lovely. This is a regular read for our smart girls. Science and tough girls is always a win in our house.
summary: Rosie is wonderful. She deals with insecurities of being an inventor ...

reviewText: I love this author and series for my young girls. They love the rhyming stories.
This is a wonderful book for kids of all ages! There's even a little "wink wink" to the adults reading the book, who might recognize that Rosie's great aunt is Rosie the Riveter!
My niece loved this book. I had to read it two times in a row but didn't mind! Great illustrations and story. She is learning about rhyming so she loved the flow of the story!
This is such a lovely story about not giving up and finding confidence in oneself.
Love the tie in to "We Can Do It!" from WWII and love that it inspires us to overcome our fears and embarrassment and follow our dreams.  My kids love it and so do their parents!
summary: Love the tie in to "We Can Do It

reviewText: One of my absolute favorite books!
We love all the books in this series, wonderful illustrations and fantastic message!
Positive and well written this book made me almost cry as I read it to my inquisitive daughter. It rocks
I love this book. Teaches kids to not give up.
I loved it even though it was under my level. It was so cute and adorable,creative,cartoony,and colorful. I would read over and over
Great book!  Bought it for my children and nieces.  Hoping to raise future female engineers.
summary: Great book! Bought it for my children and nieces

reviewText: Great story & great resilience! Love the delicate storytelling with the rhyming thrown in for younger audiences. Thank You for Rosie!
Fun book to read with granddaughter & her brothers - good alternative to playing electronic'games'. Good illustration's. Kids enjoyed it.

I'm trying to raise my daughter to see that girls can be scientists, engineers, fill-in-the-blank-here and normalize those concepts so she can truly pursue her interests, whatever they may be. This book, and Ada Twist, help me do that. The books have wonderful illustrations that lend themselves to games of "I spy ..." and the messages are great. I like that they don't overly focus on "Hey, girls can do things too! Life is hard for women, but they can persevere!" (though those books have their place too). Instead, they simply show a little girl interested in inventing and engineering (or in the case of Ada Twist, how the world works). Love this book and would definitely recommend it for the story and illustrations alone, even if you don't agree with my above parenting goals :).
summary: Great illustrations, story and message, all in one

reviewText:
Engineering involves things breaking to see how to not make them; the series of improving.  First, one fixes the break of absence of a solution, next one fixes the solutions mistakes, then one fixes the efficiency via refinement.

This story discusses discouragement: age and gender are displayed to not be factors.  How to recover from disappointment and why encouragement is such a strong tool.  It's a very encouraging story and is well illustrated.  The method at which it is written makes it an interesting longer read for younger audiences.  Bravo.
summary: Great lessons for children, great writing, great illustration

reviewText: We like when Rosie engineer cheers for herself!  What wonderful illustrations and an uplifting story, perfect to read to my curious daughter.
We LOVE this book in our family!  Our kids are always asking us to read it. I really like how it teaches them to never give up and keep at it even if they fail in the beginning.
This book is perfect. The attention to detail is superb. The message is outstanding. The art is amazing. Worth every penny.
So good to see a book encouraging kiddos to try again from an engineering perspective! I can't wait to read the others in the series to my son!

My nephew has 2 daughters and his wife, thank goodness, will e-mail a list of her choices - because no one knows what they already have.  Her choice of books are those that deal with science, engineering and math.  Recently at a party, I heard her nanny and several younger couples talking about books "that were great for kids" and heard this one mentioned.
summary: I heard her nanny and several younger couples talking about books "that were great for kids" and heard this one mentioned

reviewText: Incredible. Beautiful, well written, empowering. The theme and message is one all children need to hear. There is no learning or success without failure!
My daughter loves this book!  Encourages girls to dream big and never give up!
What a great motivator for young girls to begin their endeavors into the engineering world. My daughter is 5 and she quite liked it.
Teaches kids to keep trying with historical references to the women who built airplanes in World War II. Great story.
Not my favorite of the series but still a good book.
What a great story.  What a great message.  What great rhymes!  Great for girls and boys.  Girls need to hear it most.
Great book. Good morals, great vocabulary and fun rhymes. Also loved iggy peck architect. Nice illustrations and endearing characters. Inspiring careers
Such a cute book! We love reading Rosie! Boys or girls will love it!
Good message for girls especially...
Such a great book about a little girl engineer who is amazing at designing.
Cute book with a great message
Cute book. My kindergartener loves it.
What a fun way to spur on future inventors.  We all have huge imaginations that can change the world. We must start with our young children.
Great addition for the engineering component in our STEM curriculum!
This book is so darling. The message is one that needs to be told in every classroom and home!!! The illustrations are to die for!!! Just buy it! You won't regret it!
This book touches on the fragile confidence that children have. Even innocent teasing can cause sensitive children to give up. Rosie learns that failure is an expected step on the road to success.

In the great style made famous by someone we all love, the story helps to make children learn a principle that could help boost their confidence for the rest of their lives.  I really did enjoy this book!
summary: Tho I had no idea this was a child's book, it was great!

reviewText: Innovative book, enjoyed reading it with 7yr. old daughter
Such beautiful writing. Every girl should read this story and I am so happy that it is out there. Amazing!!

LIKE this book
Good Service
Our family loved it! What a sweet book with a great lesson. We're excited to read more. Kids are 4 and 7.
love these series
Simple rhyming, great illustrations and fantastic message!  A book for ALL 1, 2 and third grade classrooms!  To be red over, and over and over again!

This book is simple, yet well written and has a wonderful message I am happy to share with my daughters over and over: advancements/inventions require experimentation and the "failure" is only truly a failure if you give up on your goal(s).
My children loved this book! As soon as I was done reading it, my son got the Kinects and legos out and spent hours building!

Absolutely love this book!  Great message.  As an engineer, I can help reinforce with the kids that we very rarely ever get anything right the first time.  We have to try and try and try again till we get it right!

Rosie Revere, Engineer is the best children's book I've read to my kids in a couple of months. It's about a little girl who stopped showing people the things she invented after she got laughed at. It is funny in the absurd way that kids love, it has detailed illustrations that can be studied for long periods of time, and it gives great reinforcement to the idea that failure is only a reason to try again, better. My son bonded really hard with the girl in the book because he wants to be an engineer, too.
summary: Best children's book I've read to my kids in a couple of month

reviewText: What an inspiring story for children and adults alike. Clever rhymes and cute pictures make this a fun read for all.

This my my 2 & 1/2 year old daughter's absolute favorite book. She asks for the "Rosie book" almost every night. (It probably doesn't hurt that she looks a bit like the shy little blonde heroine.) My husband is an engineer, so I bought this book for our daughter on a whim, but we all really adore reading it to her. I love the rhymes & poetic flow, humor, and the important life lessons in this lil story. Not to mention, I just LOVE the artwork. I can't wait to buy the other two books in this series, Ada Twist and Iggy Peck. Really, really recommend this book to other budding STEM-curious kiddos.

I saw a couple reviewers saying how they were disappointed at the "negativity" in this book (specifically: Rosie gets laughed at, good-naturedly or not, by adults when she makes her wacky machines, and that makes her withdraw & become shy and she *almost* gives up her dreams).

Uh, okay, but that's REAL LIFE for women in STEM career paths. This is a really gentle, good-natured way of introducing the real world challenges that ALL little girls will face if they choose a male-dominated field. The point is that she learns really vital life lessons from these "failures" and moves forward with her dreams... this is a great book for any kid to read because the message is universal.
I can't enlarge on my kindle for some reason. The print is too small. I can't read it. The pictures are nice.
I thought this book was exactly simple enough, direct enough, fun and inspirational.  It told a tale and taught a lesson without lecturing.  Thank you Rosie Revere.
summary: Wonderful read and inspiration for a child.

reviewText: great book and my toddler loves it!

I love this author and the series. Illustrations are great, but more importantly, I love the story/message. It reads smoothly and rhythmically. There are great opportunities for expanding on some of the vocabulary as well. I read this to my students in class as well as my kids at home. I will be keeping my eyes out for new releases.
summary: I love this author and the series

reviewText: A fun read to my granddaughter, age 6.

We checked this book out of the library and then watched the video of astronaut Kate Rubins read it while on the International Space Station as part of Storytime from Space. The story is quite moving on its own but even more so when Kate ends the video by saying that they have a lot of engineers working for them at the International Space Station and that she hopes someday they have Rosie Revere working for them too!

The story is in rhyme but despite that it does not have a babyish feel. It is easy to relate to Rosie's fear of failure inadvertently created by her family. Her favorite uncle, Zookeeper Fred, laughs at her when she gives him a hat she invented for him to keep snakes off his head. He thinks she is "cute" but she is embarrassed and decides to keep her dreams to herself after that. She does until her great-great-aunt visits and says she has on one "thrill" left on her list that she has not accomplished - to fly. Rosie invents a machine to help her fly. The machine only briefly flies and this relative laughs too. However, Aunt Rose laughs because of joy and happiness and her encouragement allows Rosie to flourish and stop hiding her dreams! Great theme!
summary: Great book about overcoming fear of failure!

reviewText: Excellent

Just a short book about a young girl who is an engineer at heart.

There is nothing wrong with a young girl being an engineer and I think that is the point of the story and I feel like I can identify the point of this book in a couple short sentences so therefore I don't really see why it is a very good book.
Rosie has already become our little prince's favorite

reviewText: Imaginative and fun read for us and our preschoolers!

Our two and a half year old daughter loves this book. The story, the rhymes, the pictures, all of it. The writing is fun and whimsical and rolls of the tongue with the fluidity and frolic of the best of Dr Seuss or Shel Silverstein. The pictures are beautiful, colorful and intricate, and even on pages of denser, longer text, where my little girl's attention might wander, the artwork keeps her entranced. If your own two-year-old is one with a shorter attention span, the book will still take hold of her or his heart a little later. If your kiddo is between 4-6, maybe 7, this book will ROCK.

Oh yeah, and the message. THE MESSAGE! :-) Girl Power, baby. But not overtly. Rosie is NEVER ridiculed because she's a girl. Her challenges have NOTHING whatsoever to do with gender. But she IS a girl. And her new hero and mentor IS an iconic WOMAN. And that's what I wanted. A protagonist with whom my own little girl might identify. Awesome. Super Highly Recommended. Along with Ms Beaty's "Ada Twist, Scientist" - another huge winner.
summary: So very, very pleased I found this for my toddler daughter.

reviewText: So fun to read and a great message!

I was looking for a book to read to my daughters first grade class - the same week they were learning about occupations.  Rosie Revere Engineer exceeded my expectations!  The kids loved the book!  The rhyming kept the story fun and they really enjoyed the illustrations. It's also a wonderful story line about not giving up.  I'm actually not sure how I will top this one on my next turn to read! This is now my 'go to' birthday present for this year.

reviewText: My students love this book. It encourages girls to start thinking about non-traditional careers (e.g., engineering). I love the spoof off of Rosie the Riveter.
great book about perseverance!

This story is kind of a historical fiction about Rosie, the riveter the scarf wearing fictional character with the slogan, we can do it, back during World War II. This slogan was seen across American factories and she brought hope to people in the United States, and women, that we can do this. This is a great story because Rosie, in the story, is an engineer, with lots of ideas and is very creative but she is made fun of by her family members for her creative ideas. Her wild aunt comes along and encourages her to continue to build on her ideas. A quote from the book that I really loved is Life might have its failures, but this was not it. The only true failure can come if you quit. This story teaches growth mindset and that what might seem as a failure can actually be a wonderful learning experience. Maria Dismondy, author of Spaghetti in a Hot Dog Bun: Having the Courage To Be Who You Are

reviewText: Purchased to use in my classroom to add to my Growth Mindset Lessons.  Awesome book. Arrived neatly packaged and in perfect condition.  I would  highly recommend this book along with Andrea Beaty's other books:  Ada Twist, Scientist and Iggy Peck, Architect!!

This story in rhyme just made the NY Times best seller list again! Published in 2013 it is a winner!! The illustrations are unique and the story and rhyme are universal and uplifting to the female who wants to try things that are stereotypically a "man's job". Rosie is reminded that it's not necessarily the end result that is important, but it's the journey!

One of our favorite books! I love the rhymes and the lessons it teaches outright, as well as the subtle ones (like women can be engineers). Our 5 year old boy reaches for this book the most, and these are lessons that should be taught to boys as well as girls. I frequently buy this as a gift for our friends' children. We enjoy the other two books in the series very much as well ("Ada Twist, Scientist" and "Iggy Peck, Architect.")

reviewText: I bought this book to read to my gifted fourth graders. They LOVED it! It's a inspirational story of a gifted young girl with a passion for engineering. She becomes disappointed in what appears to be frequent failures. However, with the help of a famous loved one, she sees she is just beginning her journey to greatness. I highly recommend this book to any parent, teacher, or anyone who loves children! It's appropriate for children between 5 and 105. :-)
summary: They LOVED it! It's a inspirational story of a gifted ...

reviewText: Eh. Why is it Iggy Peck is a natural, but this is all about Rosie's self-doubt? I found this to be the worst of the "girl power" stuff and ended up getting it off our shelf. This book reinforces the insecure aspect of girlhood in the first half of the book, which does NOT need to be enforced. If you want a great book about a woman engineer, try Violet the Pilot. Now there's a kid who knows how to try and try again - but because she's passionate about what she makes. (What she makes is awesome self-built airplanes, in case you're curious: The Tub-bubbler! The Wingamajig! The Hornet!).
summary: Rosie reinforces that women are self-doubters, but boys like Iggy just go for it and build what they want to.  Oh really.

The characters in all AB books are seen throughout her stories, leaving readers anxious for the next book launch. We just can't get enough of these and love the STEM focus. These books are a masterpiece!

reviewText:
I bought this book for my husband who is an engineer, to read to our toddler. He took one look at the book and was very angry, because, he said this is not truly good engineering. Engineering involves planning, design, modelling, prototype, testing. This book involves random experiments, which whilst they make a very cute and fun story, don't actually represent engineering at all. So... Rosie is an inventor, a mad scientist, and definitely a dreamer like her french surname suggests, but not an engineer.
Apart from the obvious flaw in the title, it is a very cute book, I love the illustrations and the story line is sweet and funny too.
summary: Not an engineer! Call it something else!

The message of the book - don't give up after you fail - is a good one though.

reviewText: My kids LOVE this book and it has a great message.  A great read.  A great gift.

Such a cute book! We love reading it at bedtime, although it's a bit long of a story to hold my son's attention at his age (he's currently 16 months). I think he will really love and appreciate it when he's a little older. It's a wonderful story about a little girl who wants to be an engineer but is frustrated when people laugh at her inventions. At first she wants to give up, but with the help of some wise wisdom from a close family member, she is able to overcome those feelings and continue to try, try, try!

reviewText: Great book for a girl or boy. Moral of the story is to keep trying. My daughter loves it.

This book is in constant contention with Iggy Peck Architect as my 20 month old's favorite book.  At this age, she loves books with a good rhyme and I would like to believe a great story.  She also loves pointing out objects and the page where Rosie has all of her supplies out is her favorite.  She can point to everything she knows.  The book is also great because we have been traveling a lot and my daughter loves seeing the planes in the book.

Rosie Revere Engineer is a great story and I love everything that great-great aunt Rose says to her when her plane crashes.  I borrow her words all the time when my daughter gets frustrated with a task.

It took me several weeks to realize that the last page has an introduction to Rosie the Riveter.

For people that have read Iggy Peck Architect or those that have a younger child.  The amount of words on each page of this book is much more than that of Iggy Peck.  Therefore, it does take more patience for my toddler to sit still while I finish reading the page.  However, I do find that this book has so many more items on each page that after going through the book pointing out items, my daughter is able to say the names of items while I read to her.  Sometimes this keeps her attention and sometimes it does not.
summary: Great Great Aunt Rose... I love you

reviewText: So glad to see these kinds of books for children, particularly girls!!

WONDERFUL book for little girls, in particular--and little boys who could learn that not *every* girl wants to be a princess.  This breaks all the gender distinctions that society loves to impose upon our kids.  I recommend this book for any younger kid out there.

It's so hard to find books with a great message for girls.  The market is so saturated with "princess" stuff, it's great to have a book for girls that's about more than looking good or being nice.  Being smart and having drive gets you places in life.  It's a great message, cute pictures and easy to read cadence to hold the attention of both parents and kids.
summary: It's so hard to find books with a great message for girls

reviewText: If you have Iggy Peck in your life, you need Rosie Revere.  A fantastic tale for little girls AND boys too that tells them to persevere and to make mistakes but keep going.  Cute rhymes, great illustrations, and a wonderful moral.  I can't wait to see more books from this pair.
Excellent

This is a great book to inspire girls and boys both but is especially great because of the strong female character.  The message of the book is one that kids need to learn but often don't see concrete examples of: that in order to succeed you are going to fail (and fail, and fail...) before you succeed.

Great no matter the gender of your child, but especially important for little girls. Rosie Revere wants to be an engineer, and she comes up with fabulous inventions. But when her favorite relative laughs at one of her creations, she becomes disheartened, and never wants to invent again. It's only the inspiration of her high-flying aunt that pushes Rosie to give it another try. And further tries, when that try fails.

This book's greater message is about the important of perseverance and trial and error. Very important for young children, just learning how to do pretty much everything. Rosie is very relate-able, and will hopefully be accepted by children of all genders.

Quite suitable for a school storytime, and this would pair well with a unit about building, perhaps accompanied by play with Legos, Knex, or similar.
summary: Not just about being a girl with an interest in STEM. This is great for anyone trying to learn new skills

reviewText: Love the book.  Good model for young, growing girls.
5.5 year old daughter LOVES this story!  It teaches little girls and boys to imagine, create, build and learn and not be afraid to make mistakes.
I gifted this book to a friend's daughter and finally got to read it during a recent visit and it's brilliant.  The story and illustrations are beautiful and exciting.

Great book for children playing off the history of Rosie the Riveter and encouraging girls to design and make things and not give up.

The perfect book for the baby daughter of a feminist.  It even has the little scene where someone laughs with delight, and Rosie is offended because she misinterprets the laughter as being AT her, rather than the happy recognition of her imaginative inventiveness. Dads will like this book, too, though.  It is a nice way to say, don't give up, keep trying, good effort.  I have to admit, it was a teensy tiny bit tedious, but maybe I am old school, let the children be children and quit trying so hard to eddykate, as my little daughter wisely informed me long ago.  Illustrations are worth it.  Very marvelous and the reason I give it 5 stars.
summary: Not my Favorite, But Good for Tots Into Personal Growth ...

reviewText: My 3 year old loves it. Thank you!

What a great story for young girls, AND boys!  Why not teach boys that girls can be engineers too! The story encourages kids to never give up and to build with their imagination.  The publisher's recommendation according to Amazon is 5-7 years old, but I disagree.  I think this book is appropriate as young as 3.  Some of the illustrations provide additional text that really gives context and adds to the story.  It's too much for younger kids, but the older kids will get a lot out of it.  If you're just reading the story without the details in the illustrations, I think this is definitely appropriate for a 3 year old.  The final page of the book also gives some historical information that older kids can appreciate.  I'd skip that for the younger ones as well.
summary: Great book for girls AND boys as young as 3

Not to mention my absolute adoration of Rosie the Riveter. My daughter loves to build right along with her brothers and I encourage her to keep it going, even when it all crashes down or falls apart! This book shores up the idea that failure is assured for quitters. Success is built on the remnants of what didn't work, not what failed. Best Book Ever (This Book Has No Pictures) (Volume 1)

I think it's important to read this book because it teaches young kids the lesson to not stay down, but to keep going until you succeed.

reviewText: We love this book in our house! I like that Rosie experiences difficulty but has a supportive person who encourages her to keep trying and tells her that failure is part of what allows us to succeed in the end. I'm a bit of a softy - I sometimes cannot finish this book without getting tears in my eyes. It really is just such a heartwarming book with a great message for kids.

This is a fabulous, fabulous book.  The story is told in enjoyable rhyme (a lot of times "rhymes" are so forced it's just painful, but not this book), and the story is important for children and adults alike.  The story line explains how Rosie, once a vibrant, vivacious engineer who enjoyed coming up with inventions TO HELP PEOPLE SHE LOVED, has had her confidence shattered by an adult who laughed at the gift she made for him.  In all likelihood, he was probably one of those adults who thinks it is perfectly appropriate and charming to laugh at children (as if just because they are children it means we are laughing with them -- they know better).  So she scraps her dreams and decides never to invent -- or be humiliated-- again.  Along comes her aged aunt (and apparent namesake), who talks to Rosie about the things in life she wishes she had done but never got around to doing.  To help her aged aunt fulfill those last wishes, Rosie pushes past her trepidation and invents a flying machine.  It crashes to the ground.  Rosie is devastated and once again determined to never invent or be embarrassed by her "failures" again.  Thank Goodness for her feisty Aunt Rose, who teaches the big life lesson of this book:  Success is built on failure, and tenacity.  "The machine crashed, yes, but before that, it flew!"  It was a starting point to learn from and continuing improving on.  "The only true failure comes when you quit."  As the mother of a young girl, I also love that the engineer in the story is a girl, but if I had a son, I would still read it to him all the time.  This is just a great book.  And as adults it IS important to remember how crushing our words and reactions can be to the children who look up to us.
summary: Great Book with a Message we ALL need to remember.

reviewText:
Good book but a few criticisms from the engineer reading the book:
1) Why does cheese play a central role in all her inventions?
2) Why do her inventions always have to be made out of garbage? It's not a recycling thing - it's a garbage thing.
Still, a nice edition to your library and just as good of a read for a little boy as a little girl.

I can't believe I haven't writte a review for this book yet. I LOVE IT!  I get goose bumps every time I read it to my daughter.  The pictures are clever and cute and the story is fantastic: Even a failure is still an effort so don't give up.  Love it!

Inspiring and fun. "The only true failure can come if you quit." This book is about the importance of failing but continuing to go on, continuing to try, and I really love that message. Its all about having confidence in yourself and what you want even in the face of ridicule and failure. Its a quick, fun read, but definitely powerful. Plus, its got some GREAT illustrations.

reviewText: What a great story to use in my STEM class.

reviewText: Wonderful book with such a great message. Love this in combination with Iggy Peck Architect. So great!

This book is seriously fantastic. I bought it in the store for my 5.5 year old boy because he's very interested in engineering so I've been trying to find books that show engineers. I admit I didn't look too closely at the story before I bought it, but boy was I blown away when we finally read it. It is clever and cute and thought provoking. Even my son, who normally doesn't want to read anything that's not about superheroes, love the book and has asked to read it repeatedly in just the last 2 days. It opened up natural questions and conversations (many even initiated by my son) about how women have been treated in history and today, what it takes to invent something, what family can and should do to support each other, even what graph paper is and what it's used for! It's not preachy, though, just a great story.

I see some other reviews mention the negative reactions of adults in this book, but I strongly disagree that those are a problem. Kids DO get told all the time that they can't do something, shouldn't do something. They're assessed thousands of times at school, in their grades, standardized testing, etc and often made to feel that they're not measuring up. Why pretend they're never going to face criticism or someone blocking their way? And Rosie overcomes her fear of people's reactions, and she joins her class in their inventing proudly. Even my son immediately picked up on the message. When I asked him at the end of our first read what he thought Rosie learned in the book, he immediately said "To not stop trying just because someone laughs at you." Kids can handle that message! This is a book about perseverance, not an instruction manual on being an engineer.

The illustrations are very charming, and my son has been enjoying spotting all of Rosie's inventions in the book. Honestly this is the best children's book we've read in a long time. It works on many different levels and is just plain enjoyable.
What a perfect book for engaging young girls in Science!

When Rosie Revere was just a tot she vowed to never share her passion for inventing again after her favorite uncle laughed at an invention she created just for him. Late at night, tucked away in the attic she creates gadgets and gizmos out of salvaged garbage that will never see the light of day. Can anything, or anyone, convince Rosie to change her mind and face her fear of failure?

There is a lot to love about Rosie Revere, Engineer, from its whimsical rhyming prose, to its incredibly detailed Art Deco inspired illustrations. But, what truly earns this jewel of a story its wings is its always relevant and hopeful message about embarrassment and failure anxiety. Young children learn to internalize adult opinions early on in their life, and most will be able to relate to Rosie as she secrets away her passion, afraid of rejection, and eventually battles those fears to bring joy to someone she loves.

Rosie Revere is hailed by feminists as an amazing book for girls due to its strong female characters, including the feminist icon Rosie the Riveter, and its STEM (STEAM) subject matter, and they are right to think so. Rosie and her Great Great Aunt Rose are excellent role models for inventive little girls everywhere. It is equally an important book for boys who need to hear as much as girls that it is all right to try and fail, and it is all right to be themselves, even when others don't believe in them.

Parents a teachers cant go wrong adding this colorful and inspirational tale to their kids bookshelves.

Being a young engineer is about tinkering and testing and trying again until you get it, not about building something amazing on the first try. It's a great message for everyone and might encourage parents and kids to read up on Rosie the Riveter.

reviewText:
Rosie Revere, Engineer is a follow-up to Andrea Beatys Iggy Peck, Architect. We see some familiar faces: Lila Green is the teacher again, and even Iggy makes an appearance. One of my favorite things about this book is how Beaty syncs the story with the design not only is Rosie an architect but the all the ilustrations are drawn on engineering grid paper! The colors are vibrant, cheerful and highly detailed with a mix of pen and pencil sketching. The illustrations are charmingly busy ax Rosie tinkers amidst a mess of equipment and tools. It reminds me of Einsteins quote, If a cluttered desk is a sign of a cluttered mind, of what, then, is an empty desk a sign?. Rosies clutter of engineering odds and ends is indeed proof of a little genius.

This is a great picture book about believing in and expressing yourself, pursuing your passion and talents, persisting even if others don't agree or support you, and always trying, even if you have failed before. You can be considered a genius like Rosie If you pick up this story you are one step closer! A fun, fast and smart read to add to your bookshelf. Read more at www.diapers-and-daydreams.com !
summary: One of my favorite things about this book is how Beaty syncs the ...
