reviewText: This book rocks--what an empowering story for little girls who love to build and invent. I loved the Rosie the Riveter connection!

We bought this book for our 4.5 year old daughter. It is a great book. The rhythm and rhyme make it really fun to read and the illustrations are really interesting and warrant lingering over. The overall message of the book is to not give up and that failures/flops are a necessary part of trying something new.

I read a number of reviews that complained about how the uncle laughs at her invention, and I wanted to touch on that. The context for this is that she invents a hat to protect him from snakes. A main feature of this hat is that it sprays spray-cheese all over the place. It's funny. Rosie didn't intend for it to be funny and is hurt by the laughter, but the uncle is quick to say he loves the hat (although Rosie refuses to believe him). My daughter finds this situation very relatable. Kids often find themselves accidentally funny and often the adults around them fail to play it cool. My daughter is particularly sensitive to these situations. The book gave us the opportunity to talk about how sometimes things are funny, even when they aren't meant to be and when people laugh, it's not intended to be mean. It's something inventors often face, I imagine, and knowing that it shouldn't dictate how you proceed is a good thing.

Overall, this book offers a view of a young girl who invents. You see her get discouraged and, later, overcome that discouragement. She learns that failure happens, and is even necessary and good. All that to a lovely rhyme and with great pictures means it is sure to be read over and over again.
I love this book as it encourages girls that they can be anything they want to be.
Love this book
Cried the first time we read it. Really nice story and illustrations.

I think this is the only book we have that emphasizes the importance of making mistakes.  And also encourages little inventors to keep inventing.  The pictures are fun, the text has rhyming.  There is a bit on the last page about the history of Rosie the Riveter.  But what I really want to know is how Rosie is able to make things fly using cheese power.

Cute book, easy read. Some parts were confusing to my 5 year old and it didn't have the best flow of any children's book I've read. Despite that, it is cute and I love the idea of having a female character interested in engineering. I would buy again.
Two  & for year old love this book!
summary: Two & for year old love this book

reviewText: My 6yo son loves this book!  He can be uncertain and hard on himself in the face of setbacks, so I think he connects with Rosie's decision to withdraw in the face of (perceived) criticism or failure.  It has a great message about the value of trying and falling short.  The book doesn't conclude with Rosie successfully building her cheese-copter, but with her openly and proudly watching her projects succeed- and fail!- alongside her peers.
summary: It has a great message about the value of trying and falling short

reviewText: Great book for young girls!!! I highly recommend it!

Our 3-year-old daughter spends 95% percent of her day, building and tinkering with everything from her Lego sets to the trash that we inadvertently drop on the floor.  You can imagine then how happy we were to find this book for our daughter, who was able to fully identify with Rosie, the story's main character ("Hey, mommy! I'm an engineer, like Rosie Revere!!").

The artwork is fabulous.  The story is engaging, very touching, and quite inspiring. It's simply wonderful to be able to read a very well written book that effectively addresses everything from the importance of creative exploration, self-love, and having the courage to never give up on one's ideas and dreams.

Highly recommend this purchase!

(Other great books I highly recommend include: Spork, The Most Magnificent Thing, and What Do You Do With an Idea?)
summary: Engaging, very touching, and quite inspiring...

reviewText:
Andrea Beaty is so creative, she writes children books on professional careers, BRILLIANT!!!  The stories are fun, full of rhymes and silly incidents, just what children love.  My child is 7, he loves for me to read this to him, and he likes to read it too (he is an advanced reader).

Any questions or want photos, please message me:)  Happy shopping!
summary: Author Beaty Does it Again, WINNER

reviewText: Love this and the Iggy Peck books to help inspire kids to keep creating. I especially love giving this one to girls ages 3-5 as gifts. We keep a spare copy in our "gift closet" just in case.
Loved it!
One of the best children books I have ever read!  Great story, well written. A Must buy!!!
Gift recipient and her science-y Dad love this! I also enjoyed the story.
summary: Lovely story, good for bedtime storytime.

reviewText: What a cute little book! It has a great story and teaches kids to learn from their failures and try again. The women empowerment and throw back to history is a nice touch.
summary: Good book for kids, better for girls

reviewText: An amazing and wonderful book to encourage all children to persevere.  I used this for a second grade read aloud and the kids were engaged and excited about the book.  I love it. I cannot say enough good things about it.
summary: An amazing and wonderful book to encourage all children to persevere

reviewText: Awesome book (birthday gift) for a little girl
Total girl power! Inspiring book about the power of curiosity and the natural curiosity and drive we need to encourage in our little girls.
I love this story - teaches persistence and learning self confidence in the face of disappointment!
very creative
What a great book about an inspirational figure in our history.
I bought Igby the architect first before I bought this book. I like Igby much better than Rosie one because it's not focusing on gender, but on his interest and talent.
summary: I like Igby much better than Rosie one because it's not ...

reviewText:
Cute book, but a few problems just fyi:
1.) My 3-year-old is very interested in machines. This book's illustrations include lots of contraptions that Rosie is building, and my son wants to know how they work. He is not satisfied with anything but the most detailed response. Unfortunately, the way things are drawn, the machines can't do the things they're shown doing (like a pull handle, attached in such a way that it can only be pulled, attached to something that would have to be pushed for the machine to work). If your kid is also interested in the actual mechanics of things, I'd skip this one.
2.) It talks about Rosie digging through the trash for supplies to build. My 3 & 2-year-olds have never taken stuff out of the trash. Until now. Grrrrrrrr.
3.) This might seem silly to some, but I heard about this book because it was recommended by the organization A Mighty Girl, and I was a little disappointed that the main character's appearance comes up in the text (just that her hair covers one eye), in a way that's not integral to the story. Why does her hairstyle matter? It has nothing to do with the story. It's lazy writing (stuck in because they needed a rhyme) that reinforces some negative aspects of our culture that I specifically bought this book to try to counteract.

That said, the Rosie the Riveter tie-in is cute and I think it would make a cute gift for someone who's into rockabilly culture. It does have a good message about overcoming fear and failure by trying again.

Update: My 2-year-old who loves dolls keeps asking me to read this book and was finally able to explain to me why. A lot of the contraptions illustrated in the book incorporate parts of dismembered dolls. She's trying to figure out what happened to the dollies, and is pretty upset about it. (yes, commenter CD, my kids are sheltered, it's an important part of my job as their parent at this stage in life)
summary: Drawings not mechanically accurate, if you care

reviewText:
This book tries not to be sexist but ends up being really, really sexist, especially when compared with its slightly less sexist companion book, Iggy Peck, Architect.  Iggy Peck's story begins with, "Iggy Peck is an architect and has been since he was two," and then it goes on to describe his ingenious toddler creativity, which becomes thwarted in elementary school by his architecture-hating teacher, a neurotic woman who's traumatized by having gotten lost in the Empire State Building as a child.  Iggy saves her life, heals her neurosis, and is not only a hero but then takes on the role of lecturing his class each week on architecture, supplanting his neurotic teacher.  Rosie Revere, by contrast, is hampered by insecurity and easily daunted by others' criticism.  Her creations are acknowledged failures, and she's deemed adequately successful if she can just keep trying despite failure (go, Rosie!).  Her great aunt, the iconic Rosie the Riveter, is an obese crone who cheers on young Rosie's failures--failures Rosie constructs in secret to avoid criticism.  In the end, unlike Iggy, an acknowledged authority on architecture and Rosie's classmate, wallflower Rosie is just happy not to be crushed by her neuroses, even if she is still pretty much a failure and invisible to everyone except her absurdly fat aunt.

Edifying, really.
summary: Maybe people who write books for girls should start by not hating women and girls.

reviewText: Very nice story about not letting your insecurities hold you back! Never quit. Great book.
My 6 year old enjoys this book.  A lot of reading, so younger than 6 it might be a little too detailed for their attention span.  Great photos.  I would buy it again.
summary: Great photos. I would buy it again

reviewText: thanks

I bought this for my daughter's 5th birthday along with some tinker toys. She was really into inventing things and developed this pulley system in the closet. After reading some reviews, I thought this would be perfect to encourage her. Both my 3 and 5 year old love this book. It has a really nice message to encourage kids not to give up and show that failure can happen but you don't give up. My girls request this one every night.

i really really wanted to love this book.  sadly, rosie constantly doubts herself and has no confidence.  not the story i want to tell my daughter.  she won't speak out in school.  i want a better role model please.  all these books about boy characters have none of this self doubt.  sad.
summary: this could've been a great book.

reviewText: I absolutely love this book!
Bought this book for my 4 year old daughter and she LOVED it...as did my 6 year old son! Super awesome book!!!
summary: ... book for my 4 year old daughter and she LOVED it.

reviewText: This is my GO TO purchase for little girls! It has vibrant artsy illustrations, a super cute message, just the perfect package. I do think it there is an intrinsic 'value' to a book Mothers and Fathers enjoy reading right along with kiddos!

love this book. encouraging story of how Rosie first got discouraged because she was laughed at and then learned that the failures are the important steps to success.  let's teach our daughters to build and our sons to cook and nurture and we'll have a better-- or at least more balanced-- world. my six year old daughter loves the book.
summary: excellent inspiration for aspiring young female builders

reviewText: There's a bit of repetition in the rhyming, but this is my 5-year-old daughter's absolute favorite book. I read it to her every single day and she has it pretty well memorized. It has a good message of not giving up, and learning from mistakes. Highly recommended. My daughter now always wants to collect stuff to make inventions from.
Neat book. Good for any little girl. My four-year-old requests it.
summary: Parents of girls should buy this.

reviewText: I bought this after reading the reviews.  I was a little cautious because the negative reviews implied a number of lessons I did not necessarily want to provide my granddaughter.  Well, some of those reviewers either received a completely different book, or have some grudge against real life and positive messages.  The book is about a young, shy girl who makes her own gadgets out of junked items.  Yes, an Uncle laughs at her spray cheese can hat device to keep snakes away.  And, yes the uncle is a zoo keeper.  And, the uncle's laughter hurts her feelings and causes her to stop working on her inventions for a while.  But, the story is about bouncing back from disappointments and failures, not about a mythical perfect world where all Uncles are perfect and there are no zoos, and helicoptering parents are ever present to protect you.  So, an Aunt also laughs at Rosie's flying machine invention failure. And, Rosie is disappointed and decides to stop inventing. But, the Aunt's laughter is based on amazement, or enthusiasm, or perhaps just on seeing a spinning cheese spraying contraption try to fly.  The Aunt embraces Rosie and her failed machine and teaches her that failure is part of the process of succeeding.  So, this is good book that promotes a good lesson.  (I have to admit there seems to be a strong canned spray cheese component since that shows up in two "inventions".  But, perhaps it is better to use that supposed food product as a flying/snake repelling device than as food.)
summary: Good for Rosie (and other girls and boys)

reviewText: Super cute story and creative, fun illustrations. My 5 year old and I always laugh at her contraptions that send cheese spray flinging everywhere. I love the Rosie the Riveter reference and cameo and a tear still comes to my eye when Rosie Revere realizes that it's okay if your first try isn't perfect - and that we should probably celebrate it : ) One of my favorite books in my daughters' collection. From a reader, a reading teacher, a mom, a computer nerd and a lover of picture books, this is a great one for your girls!
summary: A must have for a little girls' library

reviewText: wish was bait more like  the other book missing something but not a bad book
summary: wish was bait more like the other book missing something but not a bad

reviewText: Read this book over 10 times. Still love it. My 2 year old adores Rosie.
summary: Still love it. My 2 year old adores Rosie

reviewText: We bought other Andrea Beatty books at the same time, and of cousre love them all.  My daugher even noticed that Rosie in this book is pictured in the Iggy Peck Architect book also - nice to see that little internal cohesiveness with the characters and the story and images are wonderful.
summary: Andrea Beaty's books are amazing!  My 9-year old love these!

reviewText: It's a new favorite in the house for my newly 5 y.o. niece. It's a great and empowering story that reaffirms not only can girls be engineers and build wonderful and imaginative inventions, but more importantly, for either a girl or a boy, it places the importance on trying, failing, and trying again. It's the process that's lauded. It's the process that eventually leads to what one hopes the final product will be. The story is told in rhyme and is super fun to read out loud. Plus, Rosie's inventions are fun to discuss (i.e. helium pants!!). This book reminds me of a quote I once read to the effect of: doubt kills more dreams than failure ever will. Highly recommend this book for both girls and boys.
summary: Empowering and Reaffirming for girls and even boys

reviewText: This was for a preschool teacher in Geneva  Switzerland and the children loved it!
summary: ... a preschool teacher in Geneva Switzerland and the children loved it!

reviewText: We need more books that encourage girls to pursue S.T.E.M careers. Our own daughter is very similar to the main character, Rosie, so it was a big hit! It teaches girls not to give up and that they can make great things with a little engineering and creativity!
summary: It teaches girls not to give up and that they can make great things with a little engineering and creativity

reviewText: An excellent story for encouraging all children, especially girls, to pursue engineering. It also addresses the concept that when things don't work the first time, you keep on trying until you get it right.
Clever book!
beautiful layout, illustration, and story. a gift for all ages. i look forward to reading this with my daughter when she gets past the book-nibbling stage. :)
My 4 yr old really enjoyed this one.
This is a great story for little girls everywhere, empowers them to think outside the box.

I shared this story with two 2nd grade classrooms.  It's a perfect story to teach that it's okay to fail.  We can't get things done right the first time always, but we shouldn't give up.  Try and try again!  Both boys and girls enjoyed this story!  (Be sure to look up poster pictures of Rosie the Riveter from WWII to share with the children when you read this.  Adds a new interest to it.)

My granddaughter loves this book.  She has me reading it over and over, and tries to emulate the main character.  As a retired engineer, I am hoping it inspires her to pursue a career in science or engineering.
summary: My granddaughter loves this book. She has me reading ...

reviewText: Very amusing and companion to Iggy Peck.

my almost-four-year-old loves this book, but maybe not as much as her momma.  she has it memorized in its entirety.  what a great message it shares with children and i love rosie revered tied back to rosie the riveter and how she is positioned as an engineer.
love this girl!
My Granddaughter loved this book and learned some valuable lessons from it. An excellent story with a great message.
summary: An excellent story with a great message for young readers

reviewText: Great premise but weak and forced rhyme.

We love this book!  I purchased this book the other day and instantly fell in love with the story!  My 5-year-old daughter likes it, too, especially the illustrations.  I am thrilled to have a non-princess book for my girl!!
Nice
Great book. Kept the girls riveted. Good balance of text and pictures for 4 and 5 year old girls. They got the message, a flop is not a fail but a challenge to keep going.
A great book for those looking for an alternative to the stereotypical princess books for girls. Well-written and illustrated.  I wish all little girls could hear this message.
summary: A great book for those looking for an alternative to the ...

reviewText: The story has a great message both for adults (don't laugh at your kid's creations) and for kids (don't quit). I love the story, although rhyme at times is a bit forced. The illustrations ar humorous, but I find they could have chosen a different illustrator to enhance the story.
summary: The story has a great message both for adults (don't laugh at your kid's ...

reviewText: This was not as good as I'd hoped it would be.

I teared up when I read this as THIS is what we want to teach our daughter, fail fast and move on.  Weve read so much about how to raise a child with aptitude for math and science and the #1 thing is its not getting the right answer, its the WORK, its the thought process, the failure that you need to celebrate.  This book is an amazing story, clever and hits the nail on the head for all women in science.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
summary: This book is an amazing story, clever and hits the nail on the ...

reviewText: Both my 9yr and 12yr old daughters love this book
I purchased this book as a gift for my 3 year old niece. She adores the story of a smart, inventive girl who solves problems ingeniously.
my 3 year old loves this book. It encourages creativity and inventiveness. I enjoyed reading it as well. highly recommend.

Rosie Revere, with her hair tucked into a red polka dot kerchief, has a secret. In her spare time, she's constantly on the look out for discarded trash that she can use in her latest invention. She builds delightful things like snake repelling hats and helium pants (my personal favorite), but she mistakes delighted laughter for contempt.

When her great-great-aunt Rose (also in a polka dot kerchief) comes to visit, Rosie is inspired by their common love machines and adventures (hint: great-great-Aunt Rose used to be a riveter, during the war). With the following Seussian words from great-great-Aunt Rose, Rosie learns that every apparent failure is just an opportunity to learn something new and try a different approach.

Life might have its failures, but this was not it.
The only true failure can come if you quit.
By the end of the book, Rosie's entire class has become a community of makers, working and learning together, building great gizmos, gadgets, and doohickeys.

Andrea Beaty's lyrical poetry is reminiscent of Dr. Seuss and is an absolute delight to read. David Roberts fantastically expressive illustrations make this a very visually pleasing book, with plenty of laughs. Enjoy!

This review and more like it available on my blog, Bibliopapa.

I just got this book for my kids and so far I choke up every time I read it - I LOVE the encouragement for the little girl to try big things, make mistakes, and keep trying!

It's written in a rhyming, fun to read style and the pictures are whimsical and wonderful. Rosie makes a cheese-copter!

First and most important of all - my two daughters 3 and 5 LOVE this book - the illustrations are so detailed in they find new things after multiple readings, there is good humor in the text and the pictures, and the sing song like text is deeply appealing - they now "sing along".  Less important - but noteworthy - I love this book as it wraps in a series of wonderful messages - encouraging girls in engineering, learning not to quit, realizing that old relatives have great stories to tell, and even grabbing their interested in world war 2 history.  I do want to note as a warning though - that after reading it to the girls no fewer than five times a day for a month (not an exaggeration...) - I cannot get the damn poem out of my head, it like a song stuck there...

Both this book and Iggy Peck, Architect are children's picture books at their best and they both have the added bonus of being enjoyable to the parents too!
summary: Great Book, Great Message (and ear worm warning....)

reviewText:
My four year old got this as an early present for her 5th birthday because she wants to be an engineer when she grows up. Rosie's inventions are kind of silly and I wish she had some variety in her building materials (two cheese machines? Kind of weird too since my daughter does not like and refuses to eat cheese for moral reasons. It's hard to spin canned cheese into something else. Uh... carrot toothpaste?) But I really appreciate the moral of not quitting. The kid is entering a stage where she wants to throw up her hands and quit when something frustrates her so this moral couldn't come at a better time.

I also really like the plot point concerning how her uncle laughed at her invention and made her feel insecure. It sucks and all, but people in this world will put you down and you have to learn to rise above it. Especially for a young girl hoping to grow up and be an engineer, there will be lots of people that stand in my daughter's way and put her or her abilities down, just like what happened to Rosie. I'd love if we lived in a world that openly welcomed and encouraged girls to STEM fields, but until we do, books like Rosie Revere help approach the idea of dealing with people putting your dreams down in a kid appropriate way that leaves a lot of room for dialogue about feelings and potential solutions.

Total panic about Rosie's trash collection though!  Every time we read it, I look at my kid and tell her "This is just pretend! Please do not REALLY start storing collections of trash in your room!" Just knowing my kid, she would TOTALLY do that.

My partner and I ordered this book for our two young granddaughters and arranged to return it the minute we had finished reading it. Rosie "invents" a hot dog dispenser and cheddar cheese whiz, her emotionally abusive uncle is a zookeeper and her aunt a stereotypically obese older woman. So in this very short book, the author manages to embrace and promote animal exploitation and sizeism. That would not fly in our vegan family in which we promote kindness to all animals, human and nonhuman. Ms. Beatty needs to realize that many families teach their children compassion and that animals are not ours to eat, use or wear.

Arrived on time and was exactly as advertised.  Looking forward to sharing with my
grandaughter who is showing a remarkable curiousity about how things work and
assembling forts and camps on her own, much as we did when we were young.
Exciting to see curiousity in a young person.
My 5 year old loves this book and so does her mother! I wish they had something like this when I was growing up.

When I find a smart, funny and amusing book that showcases a crackerjack girl like Rosie, I just cant help myself! Using everyday household objects, Rosie creates wacky inventions, including a pair of helium pants and a hot dog dispenser.

Rosie absolutely loves to invent, but when she fails and is laughed at, she throws in the towel. But her Great-Great-Aunt Rose (akin to Rosie the Riveter) teaches her only through trial and error can she truly succeed.

With such a wonderful message about not giving up, Rosies class gets in on the inventing fun. When kids can discouraged so easily, this book lets them know its okay to fail but its not okay to give up.

My granddaughter is SUPER smart and I want to encourage her to keep being as clever as she is - as she gets older and has the need to be all beautiful and stuff! This book is so cute and creative and rhymes and there are characters from the Iggy Peck book in this illustrations that I totally missed but my granddaughter pointed out to me. I just love how this brings out the baby genius in her!
my children love this book.  it is fun to read and they laugh and are very engaged.  my 5 year old asks for it almost every day.

What a great book for encouraging all the little girl designers and dreamers!  That said, when I bought this book for my kindergarten triplets, it was Jack who kept saying, "Read it again."

I especially loved the freedom Rosie's "oldest relative"--who happened to be THE Rosie the Riveter!--gave this youngest Rosie.

This book is awesome. All three of my kids love it. Rosie is a kid builder and engineer who gets sad and doesn't want to design gadgets and machines anymore when she fails a couple of times. Then her aunt teaches her a great lesson, that failure is simply a part of science and engineering, and how we move forward. It's just another part of the process.

Wonderful book! I just read this to my class yesterday. Rosie is a shy girl who invents amazing things but she is very secretive about her inventions because an uncle once laughed at one of them. When her aunt shows up, however, she convinces Rosie that failure is simply another way to view success.....if it "sort of works" then you are on the right track! This was a great book for my kids because we've been talking a lot about perseverance and not giving up. Also, I love that the main character is a girl. My kids loved the book.

An important quality of a child's book is that it is enjoyable for an adult to read aloud many times. This book accomplishes that with good story writing. It leaves me wanting more depth sometimes, but is indeed encouraging to young girls' creativity. As others have mentioned, it is also nice that the book conveys that it is normal to feel upset about failing; yet also important to keep moving forward.
summary: Fun to read aloud, inspiring and encouraging

reviewText: We are die-hard "Iggy Peck, Architect" lovers and have been for years. My husband and I enjoy reading Iggy, even repeatedly in the same day or for days at a time. I can't say that about many books out there. We expected the same from "Rosie Revere, Engineer," but have been disappointed. We just checked it out from the library and both independently expressed our lack of connection or enjoyment of this book compared to Iggy. Granted, Beaty is a good author and the writing is good, the message is good, illustrations are good. But, it feels incomplete. The last page feels like it isn't the end of the story (I keep flipping the page and being surprised there isn't more), and there is a lack of explanation of the uncle's reaction to Rosie's first invention (i.e. did he really think she was ridiculous and try to humiliate her, as she thinks, or was it really a misunderstanding as with Great Great Aunt Rose?). The book is fine, but not awesomely amazing like Iggy Peck. We won't own this one or give it as gifts. I would like to see if Beaty plans to develop each of the 17 kids in the class or not, as that would be fun (and a lot of work).
summary: Not nearly as good as Iggy Peck, Architect

reviewText: My 4 year old daughter is in love with this book.  I'm in love with how it has inspired her to get creating and "invent" her own things.  She can look at the pictures forever (in 4 year old time) picking out all the fun things that make up Rosie's inventions.  A great book to inspire young minds to break out of their comfort zone and "try try again".  You never know what they may come up with.

If you have a daughter or granddaughter that likes to invent things, this book is for her.  My granddaughter reads this every night - or rather has her mom read it to her, as she is only 5.  She has always liked making things, but now she has an "engineering notebook" where she draws out her plans.  She has devised traps to catch a bird, catch a ghost, learn to fly, and many other interesting concepts.  I love the fact that this book shows that an activity does not have to work the first time around, that one can plan and fail, learn from that and adapt the plans.  I highly recommend this book.

The story line is fun, interesting and informative.  Rosie learns that her failures are just bumps on the road to success.  obviously written to get girls interested in engineering.  But has a message for all kids who like to try out their inventions.
summary: Good introductory book, but geared heavily toward girls

reviewText: I cannot say enough good things about this book. It's fun to read, the pictures are awesome, and the story is fantastic. I actually tear up almost every time we read it. SO GOOD.

From the amazing details on the cover art (the jacket is great but when I removed it for safekeeping from the not-so gentle hands I found even better surprise!) to the hilarious faces on the characters this book is delightful and engaging! A must have for your little one's library!
summary: Every little one needs to read about Rosie.

reviewText:
This is such a perfect book in so many ways. The verse is nicely written with a great choice of words and a well put together prose. The storyline is fun with a great take on engineering. The main character is likable - you really get in to Rosie and root for her.
My kids quickly identified Iggy Peck in the classroom and we are all hoping books are written for each child in this fabulous 2nd grade classroom!
I think the grade level for kids that would like this book stretches past 2nd grade and covers all of elementary school.
I liked it a lot because I like too make stuff too when I was younger and my friend thought my stuff was funny
Fun and helpful for letting young girls know being curious about engineering feats is also women's work!  Helps with reading skills too.
my 5 granddaughters loved the smart, spunky heroine; my children tell me the that the book has reached favorite status.
My 5 yr old loved it!  Great illustrations and a creative, encouraging storyline.  I especially appreciated the history lesson worked into the story

The illustrations are gorgeous; on par with Iggy Peck. And a little girl engineer as a protagonist is wonderful!!! What I didn't like about the book is that, firstly, Rosie's nearest and dearest laugh at her inventions and then secondly don't intervene when they notice that she has completely shut down her engineering as a result of their mockery. It wraps up well enough with Rosie using her skills again and the poem is well done and entertaining. The fact that the illustrations show Iggy and Miss Lila Greer, etc. as a continuation of the Iggy Peck book was a win with my kids too. They loved to find the details that matched the first book.
summary: A great story about believing in yourself with some harsh tones

reviewText: I read this book to my four year old daughter, and we both loved it. She loved the creative way that Rosie uses all kinds of materials to build inventions as well as the drawings. I loved the nod to Rosie the Riveter and the empowering message for young girls. I wish there were more books with this kind of STEM messaging in them, especially with a female lead. FYI, we also love Iggy Peck, Architect. I think kids of all ages could appreciate it, and adults for that matter. I loved it as much as my kid did!
This book was outstanding, and the young lady who received it was thrilled.  She is an aspiring ice skater and this book gave her so much confidence.
Got this for 5-yr-old granddaughter who already had the Iggy Peck Architect book.  I like the basic tenets put forth of thinking outside the box and persevernce.  Plus, the illustrations are great.
I am a mom and an engineer.  A picture book that explains the essence of engineer and is fun.  We like the other book on architecture as well.  Highly recommend this book.
summary: My 6year old girl loves it and I do to as a mechanical and system engineer

reviewText: Rosie is a creative little lady who loves to build interesting creations but she gets discouraged along the way. However, with encouragement from her Aunt Rose, she learns to try again and learns that even when you don't succeed, you should persevere and celebrate the small successes along the way. Love this story and the message for girls (and boys). Particularly love that this book is about a girl and her aunt without the girly fluff (glitter, pink, etc.) that so many modern toys and books resort to and that so many modern girls don't relate to!
This story is so cute, I love that it rhymes and the message behind. it! I purchased it for my young niece and she loves it!

As a female engineer, I've been looking for great stories for my literary and engineering/science loving son. This rhyming story hit the spot with a cute girl who enjoys building things for others. She's not always successful with her inventions, which is a great lesson any engineer should learn. Her Great Aunt Rose (modeled to be Rosie the Riveter) comes into the story and gives Rosie words of encouragement to continue, which they do together. After reading the book, my son wanted to create his own inventions like Rosie.
summary: Cute story with a great message and a twist of history

reviewText: I have Iggy Peck Architect by this crew and it is one of my favorite books to read to my twin boys. Rosie continues on with this tradition and makes it even more fun. A great rhyming and inspirational kids book with a shout out to Rosie the Riveter and our great history. Highly recommended for anyone with kids.

I purchased this for one of my nieces.  I love books that expose kids to creativity, engineering, and science.  This book in particular is great as it showcases a young girl as an inventor and engineer.  Resilience, perseverance and courage are all themes highlighted here and my niece (and nephews) love it.  The story is cute, the pictures are great and the message is even better.
WE loved it - Iggy and Rosie are awesome!  They're really original and we love the illustrations.  The copies were in great condition!
summary: So fun - as good as the first

reviewText: For the young person reading Rosie Revere the Engineer, it's a visual delight, yet with a message.  Perseverance, learning from prior mistakes, empowerment of girls to do non-traditional, non-girlie things is an added asset.  This book is filled with positive messages and wisdom.  Highly recommend this book!
summary: This is an inspirational book!  Highest recommendation!

reviewText:
I love this book. Let me repeat. I love this book and I loathe picture books.

This is a book about the glory of failures, the importance of trying, and the necessity of believing in yourself. Rosie revels in inventing, building, and engineering, there's not a princess in sight. The writing has the lilt and flow of a Dr. Seuss book. The illustrations are beautifully done and capture the spirit of the characters perfectly.

Rosie is a great book for girls probably from 2-6, The Girl loves it and we've already had to read it several times a day since she received it on Christmas Eve. Emotions of frustration of failure are turned to the triumph of failure in a way that children can relate to. There's enough silliness in the book (all of the inventions seem to involve cheese) to appeal to children, but not enough to make it intolerable to humbug adults like me.

Great-great Aunt Rose teaches Rosie a fine lesson when her cheese-copter crashes after hovering for only a few moments.

""Your brilliant first flop was a raging success!
Come on, let's get busy and on to the next!"
She handed a notebook to Rosie Revere,
who smiled at her aunt as it all became clear.
Life might have failures, but this was not it.
The only true failure can come if you quit."

Great message for all children, but especially girls. It's easy to read with high enthusiasm and excitement. I've not read the original Iggy Peck, Architect but I may have to pick it up next time Little Miss Princess starts to rake on my nerves.

Definitely, definitely check it out.

What a great book!  I'm an engineer and got this for my 6yo niece.  She loved it, and so did her mother.  I gave it along with a set of Goldie Blox.  This book isn't just about a girl who likes to invent things - Rosie also learns great lessons about perseverance and failure from a special guest.
I like the look of this book, the pages are easy to read.  A nice gift for a five year girl.

love the book.  gave it to my grand-neice.  She is 4.  She has been getting the princess treatment and I want her to know she has a brain too.  This is a good story and doesn't come across as pushy or women's lib, just a nice book about a girl with a brain.
summary: for little girls who are more than just a princess

reviewText: giving it to a 5 yr old with a  Sea World Barbie veterinarian doll.  mixed messages to be sure, but I'm trying.  as an auntie I appreciate that it's not a 'brand' or character like so many toys these days.  seems like if there wasn't a Pixar movie, there is no doll or book or Lego set.... sigh.  Refreshing story and illustrations - and I hope my little niece 'gets it'.
The text and illustrations are both stunning. It's fun to read (as the adult reading it) and our daughter loves it. The positive message is wonderful without being heavy handed.

Another favorite in our house - kids know more about Rosie Revere and Iggy Peck than other Disney cartoons and parents loved that!

It takes a good writing to capture the essence of being an engineer and to include one of the most important virtue (for all profession) - determination and not giving up despite several failed attempts.

Highly recommended!

My little 5 year old girl loved this! It was simply transformative. She SAW through this media channel (books) that girls are smart enough to be Engineers, a word she typically hears associated with her brother or male cousins. Since this book she has been on a building / tinkering phase which I am happy to encourage. Little girls are lost too young to the S.T.E.M. fields because of overwhelming cultural cues and media messages that say little girls are cute, do ballet and cheer, maybe play soccer while the boys play with legos, remote control cars and become engineers. It does not have to be this way. Please join me in lobbying this author to create a series with this character.
summary: Yes, Girls can be Engineers! A new enduring character in need of a Series!

reviewText:
This is my new favorite book!  My four year old daughter loves it as well, thank goodness, even though it's a bit beyond her level.  Within a few days of getting this book she started drawing labeled diagrams of things she could build - I would love it if she kept that up!  I wish there were more girl-empowerment books like this - the kind that boys can enjoy just as much as girls because they are just good stories, and that completely ignore stereotypical gender roles rather than actively trying to refute them (no one needs to tell my daughter "girls can do anything" at this point in her life, because the idea that there are any limits based on gender has never even crossed her mind).

As a strange aside, I'm currently reading the adult self-help book "Mindset", and this book has basically the same message.  A great lesson for children and adults.

What a great story! We love reading it as much as our 2 year old daughter. Such a good lesson for all kids, but especially young girls, and I love that it encourages interest in science and math. It has become a staple in my gift-giving closet!
summary: Great story with a good moral!

reviewText: Both kids love it.  Was a gift for my daughter but my son loves reading it too!  Creative book that inspires.

The 6 yo (boy) and 4 yo (girl) both loved Iggy Peck, Architect, and were delighted to get this book.  The book is well written and the illustrations are just beautiful.  It is a smart book and I highly recommend it.
summary: Another great book from Andrea Beaty

reviewText: I love this book. The drawings are really beautiful and the story is inspirational for boys and girls alike. After buying this, I purchased others from this author. My son is almost 4 and he really enjoys the story.

Love, love, love this book with all of my heart. As a mom of 3 daughters (and one son), I am always on the lookout for books with strong female characters. This book has an amazing message, beautiful illustrations, encourages creativity, AND top of it all- girl engineer.awesome. My girls love it and it is a new favorite. It will be good to read to my little boy too- good message for all of us about not giving up and being proud of who we are and what we do. I have read it aloud 3 times in 3 days and I get chills each time. This would be a great addition to any library, home or otherwise.
summary: BUY this book! You will not be sorry!

reviewText: My little one was given this book as a gift for her 2nd birthday and she loves it. She asks to read it daily (sometimes multiple times per day). As an engineer myself, I love the message about how failure is not bad - you have to fail to eventually succeed. Rosie in this book is a little girl who loves tinkering and building stuff, and I love how my little one is into that idea too.

I really loved Iggy Peck, Architect. So when a teacher alerted me a second book was coming out about a GIRL I was ecstatic. Rosie Revere has a creative mind and has lots of big ideas. But when she tries to build something and it turns out to be a disaster - she doubts herself and decides she's a failure. Luckily her aunt teaches her a very important lesson - The only true failure can come if you quit. You will also see Iggy Peck in Rosie's classroom.

This year my school is really focusing on career education. Nice to have this on my shelf to help encourage children to follow a path towards college or whatever they aspire to be.
summary: Review from Books That Heal Kids

reviewText:
"Alone in her attic, the moon high above,
dear Rosie made gadgets and gizmos she loved.
And when she grew sleepy, she hid her machines
far under the bed, where they'd never be seen."

Rosie Revere is a girl with a dream. She wants to be a great engineer, but ever since her favorite uncle laughed at her invention, she's kept her creations for her eyes only. Then her oldest relative, great-great-aunt Rose (Rosie the Riveter) comes to visit and shares her unfulfilled dream--to fly. So Rosie decides to build a flying machine. Her first try is a glorious flop, but Rosie gains a little perspective and learns that trying is more important than instant success.

I enjoyed the historical link of having Rosie the Riveter in the story, though I find it hard to believe that the real Rosie the Riveter could have gone so long wanting but unable to fly. Certainly airplanes have been around long enough that a cheese-copter would be unnecessary. I also had to wonder about Rosie's insistence on cheese-powered creations.

While all the illustrations are lively and colorful, my favorites show designs sketched onto the familiar engineering grid paper--it's a taste of "real" engineering and history. I love the upbeat Seussian rhythm and rhyme. This is a fun story with a great message about learning from failure that applies to everyone--not just aspiring engineers.

Randy-Lynne Wach
Review for Sacramento Book Review
I have twins so I bought this book for my daughter and Iggy Peck for my son. Both books are simply amazing and I want to buy everything Andrea Beaty writes!

My granddaughters love these books and this one is especially well written and full of solid, useful information that the girl can absorb and think about as she reads it.  I'm so glad such products are out there.

My coming-of-age experience featured a horrid 5th grade movie followed by an awkward Q & A with the school nurse. Right about the time I was being scared to death about growing a woman-sized body, the Boston Women's Health Book Collective came out with their groundbreaking work, Our Bodies, Ourselves, which presented women's health and sexuality from a woman's perspective. That loud and proud feminist theme is reflected in these mainstream body books which explain the dramatic changes that happen during puberty from a girl-sized perspective. Each of the 33 chapters is no more than 2 pages long on facing sides and illustrated in an array of colors with short paragraph-style descriptions. This Body Book for Older Girls gives your child access to information about their bodies in a way that is encouraging and positive. There's no baby talk in these books: pubic hair and vagina, breasts and nipples and periods and tampons are fully explained and illustrated. For a young girl, this grownup approach - albeit in cartoon-style graphics - can turn a bewildering life change into an empowering adventure. If you have a pubescent girl in your home, I highly recommend this book. Your child can use this resource as an opening for further discussions with you about the care and keeping of her body beautiful.
I responded these books to every mom
summary: Every girl should have it on her shelf

Why make them feel it is something they must get rid of or be ashamed of?  Also I wish they would show the option of menstrual cups and not just tampons and pads. Come on! I assumed it would get into other topics that come up as girls are growing up, but it did just stay straight to the point about caring for the body.  which is what book 1 had already done.  that said, maybe it could be good for some girls who need more information, or if you have a 5 year spread between reading book 1 and book 2.

all of that said, I do appreciate their efforts in providing information to girls about care, so I support their mission in general.

The one thing I did not like as much was as a medical professional I hoped that it would be more anatomical in information but we have other books for that. I ordered this book for my 10 year old daughter for her iPad. I noticed when I checked out books from the library, she did not want to look at them, mostly because she worried that someone would see them. However, downloading it to her iPad and hiding it in a folder, she feels much more comfortable looking through it. We read through a large portion of it together and it helped to clear up a lot of her questions. I think, for the most part, that this book is very thorough in explaining all of the many changes that girls experience during puberty. However, there is one thing that continues to irk me a bit. The diagram of the female genitals does not label the clitoris. Why? Having a daughter and also having friends with daughters, I have found that often times a girl's first question about her genitals is "What's this bump?" I can understand the fact that this book does not delve into sex and reproduction but the clitoris is a part of the body that the girls see and it should be, at the very least, labeled. Overall, excellent book.
summary: Very informative but should label all parts of genitalia.

reviewText: I borrowed this and its predecessor as a set expecting to be humored by the stereotypical bright girl colors, nauseating cutesy illustrations, dumbed explanations, and invitational commands about how to behave but I was pleasantly surprised - like its predecessor, it continues its informal yet very informative narrative in the personal matters that every growing girl needs to know about herself. The Care and Keeping of You 2 is a sequel aimed at girls over 10-years-old and continues its users manual approach of educating them about their minds and bodies, this time delving just a bit deeper in the unique female attributes and covering some of the more intimate matters such using feminine hygiene products, wearing underwear, eating disorders, the female psyche in relation to friends and family, and bad influences like peer pressure. Using the same simple and declarative language of the first book, it does away with any technical explanations in favor of simple declarative sentences yet with enough authority that the intended audience will be able to accept and make use of the information the first time they read it. Expectedly, its rich illustrations are also provocative - there is a sequence of girl performing breast exam, an abridged depiction of the female reproductive system, and a sequence on the proper insertion of a tampon. I do have one almost trivial problem with some the illustrations. In the Chapter "The Anatomy of You", the author emphasizes the anatomically correct labeling to the female reproductive organs yet does not use "vulva" at all. Inexplicably, parts like the clitoris or hymen are also not mentioned, despite the clitoris being depicted. Far be it for me to tell another author write about or what girls should know, but I cannot think of any good reason why they were not mentioned. In general, if you or your young daughter enjoyed the first book, you will like this one. As a matter of fact, you can enjoy this book without ever reading the first book. The book designates itself for girls ten and up or going through puberty, but I suppose great conversation starter as well when trying to gauge the developmental knowledge of the young girls in your family without going on tangents like talking about where babies come from or the anatomical differences between girls and boys. For something like that, there is this one incredible book that goes deeper to explain female development, but the content and depth is more for the middle school/high school level girl. You might not want to buy it right now, but is nice to know that books like it exist.
summary: A concise and genuine guide into womanhood
