This was a very good book for young girls. Wish I had a book like this when I started going through puberty!! Very informative!!! Book is for girls 11 and up or 5th grade and up.
Covers all the important things I want my girls to know and in one place they can look to learn and go back and remember when they have questions.

i really like this book! it is really informative and its super amazing! i goes over stuff that tweens go through! i recommend this to any 10 year old girl and up! i especially love the "Help! Q&A" it helped with lots of situations and i learned stuff that i didn't know before! Great job American Girl!
The book I gave to my daughter she loved it the book has a lot of information in it she needed to know I would recommend it to my friends for the little girls
I bought this book for my 10 year old daughter and she loves it! Its very educational and it covers important topics in which one might be embarrased to discuss.

it is a inappropriate book! Not good for kids 11 and under. It Has private parts especially not good to bring to school with all the snoopy boys.

LOL, This was posted by my 10 year old under my name. We have actually gotten a lot of good information and discussion out of the book, but taking it to school was not a good idea (I didn't know she had it in her backpack.)It does very clearly discuss female body parts, changes and menstruation and is appropriate for girls on the verge of puberty - even though they may be uncomfortable with some of the information.

This book truly helped me understand what was really happening to my body. I am 12 so this review is truly reliable because of my age and what I'm going through. The images were a bit surprising though. I definitely would NOT give this book to an unprepared child. As long as parents talk to their kids beforehand, this book is acceptable. I would also say that children who have not gone into puberty should NOT read this book. plus, should be rated GIRLS ONLY. Be careful if your child has younger siblings of any gender.
This book is just what me and my daughter needed to get her through the start of growing up.  It is a great resource with just enough information.  Great conversation starter.
this series is very productive for young girls having some issues.  especially great for mental health counselors to use w clients

I originally purchased this for a soon to be 11 year old - she's too young emotionally for the information in here. Went back and purchased Book #1 instead, my daughter said that is a much better fit!
summary: Make sure you buy the book for the right age group.

reviewText: Great book for girls to teach them about their changing bodies.  Written and illustrated in a fun way.  My daughter enjoys it.

I purchased this book for my granddaughter's 11th birthday, and read it myself before I gave it to her.  It seems perfect for this age.  It deals with changes in body and emotions, but avoids the topic of the sex act altogether.  Various drawings help to keep the topics light and make it easy to read, without being too explicit.  It has an upbeat "this is normal" tone to it, and repeatedly advises the reader to ask her parents (or other adult) if they have problems or questions, something that I appreciated very much.  It points out that peers are not a good source for information, since they may also be confused.  The book seems geared for young girls about ages 10-11, depending on maturity level.  For some girls, the book would be appropriate at a somewhat younger age, but I believe it is perfect for my 11 year old granddaughter.  Ideally, it should be given either just before or just after the girl begins to menstruate.  I love the honest and matter-of-fact tone of the book, and can anticipate buying more for other granddaughters as they grow up.
I liked the way the book was formatted it really was a helpful guide. It helped me understand more things than I ever did about this
This is a good book for young girls entering adolescence. It covers topics that they may be too bashful to ask about adults about and it way better advice then they'll get from their friends. :0)
as my daughters grow I hope to learn with them.  I know very little about the changing female body and with young daughters they are happy to learn with me.
This was a great book for my girls!  It answered questions that I wasn't able to communicate with them!  And they understood what they were reading!!
summary: Get this book if you have daughters!!

reviewText: This book is well written, up to date, and easy to understand. It has all the information your daughter will need to understand how her body is changing.  It makes it fun, stress free, and exciting, to explain what the future holds.
An awesome book for teenagers in growth, my 12 year old loved it. Very informative. Don't forget to read number 1!

This book is the second edition to the first titled, 'The Care and Keeping of You.' Even if you are open with the young lady in your life does not mean that she will not get use out of this book. Sometimes its easier to look something up in a book in private than asking someone or looking online (where the information may not be correct).

Written in fresh, conversational tone perfect for tweens, this book is well loved and well thumbed by my tween daughter. We went through it together first and now it's always nearby for reference. It's really well done and addresses those touchy subjects in an easy-going manner. She also has the first book, now enjoyed by her younger sister, and wants to get more of the American Girl non-fiction books. Makes talking about "girl stuff" almost painless!
Found it and thought it would help my little girl understand the things she is going to have to start doing when she reaches puberty.  it is easy to understand and covers everything it should.
summary: Perfect book for girls about to undergo the change

reviewText: I was excited to find the booklet to get for my granddaughter.  I is written simply and shows the importance of cleanliness.  She is a great reader and loves all books.  Thanks
summary: Personal Care so Important Young Women

reviewText: Absolutely the perfect book. I bought this for my step daughter and niece and it explained a lot that was not explained to them by their mothers. My niece and I read it together so I could expand on some of the issues.

This book I am sure helped my girl feel much better - Surprise she got her period yesterday but seems calm, curious, surprised and a little vulnerable. She is not devastated!  We think she is the first in her grade - which she isn't thrilled about - but she is not even a little freaked out. It's been GREAT!  everything we could have ever hoped for.
summary: Thank Goodness we got this when she was 9yrs old cuz at 10 she got her period!

reviewText: My daughter loved the book. She said it was really easy to read. I would recommend it for anyone with a pre-teen
Very Helpful to my daughter and made talking to me about her concerns easier for her.  It's a compliment to the first one.

Well done! this book covers all the basics in a clear non intimidating way not sure the difference between the older and younger books. We bought them both and there does not seem to be much different.
My step-daughter really wanted this book to learn more about her body. She read the entire thing in an afternoon. It was great and informational. I wish I had this when I was younger!

I have a shy tweenage girl, who is creeped out about asking questions  I can talk, but she shies away.  This helped her figure out how to ask questions, without me embarrassing her by bringing it up first.

My daughter read the first book, and I gave her this one when she turned 10. She HAS started puberty, otherwise I would have held off. Some reviewers commented that they thought the two books should be combined - but I can understand why they kept them separate. There is definitely some graphic detail in this book that could freak out the under 10 crowd. That said, this book is tasteful, accurate and thorough. I would have preferred to have "Care and Keeping of You" over the "My Body Myself" that I had WAY back when.

My daughters are ages 11, 11 and 13. I bought this book for the twins when they were 10. I let them read through it for a few days and then we sat down and discussed what they had read. I was impressed with how much knowledge they acquired from going over the book on their own. I wanted them to be comfortable with the subjects before we discussed them together. It's a great book and I highly recommend it.
I like this book because it tells what will happen to a girl's body throughout her life without it being scared if it.

My 11 year old needed this book bad. She didn't understand her feelings and was afraid to talk to her friends about it. This reassured her that she is normal and it is normal to go through an emotional roller coaster.

This book was extremely helpful and informative. It gives answers to those questions that girls have trouble asking.

The age limit says 10 and up, but this book didn't really discuss material that was too much for girls under that age. This book is mostly for girls that have been in puberty for a year or so, and some girls start puberty way earlier than others. It is just fine to give this book to a girl under 10 who is already in puberty. The only reason there is an age limit is that most girls don't hit puberty under the age of 10. But some do, so there is no reason to wait to give this book to those girls. It is completely appropriate for them.
This is the perfect companion to book one.  It is geared towards older girls and gives excellent information and advice.
summary: Perfect reading for your blossoming girl.

reviewText: This book help a little girl become a adult. This book talks about what is going to happen as they grow up. It also talks about how we need to keep our bodies healthy and clean.
I bought this book for my granddaughter's 16th birthday and it arrived in plenty of time to give it as a gift.  She loved it and I'm so glad!  Thanks!
This book provided a lot of good information for my 10 year old daughter.  She enjoys the book and it's not too long where it came across as boring.
summary: A lot of good information for my 10 year old daughter

reviewText: Great book to back up what you as a parent have already gone over with your daughter.  Easy to understand language and pictures that aren't embarrassing to pre-teens.  Great resource for her (and you) to have on hand to look over as more questions arise, too.  Can really open up a dialogue on changing bodies.  Highly recommended.
summary: Highly recommended to back up what you have already told her.

reviewText: My daughter had the first book and really liked it so I got her this one as a follow up.  Makes the subject nice and approachable. A good conversation starter. Well written and is a good resource.
summary: Got this for my 11 year old...

reviewText: The book is so informative and is worded in a way that a young child can read.  The pictures in the book are informative too.  My young daughter enjoys looking at this book and its helped her understand the many changes that she'll go through growing up.
summary: A perfect book to share with a growing pre-teen!

reviewText: Good sequel to the Cate of keeping you 1! Both books gave me info on what's ahead of me; I know it will help 1 day! Keep up the good work Cara Natterson! Write a 3rd book! Please!
This is a great book to help girls understand their bodies and what is to come.  I would recommend this to anyone with a girl.

Do you have to use tampons or pads? Because I just don't want to buy any because someone will have to come with me! So do you really need them, or you could never use one and turn out the same if you did?

- Nervously shopping
Love it. Great as an addition to the first care and keeping of you.  Would recommend this to everyone with a girl
This book was very helpful in opening the line of communication between my daughter and myself it helped for her to hear it from someone other than me.

I can't really review this book in truth, because I didn't read it, but my daughter, who is starting to go through puberty, really enjoyed it and took the advice within to heart. I think it's very practical and explains things in a way that's easy to understand and doesn't make girls feel weird or uncomfortable. Highly recommended.
This book was awesome and  I  am 11 and the book I would recommend to a girl who is wanting to read it for more information and more details
Good follow on book for CandKofYou #1.  Plenty of good information about teen hygiene and other topics.  This is a good series for young teens.

This book is another well put together book for young girls and their Moms (or Dads, etc.).  It is a nice presentation of questions and answers for those young minds.  There are various chapters to address changing bodies.  This is great for reading together!
summary: Good Book for Young, Inquiring Minds

reviewText: I can't say enough good about the American Girl books.  Such a wonderful approach to handling some of today's hard tween topics.  I have a ten year old and "The Care and Keeping of You 1 and 2" have been a great catalyst for those must have conversations.  These books take the taboo away from sometimes difficult topics and put things in a way that makes a parent understand the type of thoughts that their child might be having and helps the child to feel like it's normal to have the questions that they have.  Every tween girl should read these books!
summary: American Girl is A+ in our Book

reviewText: My granddaughter seems interested in the information so that she reads it means the information is interesting. That is all I can judge by.  I mailed it to her and never read it.

My daughter and I are reading this together and it is really helping her to understand her body and changes to expect.
I would say this would be more suitable for girls ages 10 and up. My daughter is 8 and some of the graphics and discussion around hygiene products (namely tampons) was a bit much for her to take in BUT we have to start the conversation somewhere and this book really helps with that.
I love the fact that my little one asks to read the next section each night and asks questions.

I purchased this book for my 5th grade granddaughter. She normally does not prefer to read any book. She likes to be active and reading requires her to sit still. She started to read this book and loved it. It caught her attention immediately. She now wants the other books in this series.
I love this book so much. This helped me understand a lot more. You should read it. It's amazing and awesome
Perfect for a middle school girl, I would highly recommend it . It provides moments for conversation and thiik it is worlh the price.

My daughter is 10 and she really enjoys this book and goes back frequently to reference it. That is what I love about a real book...she can go back and see the pictures and read again.  She had the first book when she was 7 and was so thankful for it!  American girl books for growing up are great.  Not too graphic, but explains well what is going on and changing in their bodies.  Overall...would recommend!
This book has been a BIG help to me.  I wanted to have a supermodel body.  Thank you for the awesome books!!!!!
Bought this for my Granddaughter and am waiting for her to get a bit older before giving it to her to read but it looks good
This book is amazing. It's loaded with great advice and helpful hints for a girl going through puberty. I totally recommend reading it.

I purchased books 1,2 and the feelings book. This book is not much different than book 1. I was hoping it would help me walk through the sex talk, but there was no mention of sex in the book!! Very disappointed.
summary: Not much more than book one and no mention of the major subject

reviewText: I chose this book for my granddaughter who is going on 13 years of age.  Girls her age should know how to take care of themselves.

This is just as good as the Care and Keeping of You for younger girls. It goes into a bit more detail and is written at a slightly higher reading level. Some of the information is identical to the other, but it's necessary information so I can see why it was left that way--if a girl didn't have the first book you'd want that info in there. And there's not so much that there's no reason to buy this one if you have the first one.

My daughter has both and loves both of them. I love that they are well-written, well thought-out, and age appropriate. The only thing that made me scratch my head was the instructions on how to check for breast cancer. How often do teens need to worry about this? I guess better safe than sorry, but make sure you explain to your daughter that this is very, very rare for young girls.

Overall, I definitely recommend this series.
summary: Great up-step from the younger book

reviewText: I swear by these books for approaching "difficult" topics with my kids.  Now that there is an older version of this bestseller, I'm excited to be able to present this information to my girls in a non-threatening, "YOU SMELL" sort of way, so that they can learn how to take care of themselves without giving up any of their identitty in the process.  Very highly recommended!

The wonderful thing about this book is that it helps you help your daughter through potentially awkward changes.  I feel that a book that aids in keeping the lines of communication open even before you enter the preteen years is a good thing.  This book is ideal for girls age 10 and up due to its going into more detail about bodily changes than the first book.  I am very impressed with the range of topics covered that not only deal with physical changes but emotional ones too.  A friend of my daughter is being raised by her Dad and I will be sharing this book with him as well.
summary: Prepares girls for what is ahead...

reviewText:
This was a great intro book for what to expect as you grow up.  The details were appropriate for my 8-year old, and the book was easy to read.  She loved the style and has referred to the book many times.

I was, however, a bit frustrated at the way some of the topics were introduced.  My daughter didn't know that she was "supposed" to be worried about acne -- now she thinks she sees pimples on her face.  She's also now worried about how her feelings will change and that she'll fight with me about them.  She was also surprised that the book mostly suggested talking to Mom -- she thought that meant that she shouldn't talk to her Dad if she wanted to.

All of the info was appropriate and very true, but I would suggest reading it together so that you can address the not as positive points when they come up.
summary: Good info, but there is a focus on the negative

reviewText: My daughter just turned 9, we finished the first Care & Keeping of You book last year and really found it a friendly and open way to discuss what can sometimes be embarrassing for girls. She liked it so much that she's kept it in her bedside table so she can look back at it if she has any additional questions etc. Next I bought her It's Not the Stork!: A Book About Girls, Boys, Babies, Bodies, Families and Friends (The Family Library) It's Not the Stork as I assumed this would be the next step in discussions... however after starting to read it together and her having really no interest (we actually stopped at the title "so what is sex" and she never even cared to go on. I realized that with the beginnings of puberty coming on and her changing hormones and feelings that what she remained curious about, and maybe even still a bit curious and/or scared about, was her own changing body and emotions. She really couldn't care less for the details on a boys reproductive organs or how a baby comes into being, but she's got lots of questions about her period... tampons vs pads, her breasts, body hair, etc. This book proved to be exactly what we needed. It's more indepth then the first and yet not off the topic that is most important to her right now... herself! I also love that it's not just a book of physical changes, it also covers emotions, friendships, family relationships etc. A wonderful pair of books for helping you guide your own little girl into becoming a young woman.
summary: I love that it covers emotional aspects as well as physical

reviewText: I got this for my 11-year-old, and she read it right away. It's a colorful book with lots of advice on everything from body changes and taking care of yourself during your period, to simple advice on relating to others and beginning to date. It's from the writers of American Girl magazine, which my daughter enjoys, and I like for its straightforward advice for girls that emphasizes being yourself and liking yourself.

The Care and Keeping of You 2: The Body Book for Older Girls is a perfect book for girls who want to know about their bodies but are embarrassed to ask their parents or just afraid to admit that they don't know about certain things. I got this book for my stepdaughter who is very shy and doesn't like to bother anyone with anything. This book helped open the dialogue and now she's asking questions about her body and even informing me of things she doesn't think I know (cute). The book talks about everything from breasts, to tampons, and all the way to infections.

I love how classy this book is and this book also opens the line of communication between you and your child, niece, or any other family member that you give this book to. I also love that The Care and Keeping of You 2 has a section that asks questions so that you and your loved one can reiterate what has been discussed and therefore reinforce.

 A great book you will love this and this can help you with some of those awkward moments in life.
summary: Very Informative for You and Your Loved One!

reviewText: This is a great follow-up to the first "Care & Keeping of You" book. It goes into a little more depth about puberty, what to expect, and emotional and physical changes. It doesn't discuss sex and heavier topics, so it's perfect for pre-teen girls who just need a gentle, reassuring guide about the changes they're seeing, or will soon be seeing (and feeling).
I bought this for mydaughter to explain her body and all the changes and peer pressures. It was very helpful
Very helpful book to read with your daughters. My daughter has re-read this book several times and keeps learning a little bit more.

Bought for my daughter who just entered Jr. High School, and she loves the book.  I got the first version when she was 8, and now that she is 11 I realized she needed something a little bit more mature.  This book was a great addition to the first version.
summary: Great for a JR. High School Girl

reviewText: This is another excellent book from American Girl. It is written for tweens. It gives clear, age appropriate information regarding menstruation, body care and more. It goes a little more in depth than the first book. I like that it is factual yet written at a tween lever. It isn't stuffy or too casual. It offers some great examples that girls may actually experience. I have recommended it to several of my friends with tween girls.
My daughter and I both enjoyed reading this book. She has read it more than once and uses it as a reference.

I got this book because we had used the initial volume in this series with our daughter when she was younger. While she protested and was "grossed out" by that one, this one is more graphic and detailed. So again after the initial negative reaction, she read this and engaged in some conversation with us, which is great!!! You can't have enough information these days for our youth and I encourage all parents of girls to give this one a look.
summary: An excellent book for girls to learn about their changing bodies!

reviewText:
I came along too early for the American Girl books, and don't really remember having anything relevant to read as a girl on the topic of "your changing body".  In fact, the most we had was the afternoon when they separated the boys from the girls so that the nurse could show us a filmstrip.  Awkward.

My little ones are not quite ready for this stage, but my now 10-year-old niece spends her summer vacations living with us, so many of these topics are relevant to us.

Like the original Care & Keeping of You book, this book is written in an easy, conversational tone.  It doesn't talk down to girls, and uses real terminology.  Having these conversations is not always easy, but the book gives you an "in" to start a discussion.

I really love this book. My girls are too young for it yet, but I plan to save it for when they are ready to read it. I'm a mom but I'm not so old that I don't remember being 11 once. My mom talked with me a lot about my body changing and various other life topics; we had a good relationship and she taught me a lot. I hope to have the same kind of relationship with my girls as they get older. But sometimes it helps to read things from another source. A source that ISN'T another mostly-clueless preteen! It reiterates what has already been taught or what has been forgotten. It makes it easy to ask questions that one might be too shy to ask, and it offers reliable answers that one can trust.
As I said, I plan to give this to my girls when they are ready to read it on their own, but I also intend to discuss it with them. The book has so many great topics that I would never have thought to discuss with my girls, so in addition to giving them good, interesting things to learn about, it will also open up new conversation topics for us. Yes, it covers the usual subjects of female puberty, and it does so in great detail (such as the pros and cons of tampons vs. pads, UTI's, moodiness), but it also addresses topics about life in general, how to eat healthy, how to have healthy sleep patterns, how to respect yourself and embrace your clothing size.
It address all of these topics in fun, easy to process ways, with cute illustrations. Cute enough for them to feel comfortable, but sophisticated enough for them to trust it and WANT to read it. Honestly I wish this book had been around when I was a preteen.

For those mothers that want to educate their daughters, but the daughters turn a deaf ear.....  There are some things they just absorb better from another source.  This answered and inspired any questions she had.

This book is full of great information for your growing girl. It is written in a way that gets the information across without being too technical and detailed. Each subject is covered on 1 to 2 pages.

The book gives the basic info an inquiring girl may want and then suggests that talking with a parent / trusted adult is a great idea.

It's a great way to bridge into topics that could be uncomfortable for you and/or your tween.

This book is a wonderful intro to the changes that happen in a girl's body during puberty (I have not read the first book). I think it is very tastefully done, and I love the nice illustrations. They do have diagrams of the female body, as well as pictures on how to insert a tampon, but they are very tastefully done.

I think it is wonderful that they not only discuss physical changes, but they talk about emotional aspects of puberty as well as healthy eating, exercise, etc. When my daughter is older this will be an excellent book to start some good discussions. I really appreciate that, several times, they mention that you should talk to a parent first before doing something - such as shaving.

Perfect book to introduce girls to puberty and to start some great discussions. Highly recommended.

I have the daughter that is very private. Does not like to talk about these embarrassing puberty things. So working with her personality and discussing the changes of her body was a challenge since she would shut down whenever the subject got even remotely close. When she was in 4th I got her the first book in the care and keeping of you along with the journal. I made her read the book and then use the journal to answer questions about herself. What I liked about the journal is it asked leading questions for the girl to use with her mother. This helped us tremendously and while she is still embarrassed with what is going on inside her she knows coming to me is safe ground. Now this book; my daughter is now in 6th and still going through changes. The differences in the book are obvious. The illustrations in the first are a little more cartoonish and definitely for a younger girl. The illustrations in book 2 are more mature. The discussions are more mature as well. Some parents may be shocked at some of the illustrations showing changes in breast and how to use a tampon. However, for girls like my daughter who is private about her body the illustrations are much easier for her. 2 reinforces the subjects discussed in the first book but also expands to include more family dynamics and social circles. What I'm really impressed with is the constant reminder to talk with your mom or some other trusted adult. Both books have "submitted" questions from girls and responses that are appropriate for the subject. Lastly a Glossary is included at the end of book 2 not included in the first to define terms used that a girl may not know - from Acne to Yeast Infection.

American Girl has done it again with publishing a safe book for tween girls to get to know their bodies. Thanks American Girl!

I cannot recommend The Care and Keeping of You series enough. If you have a girl nearing puberty, you need this book! I'm not saying  to use this book as a replacement for talking to your child about her changing body, but it's great to supplement your discussions. You can look at it together or let her  look at it in private. These books do a great job of informing girls without "over-informing" them. These book are a wonderful resource for girls!
summary: Best Book For Tween or Young Teen Girls

reviewText: The day this book arrived in my house, my 11 year old daughter disappeared into her room with it and it didn't surface again for three months. I consider that successful. It was obviously read and she started asking questions  so I knew she was thinking about the contents. I would highly recommend this book to other parents and their 5th-6th grade daughters.

I myself had the good fortune to have a mother who never shied away from discussing these things, and as a CNA/midwife's assistant, she was well-versed in these things, and I always had my questions answered before I ever even asked them....  :)  While I am long past puberty, I have several young girls in my life who will be hitting puberty soon, and I thought this book would be useful info to read/have.  :)

  This book is short, right about 100pages, it explains really anything a girl would have questions about the changes that are going on in her body, and it always defers to the parents or an adult.  Meaning, she always says if you have questions ask your parents, they are there to help you, which I thought was awesome, more young ladies need to hear this from a third party source.  :)

  The material answers many questions about periods, tampons/pads, body changes, shaving legs, etc, but it still leaves plenty of room for discussion with parents, it is not a text  book, but a cursory view.  I think the one thing I thought should have been discussed a little more was eating disorders as bulimia and anorexia are not the only two, there is a third VERY common one called "Binge Eating Disorder" or "BED", it is essentially bulimia without the vomiting, laxatives, and over exercise.

  I know this is not a book on eating disorders, but since it does give a couple pages to the issue, it would have been important to mention BED.  A lot of young women struggle with this issue, and I feel at least a cursory overview of it would have been beneficial.  it is just as destructive to your health.  I had all 3 of those eating disorders in different times in my life.  They were all equally destructive to my health in different ways.

  I liked that it goes over body image and how you should never compare yourself to anymore, whether its how you like or when you start your period or when you get your breasts.  Everybody is going to be different and that is a-okay, and in fact it is normal!  Being that it comes from a Dr., it will hopefully ring more true for girls, then again, at that age, do they really care who it comes from as long as its not a parent?  lol

  Loved the little Q&A sections they were fun and had good questions/answers,  Some of them I had to laugh at, but they were, after all, from 10-12yr girls, it was cute and relevant for other 10-12yr girls.  Loved the question about shaving legs, which ironically, my mother wouldn't let me shave them till I was like 13yrs, and I had boys make fun of me for it.  She just didn't feel it was appropriate or necessary, which I can definitely see where she was coming from, it really wasn't necessary, even if I felt it was.  Though she let me wear makeup since I was like 5yrs, so there was a weird dichotomy going on... lol

  Anyway, I look forward to sharing this with my niece(s)/friends daughters, I definitely feel they will get a lot out of it.  :D

  God Bless ~Amy

Summary: Quick and easy to read book covers basics of puberty, though avoids any reference to reproduction.  Additional information on emotions, family dynamics and appearances (Hair removal, for example) can be seen as providing context making this more a book about "Growing up" and less about "Plumbing"

If you were looking for a book that would explain puberty (Periods, breast development, hormones, etc) to your daughter without having to get into acknowledging the existence of sex or any of it's side effects, this might be for you.  It also talks about peer pressure, body image, self esteem and hair removal.

The writing is clear and friendly, I was a bit surprised to see this as a book from "American Girl" but was glad to see the book avoided any commercial or implied link to the brand.
summary: Basic body knowledge for tweeners avoids controversy

reviewText: Another great read for a young girl learning what her body is going through and how to care for her newly developing self.  I bought this for two children aged 9 and 11 and they have been reading it every night to answer so many questions young girls have.
summary: Just as good as the first edition

reviewText: My niece has the 1st version of this book and now she is a bit older and going through the phase from child to not-quite-a-tween. Book number 2 of The Care and Keeping of you really helps bridge the gap and is from a familiar source - American Girl.  While she may start to become disinterested in the dolls, the branding and familiarity of American Girl can still help pave the way into her next phase of childhood.  She loves this book and feels comfortable discussing the topics in it.

This is an amazing book! I wish they had had these when I was that age!
I expected it to focus mostly on periods and body hair and breasts--the usual puberty stuff, but this book covered SO MUCH MORE!! It goes over taking care of your skin, body odors, weight, growing pains, emotional changes, body image, self-esteeem, fitness, and more. It does this using really cute (but not "childish" cute) illustrations, clear and lighthearted language (that is not condescending), and is direct. It covers a lot of questions I had at that age, as well as some that are more relevant to the modern pre-teen. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this book for parents with a pre-teen in their home. It helps them explore some things privately to enable a dialogue when they are ready. GREAT BOOK!
summary: not just puberty, this book covers everything; awesome layout and delivery

reviewText: My daughter was very pleased that I purchased this book. She feels so much more prepared for what lies ahead. She is 12.

Geared toward pre-teens, this book covers the basics of girls getting periods, pads vs. tampons, moodiness, the need for deodorant, hair in odd places, and more.  Broken down into easy to digest sections, you'll see things like ear piercing, personal relationships (such as the pull to spend more time with your friends than your family), and other girl topics covered.  It covers way more than the generic "Changes" book I got in 5th grade for sure.

What I liked about this was that it also covered self-esteem issues, touching on eating disorders and body image.  Another good aspect was that as I read through discussions on topics, there was a definite theme of "you should talk to your parents about this before doing it".  So aside from giving girls a private way to find the answers to their pubescent issues, it reinforced that we parents are ultimately in charge and that we can be trusted (hey, mom was a teenager once too.)

I recommend to parents of girls 10-12.  This book can be used guide for discussion too for moms to thumb through, pick out a topic, read it out loud, and discuss.
summary: Covers all the basics, and more

reviewText:
I ordered this for my 10 yr. old daughter, who had entered the stage of puberty curiosity.  Having already  read through the books her older sister has on this topic, I was interested to see her reaction to this book.  I was pleasantly surprised to find that she did not toss the book aside as old news.  Instead, she carefully read through it, and shared several new things with me which she had not heard before.  She even started it over again after the first initial read through.

I was a surprised to find several drawings of naked girls, used for demonstrating breast self exams and tampon application.  However, some girls are visual learners, and need such guidance to truly understand.  The drawings are far more appropriate for this than photos!

The book is packaged by American Girl in a decorative paperboard envelope (separate from the shipping envelope) which is nice for gift giving.  However, this envelope is sealed with a wide swath of heavy glue, making it impossible to easily open.  Ours ended up a torn mess, which was not the classy initial presentation I think American Girl was going for.

With a wide variety of topics covered, from changing figures to shaving to emotional swings, I felt this book covered a lot of ground.  My daughter definitely found it an educational read, too.
summary: My 10 yr old devoured this book

reviewText: My 10 year old daughter read this book from cover to cover, without stopping. It discusses a wide range of topics from menstruation, proper grooming, self breast exams, etc to peer pressure. It provided this awkward information in an easy to read format for young girls. It also has pictures, which one of my daughter's friends called inappropriate (the breast from the breast exam article)but the rest of the girls enjoyed the different articles and actually discussed them. I also liked that it gave my daughter the confidence to ask me questions about her changing body. It made the conversation that much easier when she was able to approach me with her questions. This book should be given to all growing girls who are starting to have questions about their bodies.

I mistakenly got this for my 7 going on 8 year old and she very excitedly started reading the book before I had a chance to read it myself. And it was about 3 years too early for her.  She was fine with the content but most was over her head and more mature information than I would like for her to be learning at age 7 ie how to use a tampon and how to do a breast exam.

Not recommended for girls under 11 years of age unless onset of puberty is expected.
summary: Not recommended for girls under 11 years unless showing onset of puberty

reviewText:
The folks at American Girl once again prove that they know what's on the minds of young girls.  This updated version of The Care and Keeping of You provides a thorough look at many questions facing girls ages 11 to 13.  It provides a nice balance between the practical and the emotional, giving frank and straightforward information about managing your period and some realistic explanations and ideas for relating to friends and family when your moods are swinging off the charts.

I particularly admired the sections on body image and self-esteem and the emphasis placed on the ideas that no body is perfect and we all develop at different rates.  The Q & A sections put things in a girl's perspective, which will perhaps provide a useful resource for moms who are struggling to figure out just what's going on in the mind of their temperamental pre-teen.

There are straight forward and graphic instructions with cartoon illustrations showing the proper technique for a self-breast exam and how to insert a tampon.  Parents shouldn't shy away from these straight forward portrayals as they effectively provide accurate information in a way that will help every young girl learn to appreciate her body and its changes.

The Care and Keeping of You 2 is a must have for any young girl facing puberty and the physical and emotional changes that go along with it.  As The Letter to You states at the very beginning of this well packaged book, this book will help young girls learn how to ask questions when they are worried.  This is a great resource and an enthusiastic recommend for parents and daughters.
summary: Helping young girls learn how to ask questions.

reviewText:
I agree with most of the reviews in stating that the book is thorough, down to earth and explicit while remaining tasteful and tactful for the information presented. My one caveat is that I would NOT give this to an 8 year old. Some of the pictures are rather graphic, and I feel that teaching an 8 year old how to insert a tampon and do a breast self-exam is pushing the envelope just a bit. If you want to use this book for kids under about 11, I would do so with discretion. Don't just hand them the book. Look at it first and discuss certain parts with your child. Not all of the content is appropriate for all the ages stated, though some is.
Keep in mind that this book is NOT written from a religious vantage point, so you may have slightly different views on several issues or the way that they are handled. It is more of a matter-of-fact view of issues, options and choosing the path that is best for you. I certainly intend to use the book with my girls, but I would not simply hand it to them off the cuff without discussing the info personally before allowing them to read through it.
Some subjects may be hard to discuss, but they need to be. Handing a child a book is not the same as talking with them regarding their concerns. I see a potential for parents to buy the book and hand it off to their children with a "that takes care of that" demeanor. No matter what they read, there will be questions. I strongly urge anyone using this to read the book first themselves and if your religious or personal convictions conflict with some of the information given in the book, take time to discuss those differences.
summary: Very well done, but I wouldn't give it to an 8 year old.

reviewText: This is a perfect down to earth book presenting all the maturing girl needs to know.  It of course doesn't supplant mother-daughter conversations, but it's perfect for both to read and discuss.  It covers basic nutrition and health advice along with frank and concise concerning the changes in the girl's body.  There's no talking down to the reader, nor is it dull text book reading.  And it's all presented in a format that makes for interesting reading.  I can't be too strong in my recommendation for this book.
summary: Every girl approaching puberty should read this

reviewText:
Bras to tampons
Zits to Pits
Mood, body image, and lots in between with illustrations to boot.

Illustrations while detailed and informative are also "basic" and non-threatening.  Simple and clear but not so graphic that the "eww" factor kicks in

This is a book that I feel comfortable gifting and letting my granddaughter read when she is old enough.  I feel the information is presented in a clear factual manner.

---  I'm very impressed.
My daughter read the first volume many times, and told me that this version was now available for older girls...it is terrific!  This will become another well-read book in our house.
summary: A great book for older girls

reviewText: We have the first book, and my daughter read it cover to cover when she was 9.  When this one arrived, I handed it over and she rolled her eyes.  However; later, she asked me some questions about some of the things she had read and it really opened up some conversations that we needed to have.  I know there are a couple parts, she skipped over, because she thought they were "weird" or "gross," but in due time she will be ready for that info as well.  I notice they really don't absorb what they aren't ready for anyway.  Overall, great book, and I would recommend it to any pre-teen girl.
summary: Spot on for my 10 year old

reviewText: I bought this book for my daughters and they love it.  I bought them "The Care of Keeping YOU" first (which was a hit).
summary: This book is a big hit with my daughters.

reviewText: I purchased this for my daughter as she begins to enter puberty. We'll go over some of it together, and I'll let her explore the rest on her own as she feels comfortable and ready to do so. That's the wonderful thing about the AG books - you can trust them to give just enough information without going too far into the details. I think that the illustrations and graphics are very appealing and make the book fun to read. I purchased this as a companion to "Head to Toe Guide to You", which is also a fabulous resource that touches on some of the same topics, but also covers others as well.

I ordered this book for my 11 year old sister, since she had read the first one. It is an age appropriate look at the changes they are going through, and also discusses important emotional issues. Puberty is a tough time and I think books like these are great for helping them feel more comfortable with the changes. Even if you talk to them they may not feel comfortable asking certain questions, and books like this one can help.

This has been a great book for my almost 10 year old and I to read together. She is changing but was completely freaked out by the detail in what used to be the one book. Reading together a book which introduces/addresses potentially difficult topics but using perfectly benign language and illustrations has allowed her to ask some questions, talk about some awkward social situations, and allowed me to gauge how she is feeling about herself. I can't thank American Girl enough for their series of 'advice' books; my daughter responds to them well and as I a parent appreciate the dialogue which these books help open up between us.
summary: Great book, so glad that they split info into two 'age' groups!

reviewText: My daughter read this book and it was great she doesn't like to take my (mom's) word for things but when this book said the same things as me she felt more confident in my answers.

reviewText: I have this in the wings, waiting for the "right time".

I agree with the body image statements. My daughter will be 11 in 4 months and has never thought badly about any part of her. She doesn't even know judging people is a thing.  She knows people come in all shapes and sizes. That looking the same is boring. Also, shaving is bad for you, and even worse for the environment. We are women who are comfortable being so in my family. We don't want to look like hairless children forever. 2 pages on shaving your "hairy legs" is just idiotic body shaming propoganda. There's nothing wrong with being the strong beautiful WOMAN you're suppose to be. Sad that when girls start to become women they're told to remove all evidence of it.
summary: That looking the same is boring. Also

Now I can just answer any questions she has about what she learned. It will definitely be passed on to my younger daughter when its time.

summary: Bought for my daughter, and shes read it multiple ...

reviewText: a great book to help explain things to your little girl.

I made sure to read this first, before letting my 9 year old read it.  There were some things in there I did not like.  A lot of the info I thought was good and was fine with her reading, so I just covered up the stuff I didn't want her reading.  The stuff I covered up, were about negative body image.  One example is about freckles.  My daughter has freckles, and it is not a negative thing to her.  In the book, there is a girl saying how she hates her freckles and wants to know how to get rid of them, and talks about creams to lighten them.  The book does say to embrace them and gives the girl good advice, but I didn't want to put in my daughter's head that freckles are a negative thing, which is what I felt when I read it.  It addresses other issues, and it offers good advice, however, my daughter has zero issues with some topics discussed and I don't want her suddenly thinking, "Oh!  Am I fat?  Am I flat chested?", etc.  The book addresses negative self image, which is great if a girl needs it.  Also, in the beginning it says how the things in the book can be embarrassing to talk about.  I omitted that, because it shouldn't be embarrassing, and I don't think it will be unless I make it uncomfortable..  She hasn't finished the book yet, but she has been excited to talk to me about what she's reading.  My advice would be just to read it first and make sure it's giving the info you want her to have.

So glad I purchased this book.  It was very informative without being overly graphic or embarrassing.  My daughter and I read this together and I am looking forward to reading book number 2 with her when she gets slightly older.
Awesome book for pre teens.
Awesome book for pre-teens about body changes, including the periods.  Daughter likes to read it.  Would like to see a bit less emphasis on tampons for book #1 (book #2, sure) but oh well.

reviewText: Great!!

My sister asked me to buy this book for my niece, age 8-1/2, who was beginning to show real curiosity about her body (many of her best friends are 10 and 11 and thus are a bit ahead of her).  My niece picked up the book on her own and spent almost an hour skimming through it seemingly randomly, and since then she & my sister have used it to address several specific questions she's had. The book presents the information in a way easy for my niece to understand without speaking down to her, and the presentation is "matter of fact" enough for my sister to feel completely comfortable having her read the book with or without her participation.
summary: Has Been Great for an 8-1/2 Year Old Girl Beginning to Wonder

reviewText: Both of my granddaughters read the book and said it answered some of the questions they had. Preteens don't open up about these topics, and the book anticipates what they might want to know.
Great American Girl product.

With a topic like puberty, I wanted to read this before giving it to my daughter and I'm glad I did.

The Good:

It's got nice pictures throughout.  The writing is simple and easy to understand, working well for girls that are either teenagers, pre-teens, or girls even just curious and wanting to learn more about their bodies.

The Bad:

It introduces girls to a lot of topics that as a mom, I'm not impressed with.  I don't like that the author talks about body imagery as though it's a negative thing and that girls shouldn't be offended by what others think.  While I agree that it's not about what others think, an 8-year doesn't need to be worried about the possibility that someone *MAY* be judging her.  Why plant that seed of self-doubt when all there is is confidence now?

The other thing I'm not a fan of is that while this does talk a lot about adolescent things girls will go through such as growing body hair, body odor, acne, growing a chest, and getting your period, the book however does not talk about WHY a girl goes through these changes.  Not that I think a girl should learn about the birds and the bees from a book but the book shouldn't assume that a young girl is going to understand why she's bleeding once a month "down there."  By itself, it can leave room for a lot of questions and a lot of fear with someone young.
summary: Be ready to be a mom first, then read WITH your daughter

daughter likes.  informative.

reviewText: Well written and illustrated.  Good emphasis on esteem and healthy living.  Who would have thought a health book would have my 7 year old excited about reading each chapter?  Made the training bra experience easy peasy for this grandmother caregiver.

Bought this for my 9 year old daughter. We are pretty open, but I thought a book may provide her with more information about things she might be too shy to ask me or just provide her with more information about things I may have forgotten to talk about. This book is easy to read, straightforward, and provides factual information. I looked at ALL the puberty books and read hundreds of reviews before settling on this one.

HOWEVER, there is one aspect of the book I do not like, an aspect that several other reviewers also mentioned. This book is written for 8-9 year olds, yet it brings up many issues one could be made to feel insecure about: wearing glasses, body type, freckles, developing early, etc. My daughter currently has a very healthy self esteem. She doesn't give a thought to whether she's too thin or too fat, and she's always loved her freckles, which we call 'angel kisses.' I don't want it to get into her head that these are things to worry about or dislike about yourself. Before I gave her the book, I told her there were questions about girls not liking certain things about themselves, but you should love yourself just they way you are, as God made us all perfectly imperfect!
summary: Easy reading, factual, but may not be the best book if your little girl is insecure!

reviewText: I bought this for my 10 year old daughter. We talk about puberty, as well as other personal issues, so our communication has always been strong. Even though she can come to me for any questions or concerns about her body/mind; I feel that books like this are helpful and give different perspectives that I may not think of. I enjoy information from other sources, and my daughter seems to as well. She said this brought up a lot of what she is noticing with her change (I haven't had a chance to read it yet) and seems more informed on what is going on. It also helped to remind her she's not alone in what she's going through. From what she has told me about this book, it seems to have helped her in a few different ways. I would recommend this to any young girl out there.

reviewerName: Mundie Moms & Mundie Kids Book Reviews
reviewText:
This book was highly recommended to me by a variety of fiends. It's a great discussion starter about puberty. My daughter and I have talked a lot about puberty. She's often used this book as a reference and come to me for more detailed information. My daughter loved this book.

What I liked about it - it's simply written. It's easy for them to understand. I wish I had had this as a reference when I was my daughter's age.

What I don't like - some of the concepts. I've worked hard to establish positive body images in my home, and both my kids have that. There are some questions posed in this book, which might seem natural to some, that do take away from that positive image. However, it's also a great opportunity to talk more about positive body images, and about why these questions were mentioned.

Overall, this is a great book that does lead into puberty discussions. My daughter has loved this book.
Explaining puberty to a nine year old is difficult.  This book made it a lot easier.
Great gift for my 8 year old daughter. I love that she can read and re-read and ask me about any questions she has.

reviewText: This book was recommended to me by my sister-in-law to help start the conversation with my daughter about all of the changes she will experience in the next few years.  My daughter is reading the book on her own, and I've been checking in two or three times a week to see if she has any questions, which she always does.  Growing up can be strange and sometimes a little scary.  Knowledge of what to expect is helping to eliminate any fears.  I highly recommend this book for moms and daughters.  I would especially recommend this book for single dads; as it would help you tremendously.

reviewText: My daughter loves this book. It has generated many important dialogues.

What a great source of info for a young lady, this was a perfect way to start important conversations and lay everything out in a matter of fact way. My daughter enjoyed "reading about herself" and has been enthusiastic to further her hygiene habits. She also enjoyed the accompanying journal.

I have two daughters, and with the oldest recently turning 10 years-old, she is beginning to experience a lot of the changes we all know are bound to happen.  Given the fact that I divorced their mother several years ago, and despite being re-married to a woman who is a great support system for the girls, I have largely raised my girls from the perspective of their father, their friend, their sports coach, as well as playing the role of a mom in many ways.

I have an incredible relationship with my daughters, and we talk about everything--because of their surroundings resulting from the divorce, they've been forced to grow up quickly like many children today.  I do my best on a daily basis to prepare them and to treat them with dignity, respect, care, love, and guidance.  With that said, I don't have all of the answers, and while I can research things and explain them from an outsider's perspective, this book is a fantastic resource for several reasons:

1.) The content - it covers a lot in a small package, topics ranging from changing bodies to eating habits, exercise, and hygiene guidance.
2.) The ease of presentation - my daughter ADORES the way the book is presented.  She feels very comfortable laying in bed at bedtime and reading a section or two with me, and having comfortable dialog about often-times uncomfortable content for a 10yo.
3.) The portrayal of not being alone - One of my favorite components of this book, is that through the verbiage and imagery, it's clear that no girl is unique in encountering these issues, but they ARE very unique in when, what, and how... it doesn't make my girl feel weird about the content.

I read voraciously and review from time to time, but I really do insist that parents scoop this one up... it's a very valuable buy.

I was unsure about buying this for my 8 year old daughter after reading some of the reviews. But I couldn't find any other books that resonated with me. So I purchased it and read it before letting my daughter.
I think this book fit well. There are a few things that I think should be changed but for the most part this book is good. It helped me explain everything to her and adds other things like brushing your hair and things that aren't uncomfortable. She said she liked it. We read it together and then she asked if she could look over it by herself. I wanted to make sure she knew about periods I didn't want her to think she was dieing if she got it without knowing what it was. Kids these days are having periods earlier than years before. Overall this book is a good book. I would recommend this to family and friends.
summary: Good book, explains a lot, not just periods

reviewText: I really like this book. It helps girls to know how to take care of themselves and how important it is. The books of AG are really helpful. I am an AG fan and I have read a lot of their books. I really encourage girls to read them.
Very informative and easy to read and understand for my 9 yr old daughter.

I purchase this book for my daughter and her friend who are 9 years old.
They could not put the book down.  They had conversations about their breast  and more!!!
Keep them learning about their bodies, reading and discussing.
I would recommend this book.

My daughter is 9 and is starting to show signs that would lead me to purchase this book. I'm a registered nurse so I've been talking to her about how her body will change, etc. for over a year. Sometimes she gets uncomfortable or emotional when I try to explain what to expect, which is understandable. I bought this book for her and she was not interested in seeing what it had to say initially. I left the book on her dresser and in two days she read the whole thing. When she was done she came out of her room and initiated a really great conversation about what she read, along with questions she had come up with. I think the pictures helped her understand it wouldn't be as scary as she had initially thought. It was easy for her to read and take the information in to process and then ask her questions. I don't think she would have been as relaxed with out this so I would highly recommend it to anyone with a daughter starting puberty .
summary: Highly recommend this to anyone with a daughter!

reviewText: Great conversation starter w/ my daughter. We read chapters/sections together and then discuss it. I was worried about how to have some of the conversation and this really helps with that. Also, this is a good way to be aware of some the changes.
summary: Great conversation starter w/ my daughter

reviewText: My daughter is fascinated with the books in this series. All of the books have been helpful in explaining emotions, changing bodies, and friendship dramas. Cannot recommend this enough.

I love the format and illustrations, but I wish the information was broken down into two books; one for pre-adolescents 7-8 and another for the 9-11 range (in addition to the second version already written). That's the only reason for my rating of a 4. My soon to be 8 year old needs the body information, but not periods just yet. I also don't think she needs some of the social issues like body image that are mentioned because it's not an issue for her and she's not been influenced in that way so I don't want to introduce it yet. I loved another reviewers idea to write little notes to your daughter throughout the book and I've enjoyed doing that!. My daughter loves it as well!! It's her favorite part actually. And finally, I wish their was a boy version! I have boy/girl twins and I'm using this book with both children, but he keeps asking me "what about me?" Good question! I'm looking for a good resource for him!
Love it, exactly what I expected!
I just turned 9 and this helped me. I would recommend this book to young girls about my age, and want to be prepared.
My 5 year old loves finding out about herself. She is full of questions and this book seems to have a nice balance of fact and light storytelling.it explains things in language she can understand.

In true American Girl fashion, this book is written appropriately for a tween.  I read it with my 10 year-old daughter, and was relieved with how delicate topics, like getting your period, were discussed.  I really liked how body issues were explained, and there were a few humorous lines that didn't take away from the seriousness of the topics.
Good for age appropriate.

She is extremely intelligent and she told me the book was for someone who "did not have a clue."  She  still read it cover to cover and informed me that we had already talked about what the book covered. She wanted to keep it anyway so I guess it was not a complete waste of money!

reviewText: Great. Appropriate for my daughter.

This is an excellent book for young girls to help them learn about their changing bodies.  My granddaughter saw the title and started reading this book immediately upon receiving it.  She kept reading it for hours. It is a great book to open up a conversation with your daughter.  It helped the communication between her and her mother. They read the book together and it made questions easier to answer.  I can't stress enough how much this book helped my granddaughter learn about what will be happening to her body.  She took every word to heart and began eating healthier when she was done reading it. She turned down desserts and chose fruit instead.  It really surprised me how big of an impact this book had on her when she was done reading it.
summary: An important book for your young daughter to prepare her for changes in her body.

reviewText:
This book is even better then I remembered! When my dr told me my daughter was prepubescent I had no idea what to do! I'm not ready for this I have TWO 9yr old girls! This book was and is a life saver. It had the perfect amount of description without going into too much detail for my young daughters.

I especially like that it doesn't even touch the birds and bees yet. They need to understand what is going to happen to their bodies first and foremost. It does say that your body is getting ready for a baby, but does not talk about the boys part. For our family it is perfect because that is something I would like to explain when they get slightly older.

Pros: it keeps them very engaged, easy to read and understand. The naked pictures are just cartoons so they didn't get uneasy about them at all

Cons: there are some things in the columns that should had their own page like tampons vs pads and how to use them.
summary: Get first book for growing girls

reviewText: This book help my daughter to appreciate her body and  to understand the changes her body will be going through.
good book

ok

Recommended by a friend with an older pre-teen and purchased for a 6 year old. Very good book for younger girls and for parents who want some talking points about body care. This book will be useful for years because it also discusses peer pressure and health as it relates to things like smoking but also addresses body hair and other not yet topics. So far I have experienced the following successes:
-I noticed immediately in the improved quality of her grooming, she is taking time to brush her teeth without adult supervision and she is using soap in the shower without being asked.
-She wan't to lean every week what more she can to do take care of her body.
-She is more willing to let me wash and deep condition her hair.
summary: Great for getting little girls to take ownership of self-care

reviewText: This is great book for ages 9-12. It talks about everything from puberty to hygiene, to taking care of all aspects of your body, hair, skin, nails, wearing deodorant, what to do if you get a wart on your foot, etc, without talking about sex or sexuality. I read it cover to cover before giving it to my daughter and spoke with her friends mothers, and we all got it for our kids so they could talk about these topics together (hopefully).
summary: Great book for girls to learn how to take care of their maturing body.

reviewText: This book is a must have for not-so-little girls. After each chapter, there is a Q&A, as if young girls are asking questions about themselves on what's normal.  I like all of them except one chapter about body image.  I don't need to introduce negative thoughts to my daughter if she doesn't have them yet.  Since the two pages face each other,  I literally just glued them together. Problem solved! I still highly recommend this book,  but encourage mom and/or dad to read it first and decide what you feel is acceptable for your daughter to read.  It effectively opened the lines of communication with my 9 year old and helped keep a usually awkward conversation easy. I will be purchasing the next one in the series to aide in "the talk"
summary: I like all of them except one chapter about body image

reviewText: WOW!  This book made what I thought would be an uncomfortable conversation with my daughter a breeze! In fact as we were going through the book and started noticing things she needed to do, instead of being self conscious about it, she was excited. For that I am grateful.
summary: WOW! This book made what I thought would be ...

reviewText:
Overall it's a good book for girls.
We read it together with my 9 year old daughter. She is not developing yet, but it was good to introduce her to future changes.
Some of the advice are very conventional. I didn't care about food and vitamins sections. We read it, but I explained to my child that high bread/bread product consumption is very unbalanced. Only in America bread is so heavily promoted (by government). Natural produce and  quality protein should build the most of the food group.
Was repulsed by offering kiddos tampons for their first period, regarding sport activities. Seriously?!!!!
There were also a few moments that we had to discuss things together.
I am glad we read the book together, just a few pages every night.
So, yes, I would recommend it but with reservations.
summary: Good read, but you have to explain a few things here and there.

reviewText: Great book for Tweens. I do suggest reading through before giving to child. I was fine with the information provided and felt it helped open conversation.
Super helpful and appropriate for young tweens. Thank you!

I bought a second copy for my nine and eleven year old nieces.

reviewText: My 7 year old loves this book!

My 7 year old daughter is fascinated by this book! I thought it would be a great way for her "learn" about her body and changes  that come with-along with all the funny conversations we already have. So far so good! She giggles every now and then but it really is great facts every young girl should know. Plus, she has since wanted to exercise..drink more water, and scolds me for "picking" at my face lol.
love the book

I loved this book as a young girl and I love it for the girls in my life now. My 9-year old niece found this book very engaging and devoured it in a day or two. The writing approaches topics sensitively and reassuringly, and it does not stop at Boobs and Periods, going beyond to encourage girls to be active, use their bodies purposefully and autonomously. It's hilarious seeing kids' reactions when they feel they're reading something *elicit* but it's extremely kind and straightforward about puberty. Highly recommended!!
summary: I grew up on this book and it's still gold for little girls.

reviewText: This book has proven itself to be quite helpful! I highly recommend this book to anyone who has a preteen with or even without questions! It is a huge help to you and your daughter!

I highly recommend this book for girls to read, but also for moms & daughters to go through together to cover any questions or concerns the daughter may have.

reviewText: My daughter has always asked TONS of questions about EVERYTHING in life! I am always quick to answer her questions and love that she comes to me with her concerns, but I'm ever not around when a question comes up or if I possibly don't know the answer, this book comes in very handy! My daughter read it cover to cover in a few short hours and has been referring back to it ever since. I haven't read the book, myself, but she really likes it!

The best!!  My daughter (10 yrs) loves this book and it has given her a lot of confidence and preparation for what lies ahead for her (puberty).
*highly* recommended!

After noticing the signs of my daughter beginning puberty, I searched for a book written specifically for the 8 to maybe 11yo, meaning explaining the bodily changes of puberty without going into the entirety of human reproduction. Mine is a young eight and hasn't asked about how babies are conceived, but it was necessary to tell her what was happening with her body.

This wonderful book explains just that with age appropriate language, encouraging self-care advice and consistent esteem boosters. We'll be reading this a few times together, and I highly recommend this to any family with developing girls who want a resource that doesn't give too much information before the child is ready.
Perfect for the young girl to learn about her body

I bought this for my 9yr old daughter and she loves it. It talks about all kinds of things, braces (which she just found out she'll most likely need), shaving, hygiene, all kids of stuff. It doesn't cover some things that I don't feel she needs to be learning about now, like homosexuality & masterbation, unlike some other books out there. It is very age appropriate.
My daughter loved this book
Good beginning!
My daughter loves this book
Exactly what I was looking for, pictures and content are superb! Recommend HIGHLY!
Perfect for 8-10 year old girls.
Good.

This book was recommended by several mom frields who have girls going through or about to go through puberty. It's a whimsical way to introduce adolescence to girls. Some of my mom friends suggested that I leave the book in my daughter's room, but she was too nervous to look at it alone, so I decided we'd read it together.  It's a very easy read with lots of tasteful pictures and Q and A pages in case the girl is too shy to ask questions.  We read a chapter a day, and if she had any questions, it was easy to ask.  This book doesn't talk about sex education, but it does talk about what happens with the female body as it goes through adolescence.

When we reached the end of the book, my daughter wanted to read the 2nd book, so we bought that one as well.

I highly recommend this book to all parents with daughters. It's just an easy way to talk about the female body as it "grows up".
summary: A whimsical way of teaching about the female body for tweens and teens.

reviewText: Got this for my 8 yr old daughter and one for my neice. They both love them and will ask questions about things in the book. It is very age appropriate and well written.

reviewText: Not in very good condition
This to me is a great book because it is very easy to understand and it can be fun to read.
Ordered for my 10-y-o and she has taken to it. Reading with interest enjoying both the text sections, as well as, the illustrated pages.

After reading the negative comments, I decided to read this for myself.  I was not worried about "implanting" body insecurities on my daughter from reading a book.  I was also not worried about the grooming or holistic ways of dealing with things.  I'm traditional, I shave/ wax.  I use regular sanitary products.  Do I know about my choices?  Yes,  and I will tell my daughter.  I wouldn't blast the writers at all.  If you are a traditionalist, such as myself, this is a go.  Also, recommended by my pediatrician who also has 2 daughters.
summary: recommended by my pediatrician who also has 2 daughters

The book made her feel special (especially when she was told it was too mature for her six-year-old friend to read) She's been stressed about 'growing up' and wants to stay 'just a kid', but I think this book helped her. I told her to read through it and any questions she had, to come to me about. Some parents might want to read along but I wanted her learning to be more independent and self sufficient. This book certainly opened up lines of communication between us and lead to some conversations that were easier to have with us both having an informed opinion.

Not only did this make the whole 'period' conversation much easier (for both of us!) but she's been being more self responsible. She's taken more intiative on her hygiene instead of being reminded, brushing her hair and teeth more often, and even felt brave enough to not only ask for a bra (because she feels all 'jiggly') but exactly what type she wanted.

Why do they have to only show young girls options that encourage hair removal, like shaving, waxing or creams. Why not at least say you can just leave it there if you want? Why make them feel it is something they must get rid of or be ashamed of?  Also I wish they would show the option of menstrual cups and not just tampons and pads. Come on! Get into the 21st century and start being ecologically and economically responsible! If YOU don't know what they are, then google them and try them out. Save yourself time and money and save the earth on waste!

reviewText: Grandaughter wanted this!  Good little book
This is a good book for tween girls.

Helping one's kid to navigate the strange world of puberty is never something a parent looks forward to. The reason so many books are written on the topic is because there is no clear-cut formula that answers all the questions. What information should be provided, and when, and by whom, and to what level of detail?

This book (and the others in the series) provide light overviews of some of the more common physical and emotional realities kids will face, presented in easily digestible and often amusing language, and accompanied by inoffensive illustrations that steer clear of overly simplifying a complex set of topics. Kids are indeed smarter than we imagine, but they are also more sensitive. Sometimes a book such as this one, that lets them know the changes they are experiencing are not only normal, but far from scary, provides just enough succor and support to give them the confidence to keep moving forward, with renewed confidence that their bodies are healthy, strong, and personal property: to be nurtured, cherished, protected, and strengthened.

We parents are no longer the captains of the team, we are becoming the coaches and cheerleaders, and this simple playbook makes it a little easier to stand on the sidelines, increasingly confident that our kids are smart enough to avoid injury, and be the winners they deserve to be.
summary: Life is a tough game. It requires teamwork, and a playbook.
