Awesome book. A must for little girls.

I bought this for my daughter who currently is seven with the thought I would have it stored away until I felt like she was ready to start talking in more detail about puberty, maybe sometime in the next year or when she is eight. I developed on the earlier side, as did my mother, so I am anticipating she may start pre-puberty in the next year or so. I am so glad I decided to read through the book before showing it to her because I have decided to return it and look for something else. As another reviewer mentioned, this book has a lot of content that could actually CAUSE insecurities about her body rather than prevent them.

What I like about the book:
It is simply written and easy for a younger girl to understand. It talks about puberty in a mostly positive way. It has fun illustrations that would appeal to my daughter and does talk about all bodies being different and so on, BUT

What I DONT like about the book:
As of now my daughter has a very positive self/body image. She is very comfortable in the skin she is in.  From my observations, most girls in the target age of this book, 8-11, haven't quite gotten the message yet that they should be looking critically at their own bodies or judge others for how they look. If they read this book, though, they WILL be exposed to these concepts. While my daughter does have a positive self-image at the moment and we have worked hard to cultivate that, I also know (and remember) how fragile that can be at the tween stage and the power of suggestion is huge at this age.

Here are some examples:
My daughter has a beautiful speckling of freckles across her nose. Most people around her have commented that they love them. SHE loves them. She said to me a few months ago that she wished she had MORE freckles. In this book, on page 36: I have freckles. I hate them and wish I could get some lotion that would make my freckles go away. I need help! While she loves her freckles, I could see reading this she may start to question how she feels about them. I could imagine her thinking, Wait, are freckles considered to be ugly?

Page 50-51, three questions are about girls insecurities of having a flat chest, then this one: I have bigger boobs than all of my friends. Because of this, my friends are embarrassed to be around me because they think Im very ugly and fat. I used to be very popular, but now I find myself dorky and lonely. Yikes! Really?? I developed breasts earlier than my friends and was definitely insecure about them, wearing large shirts, etc., but NEVER did I ever think my friends wouldnt like me because of them. The message that people may not like you because of anything having to do with your physical appearance is horrible. I know it is rampant in our culture, but I really would like to keep my young daughter from being exposed to this idea as long as I can. I realize the book is trying to prevent these kinds of thoughts, but the question in itself may get girls wondering and thinking about these things, not to mention re-enforcing the message that if you are fat, you are unlikable.

In the same vain, pages 62-63, titled Body Talk, all four questions from girls are about how other girls are thinner;  how to stay thin; how to get thinner; and comparing your own body to your friends'. Talk about re-enforcing the idea that thin is ideal!  I know the answers talk about all bodies being different and not to compare yourself, but these questions themselves might get our daughters thinking about whether they are thin enough and that it is normal to compare their bodies to their friends'. Yes, I realize she will face these issues at some point. I just feel there is no need to get these thoughts going at such an early age.

This is getting so long, but just know there are other parts in the book talking about comparing yourself to others physically; calling someone pizza face because of acne; insecurities if you haven't gotten your period yet and are not considered a woman like your friends, etc. Again, I know that these are presented as questions and the book is telling the girls not to do those things or feel these ways, but the power of suggestion is so strong.

I wish there was a simple book about bodily changes/puberty which I could read to an eight year old girl without going in to explicit details about sex. This book would be much better if it just stuck to the facts about physical changes during puberty, how to take care of yourself, etc. and left out the question/answer section. The questions seem more appropriate for the second book for older girls (if even), not the target age of this book. I saw one recommendation in another review for "Reaching for the Moon," by Lucy H. Pearce. I will try that and then leave an update here.
summary: Read the book first to see if it is a good fit for your child

This is a simple factual book that lays out an appropriate amount of information. It mentions tampons and pads but does not get into the details of how to use them (it shows how to use a pad but not a tampon). I appreciated that as I don't think my daughter was ready to get into a full discussion about tampons yet. This is a great gateway book in talking about the changes that are upcoming. She was completely enamored with the idea that she was big enough to read about the changes her body will make and has plans already to be prepared for her period. Thanks for this great conversation started. She also made other plans to better take care of her teeth, hair and skin because of what she read here. I was so happy with this purchase. And, when we finished she realized it was an American Girl book......which was basically sealing the deal of her approval.

reviewText:
As a two-dad household with a single daughter, we gave our daughter this book when she was 7 years old. She's now 8 1/2, and she's read through this many times. We used this book as a method for introducing and opening up topics about her growth and body changes. We talked about each chapter and section, and because much of it was on the horizon, we feel comfortable that she knows she can talk with us about any of the issues in this book without shyness or embarrassment. There are some areas where we have wanted to go deeper - one commenter mentions that it doesn't go into the itty-bitty details of what is happening when menstruation starts - but we aren't expecting this to be the one-all answer. It is a great book to open the conversation about daily body needs.  If I had one request, it would be for a bit more around washing or showering, and cleaning the vagina.

Our daughter is asking us for the next volume, but we are waiting until she is a bit older before she gets that one.
summary: A great intro book to body care for young girls

reviewText: An excellent introduction to learning to care for yourself as you grow.  It's hard to know when is the best time to begin discussing the future changes, but this addresses so much more. Body image, body care, hair care, feelings, nutrition, exercise, and puberty...it's all in there.  I think this would also be an excellent resource for single dads raising girls.  One bit of advice-- if you are reading it with your girl, read ahead so you know that YOU are emotionally prepared to discuss what is next.  Don't avoid the discussion though, it needs to happen and preferably from the adults that care the most about her, not her friends at school or the school nurse.  After all, it is nothing to be ashamed of, it is only the most natural part of growing up from an amazing little girl into the amazing woman she will become.

I bought it for my daughter (9). I want her to know before the changes begin. This is a great opportunity to start the conversation and her confidence to ask and trust. Language and style are appropriate and easy to understand.

Our pediatrician recommended this book for my 9 year old. She has appreciated knowing that she has a place to turn to for answers about her changing body besides her mother. It's goes into a short discussion about menstruation that I wasn't ready to talk about with her just yet. I taped that section together and told her we would open it up and read together in a few months. It also talks about breast development and bra types. The other topics include shaving, personal hygiene, healthy diet, acne, emotions, getting rest and a few others. Sex is not one of them which I'm glad about. I think that will come in volume 2. Overall, it's an age appropriate book for the 8-11 year old girl.

Book one seems to be more of a basic introduction to the changes which is a great place to start.  One my daughter (10) and I finished this she immediately wanted to continue on to book 2!  It has been a great way for us to discuss the changes she is going through, why, what's next, what she can expect and why not to compare herself to others during this journey.  Book 2 is more in detail which will hopefully allow my daughter a good, clear understanding of the specific changes and why they happen.  I'm hopeful it will also keep a good line of communication open between us so she'll feel comfortable talking to me about any concerns or questions she might have.  Also, I want her to know the truth so she won't be easily swayed by anyone who would try and tell her opposite.

This book does a decent job explaining the basic details of a growing girl's body, but the tone is too flippant for me. They also introduce ideas that may or may not be a part of your girl's life, such as body shaming and bullying and feeling ashamed of body issues, which seem unnecessary and actually introduced unwanted ideas to my daughter (like "mom, why would I feel embarrassed about my breasts not being as big as the other girls?" That issue is a moving target and really based on the male gaze, which is changing as well and not necessary for a body discussion). I guess this book seems more geared toward 20 years ago than today.
Cute little book that lightly introduces changes in a girls body. It provides just enough information for the age when girls are on the very front end of puberty.

reviewText: My daughter loves this book.

It's an incredibly informative and motivational book.  I borrowed this on a lark expecting some patronizing girl colors, nauseatingly cutesy illustrations, dumbed language and content that would make you would wonder if were made for reading and comprehension exercise but the authors and illustrators present themselves with such a depth and simplicity, anyone dealing with the growth of young girls ought to consider getting their own copy

The Care and Keeping of you is an informal user's manual explaining the less provocative features of young female bodies with simple elaborations and basic advice for general health and hygiene.  The author works her way down from head - explaining hair care, the importance of brushing and flossing of teeth, acne, eye care and dealing with having to wear glasses to the legs stressing the importance of exercise, shaving legs, foot care, and sleep. In between, it touches on everything that a young wants to know or needs like body image, menstruation, underwear, and something just as intimate - emotions.  The simple and declarative language makes the entire book easy to read yet with enough authority that they can accept and make use of the content the first time.  For better or worse, there are few technical explanations such as chemical process of menstruation or what exactly makes a healthy meal, instead encouraging the young reader on almost every subject to seek further advice from parents, trusted adults, and health care professionals to determine the best course of their lives.  Better there is very little provocative material - there is one sequence of illustrations that feature the five stages of breast growth and how a young girl properly uses a sanitary pad while sitting a on toilet but figure such matter are rather tame - its not more than what is presented in sex education in public schools.

I do have one almost trivial problem with the content.  The book is richly illustrated with young girls and parents going about their lives and the chapter entitled the "Belly Zone", the author explains proper nutrition and the varied shapes that girls come from and change to as they grow.  Appropriately, the authors are quick affirm that there is no "normal" shape, weight, or height, moreso since they are still growing but the more perspective/cynical reader might have noticed that the girls depicted in this book (albeit just illustrations) all had the same petite body type.  Of course, better critics will emphasize artistic license to defend this book, I dare say it's not enough to say that there is no normal body shape - you have to show it.

In general, it's an awesome book.  Written for the pre-puberty/going-through-puberty crowd, it tells what they need to know about themselves without going on tangents like where babies come, how boys are different from girls, or the chemical processes that make it all work. Heck, even I learned something from it
summary: An concise and authentic guide to girlhood

reviewText: This is a great book for pre-teens, or even slightly younger. There is nothing 'inapproprate' at all for those ages. reviewText:
I give this 5 stars for helping me communicate with my boyfriend's 8 and 10 year old girls. They don't have a mother, and every girl needs a special someone to turn to in order to understand and not fear the changes they're going through and will go through (just around the corner). Little did I know that this book is by the American Girl Label, and both her and her younger sister love American Girl. It was immediately accepted as a "book of gold". I expressed to her that I am absolutely here for ANYTHING, ANYTIME she needs/wants to talk. She's got a wonderful father, but sometimes it takes an understanding woman available in order to keep the communication lines open and confusing changes in your body to be less feared and better understood. We've had the "period" talk, which went much smoother than I thought it would, thanks to this book. It appears that she is developing early, so it was a wise investment purchased not a moment too soon. She's now confident in talking to me about everything; and she's asking for the next books and journal for Christmas 2014. I'm happy to oblige.

I'm very grateful for the bond that I have with both girls. Now, her younger sister is reading the book and is more open to asking questions also.

This book opened the door to a stronger, more trusting relationship that would not have been as easy without this book. *Just a tip: read the book yourself. That way, any questions you are asked can be better planned for, and questions better understood. Plus, it's just best to understand what they are learning and the details. When I'm shown a page in the book and asked "What does this part mean?", I know exactly what they've read and how to comfortably answer it in a way that they can understand.

The best thing about this book is that it teaches girls what they need to know and understand at the age they are at. At 10, I started my monthly cycle. I was early, but I had no one to talk to. I only had a library full of books that informed me, but they also terrified me. I wasn't old enough to learn about subjects attached to you're period, such as details about sex. That's one thing I hoped to eliminate with this book. Yes, it does explain what a period is and why, but it does NOT explain sex or pregnancy. At 10 (the younger is 8), I can trust that this book won't terrify them like I was. The "sex talk" will happen when she's old enough to know. Some people believe in terrifying their child because it scares them into abstinence, but I'm not that type of parent. I encourage good choices based on information given to them in a way that encourages those positive choices. This book is an excellent tool for that.

I recommend this book to any mother, step mother or parental figure that wishes to have a stronger bond and open communication with every little girl/young lady in their lives. It's truly helpful, and we're all grateful for it!!

Thank you, American Girl, for helping the girls in my home to better understand themselves, and feel comfortable communicating their questions and any fears they may have. Book #2, and the journal out of the line of books/journals available will be making their way under the tree this Christmas.
summary: An Amazing Book That Creates A Strong Bond!

Well, I'd hoped to write a glowing review of how great the actual book is but, according to Amazon, the publisher did not authorize it to be delivered to KINDLE EBOOK READERS, only to Android devices (of which Kindle Fire is one).  Beware!  If you do not have an ANDROID device running Kindle Reader, you won't even be able to read this book.  Also, do not give this as a gift--it's NON-REFUNDABLE.  :-(

Sorry girls, you'll just have to figure it out on your own.

EDIT:  Since I wrote this review, Amazon has added a "only works on these devices" section.  Good going!  I only wish y'all'd done that before I paid for something that is USELESS to us.

To all you whingers who "only want the content reviewed," well, #1. "the content" includes Kindle Store's products' ability to actually work on a KINDLE, and #2. instead of taking it out on me, why don't you complain to AMAZON and ask that there be some feedback mechanism for such information to be processed and shared with potential buyers, rather than just telling me that I'm wrong?  As it is, this review appears to have saved at least FIVE other people the agony of buying something from The Kindle Store that will not work on a KINDLE, and was probably instrumental in getting Amazon to add the note that this "only works on these devices" warning.  That seems a valid reason for reviewing as I have done here, and I certainly wish someone else had done so before I wasted my money.  Also, maybe take some reading comprehension and/or bother reading the explicit title of my review.

I have still not received a refund for this book we purchased that is unusable on our Kindles.

I did finally read the stupid book, and it's no loss that it will never work on our Kindles.  My one star review stands, this time FOR THE CONTENT!

reviewText:
These books and their accompanying journals are really informative. It's so ironic; I've been trying to tell my Goddaughter to eat certain of foods so she will get all of the daily vitamins that she needs. She's been poo-pooing me and rolling her 10-year old eyes. Sound familiar? Anyway, the irony, sorry - she looks through these books and sees a page that discusses nutrition for girls (because I wasn't one and wouldn't understand;)). It's like she just got a revelation and has decided she needs to eat more green vegetables. WOW, I wish I would've thought to tell her that. HA! REALLY GOOD BOOKS.

And, after reading some of the other reviews, I'm not going to pick apart these cute little books. I don't find them harmful in any way and aren't forcing any beliefs. I'd suggest whichever book you get, also get the journal. They are so worth the price. I would definitely make certain that the book or books that you purchase are age appropriate. A seven year old does NOT want to read about a period quite yet - scary stuff that they don't need to start worrying about - my opinion of course.

reviewText:
I ordered this book Yesterday but received it today even though it was free 2 day shipping. That in itself is awesome haha. I ordered this book for my 9yr old daughter whom I realized is growing up too fast. I wasn't sure how to go about explaining the changes she is going through and since she is a reader like me, decided this was the way to go. I of course looked through the book first (since I feel sex talk can wait a while longer), and found it was just what I was looking for. I sat with my daughter, read and spoke to her about parts I thought were most important like hygiene and PMS. I also added in MY stories to make her laugh and feel more comfortable. She is my oldest of 3 girls and I honestly was freaking out about it. The book did talk about not letting anyone put their hands on you and telling someone you trust if that happens. It was just added as a side note but I am very happy that it was there at all. I give the book 5 stars since it brought up every subject I wanted to talk to her about and also tells her how to shave, etc. She is
currently reading the book in her room.  I am very satisfied with this purchase.  I will soon go for book number 2. God help me lol :)

Excellent book to read with your daughter or granddaughter.  Reading together allows you to start discussions on personal topics that are sometimes hard to talk about..

reviewText: This is a great book for little girls.  Bought this for my 8 year old to get her started on at least some of the talks...  It is easily read and has lots of pictures to keep her attention.  Great book for prepubescent little girls that doesn't get too graphic and detailed, but just makes a little easier to explain things.

Everything from body to emotional changes of adolescence for girls. My daughter reads it on her own and then asks me questions about parts afterwards. Easy to read with good illustrations. A wonderful tool for helping to navigate this challenging time.

reviewText: it's a good book for ages 9-11, I think. it explains what's going on and how to handle it. I thought it was a great book.

I am totally impressed by American Girl books. I thought they would be commercial and markety, but instead they are attractive to my daughter to read and at the same time convey the kind of information I would like to convey to my child. I'm taking advantage of the fact that she loves to read to give her these gifts periodically, which she swallows with enthusiasm. Totally worth the cost.

I am 9 years old, and I just started getting some signs of puberty. My chest was no longer starting to feel flat. It seemed like it was growing, second by second, very slowly. I didn't even have a period yet, but I was prepared for it whenever it came. But, what is a period? This book was so helpful for the new changes that I am going through. As I start to get older and more noticeable signs of puberty, I will get the second book, the sequel. So, if you are just unsure and curious about puberty, even if your 5, then I still recommend it.
summary: Growing Up is now so much easier!

reviewText: My 9 yo daughter loved this book. She was so fascinated that she read the whole thing in a couple of days. Then we discussed any questions or concerns she had. She even took it to school and shared with her girlfriends.  It is written in a simple, but medically accurate way to help young girls understand what is going on physically and emotionally in their bodies.  It discusses all kinds of healthy lifestyle choices.  I highly recommend it to anyone with a young girl in their life.
I love it I need some help on this and my mom got this for me tanks for all the HELP!!!!!

Speaking to your kids about changes occurring to their body may not always be the easiest task. This book formulates each occurrence in a friendly and understandable way so that kids can comfortable with their bodies and keep their self esteem up!

This is a great book for girls. I purchased the book for help with having "the period talk" with my daughter. My daughter is 10 years old. It covers a variety of coming of age topics such as body changes, getting your period, body odor and how to care for your changing body, acne, and boys. My daughter liked the book and she keeps going back to certain chapters to reread information. There are many topics in the book that I did not even think of, so it has been a great conversation starter and explains things better than I could by myself. It is appropriate for ages 9 to 12 I would say. It's a nice price and was well worth it.
summary: The Care and Keeping of You Book

reviewText: My daughter is almost ten, and has plenty of questions about her changing body. This book not only answered her questions in an appropriate manner, but opened the door for us to have comfortable discussions.
This book is very helpful and answers a lot of questions that young girls might have about changes happening to them.
Good book it is good for girls ages 9 - 12 and helps with problems like bed wetting and mega dry hair

My daughter has begun being curious about the things she is noticing about her body as well as mine. This book is a great resource to explain her developing body and how to care for it. It was recommended by a child psychologist friend of mine and she was right. It is just perfect for 8-12 year olds who are full of questions.
Every girl is different developmentally, but my 10 year has been reading this book constantly.  Even better, she brings up topics from the book with me!

I recommend this book for all girls on the verge of puberty. My 10 yo read the whole book in 1 night, and I still see her reading it from time to time.  We had "the talk" but this book allows her to follow up whenever she wants.

Was for a friend's daughter. She was very happy that her girl was talking and asking questions. Her younger sister was also intrigued. I liked the pictures and liked that it took a self grooming approach.
Purchased this book for my 9 year old daughter and she absolutely loves it and relates to it easily. It is an informative book written in a way to be easily understood. A great purchase..
Gives enough information, but does not go overboard with details that are not necessary at this point in development.  Worth the money.  American Girl does it again.

I got this book for my 8-year-old for Christmas. Sensitive issues about body changes are becoming a hot topic around here as we begin to deal with pre-puberty. Because she is such a huge bookworm I thought this would be a great starting off point for her to learn about body changes. I think that this is one subject where you really have to take into consideration your own child's personality and decide how to approach these sensitive topics. With that being said I asked her to read the book on her own time and then we could talk about any questions that she has, leaving the ball in her court and leaving the door to conversation WIDE open.

The book has definitely given her the courage to talk about something she was very unsure about. She understands her body now and is actually excited about the changes taking place (I was NOT as a child BUT no one gave me a book like this or talked to me about anything!). I think the book has given her courage to ask questions and even given her vocabulary about the issues she otherwise wasn't sure how to articulate, if that makes sense. I think it also made her aware of other changes that she was not even aware about. No matter how you decide to use this book or other material it is imperative that you not embarrass or belittle your child. It is also imperative that you are there for them and answer questions appropriately and honestly. If I ever feel that something is inappropriate to talk about then I honestly tell them, "This isn't something that is appropriate right now but we will talk about it soon!" And then don't go back on your promise.

Some pretty funny "kids say the darndest things" moments have also happened because of the book. She knows that these are private topics that stay at home so she's very comfortable saying things to us that might make others blush or stutter. I won't go into that here but I'm chuckling right now as I type this, thinking of the things she's said!

Finally I want to mention that we're a super conservative Christian family. I found nothing in this book that I felt was perverse or misguided or inappropriate. It is merely an anatomical book about changes that happen in early puberty. God created these wonderful bodies of ours and it's important to understand the changes *before* they happen. If there's something in ANY book that we don't exactly agree with then we use it as a teaching moment and explain that some people think dealing with emotions or friends "this way" is okay but this is how our family chooses to do it. If I am made aware of a serious problem in a book or one that is most definitely not Godly then we discard it but this book was well written and we've been pleased in how it has helped build our daughter's confidence in an uncertain and sometimes scary time in a young girl's life! We will be getting the version for older girls when she's a little older.

I liked this book very much because it was perfect for my 9 year old who is just starting puberty.  It goes through the physical and emotional changes you can expect without going into sex and std's which so many book like this tend to focus on.  She loves reading it and we have had many good conversations about body changes and emotions and things.  It is perfectly geared to the young girl who just needs to know about her body.  By the way I am a very conservative Christian and have pretty high standards when it comes to content.
summary: Very good for the girl just starting to go through puberty

reviewText: This is a really good book as an introduction to growing and changing bodies.  It does not delve into sex or heavy issues.  It focuses on taking care of the body and the changes a young girl will begin to go through.  I thought it was a perfect introduction and understandable for a young girl.
summary: Good starter book for young girls

reviewText: Chose because sometimes my grandkids over look places like elbows, knees and proper brushing. With this book, they may better understand my nagging.
summary: The Care and Keeping of you

reviewText: Loved this, a mix of humor and information for a younger child (my grand is 10) it's informative and gives just enough info for her age and gives my daughter a way to talk to her about the things that are changing for her....would recommend to any mother of a young girl!
summary: Bought for my granddaughter and daughter to use.

reviewText: This book was recommended to me by a fellow mom and I scooped it up quickly as well as a few other American Girl books with similar themes. My daughter and I read these together at bedtime. They are entertaining enough that she puts up with my obvious ulterior motive which is to EDUCATE her (horror of horrors) about something. She is really happy to understand that she is not the only one to be going through the changes and emotions that come along with puberty. Well worth it!! Pass on to family or friends when you're through.

I will give one warning:  my young daughter was quite upset by the idea of "periods." I thought reading about it might help, but it didn't seem to. However, it's a scary thought for a little girl, so it's not the book's fault. Just be aware the topic is discussed.

My 10 year old daughter started asking questions about "growing up" and was getting anxious about the process.  This book answered her questions and opened up dialogue between us which was wonderful.  I'll definitely order the second book.

I got this book for my daughter. It helped me to look over it first so I would think about some things I could talk with her about that I hadn't thought of myself. I always encourage her to ask questions, and this book helped her get some answers I maybe hadn't provided. Great for encouraging extra discussions with mom and daughter, or even dad and daughter.
I got this book for my 11 year old grand-daughter. She has read it and gets it out every now and then when she has something she is curious about.

I have been so nervous worrying about dealing with these issues with my 9 year old daughter.  She is developing so fast!  Is she emotionally ready to deal??  I found this book informative and perfect for her age.  I loved the illustrations and the subject matter was dealt with perfectly for my daughter.  We started by reading it together but she read most of it by herself.  I checked in often with her to let her know I was available if she had any questions or concerns.  We talked about anything she had questions about and then that was it!  She handled it fine.  As with most things, I probably worried more than I needed to.  :)
Thank u for helping me feel comfortable with myself KYLIE SWEET age eleven ps I'm buying the second one yay

Great book for introducing certain subjects to preteen girls.  I have always been open with my daughter in regards to the upcoming "changes" she will soon be experiencing, but I think it helps to have resources to go a long with our talks.  This book is the perfect addition for that.

My 9 year-old daughter and I love this book. It's given me age-appropriate language to use and it's allowed my daughter to open up to me about things she was wondering about. My mother was not open with me about menstruation and I wasn't prepared when it arrived. So I'm very happy to be able to prepare my daughter and eliminate the weird stigma I felt growing up.

I've also found it helps her to feel a bit more "normal" - by virtue of the fact that most everything is "normal" since everyone develops at difference paces.

I really am thankful for the book and plan to purchase the next one as well.

Great book for 8-10 year olds.  It explains a lot about girls health and taking care of themselves.  Excellent book.
Good price, great shipping, as expected.

I enjoyed using this book to help talk to my 9yo daughter about the changes she's about to go through. I read it before showing it to her, and then went over some of the more involved parts (ie. periods) with her. I then let her digest it on her own.

My eleven year old likes this. It isn't cheesy and it's informative. It doesn't talk about anything beyond her except tampons. We could have done without that, but it did help her understand. And it was a way for her to privately process things by going into her room and reading it.

I purchased this book for my ten year old..  It was what I wanted and didn't go into areas we are not quite ready to discuss.  She seemed to appreciate the book and it helped her understand she was going through the same changes as all other girls her age.

I wanted a book to help me explain to my 10 year old daughter the changes that are beginning to take place in her body without, at this age, going into anything sexual. This book filled the bill nicely. As with most American Girl books, the text speaks to the child respectfully. The graphics are appealing, not at all silly yet not overly-detailed. I appreciated that this book did not tread on unnecessary ground regarding conception, contraception, etc. As a Catholic, I have had a hard time finding books that were not too graphic, that did not go into subjects contrary to my faith or beyond the child's maturity level, and yet were not too vague or old-fashioned and which make the topic seem taboo.

What worked for us and for my daughter's comfort level was for us to read the chapter on her period together, after which I allowed her to take the book and read the rest in privacy. She is an avid reader and likes reading about health, so that worked for us and none of the other chapters were so startling that she would not be okay with reading them on her own (e.g. hair growth, shaving, deodorant, breast development, bras, etc). The subject of menstruation was covered well. My only complaint would be that a couple of words, including vagina, were not defined in the chapter. That was okay for us because we were reading it together (which I think is the best way to use this chapter) so I was able to explain. Also, the picture of the uterus (just a little squiggle on a girl's abdomen) was a little bit abstract, so I was prepared in advance with a simple picture from an anatomy book.

This book helped my daughter be comfortable with the changes in her body. Each parent should decide what to read together and what, if anything, you feel comfortable having your daughter read on her own, depending on her age, maturity, and what is happening in her body already. For example, my daughter and I had already purchased bras for her together so that chapter was nothing unexpected. There is a second volume for older girls which I also purchased to have on hand when needed. I am grateful for these American Girl resources which give a modern presentation yet retain a sense of innocence and dignity.
summary: Just what I was looking for

reviewText: OK...so...as a single Dad of a 9 year old girl, many questions have been coming up.  This is a Great book for the two of us and very empowering for my daughter.  Definitely recommend it.

I just gave this book to my 10 year old daughter last weekend.  She's kind of "weirded out" about the whole puberty thing, but she need to learn it from me rather than from her friends.  This is the growing up "Bible" for younger girls.  Easy to read and understand and not too "icky."

I bought this for my 9-year-old (who loves all things AG) so we could start the puberty talk.  She had no idea about periods or any of that, so this book helped me open the door. The version I purchased is the revised #1, for younger girls, about ages 8-10.  The book sort of backs me up with all the things I've been trying to explain to her about her taking care of herself, her changing body and emotions, so I applaud AG for that.  The only thing I am on the fence about is the part about girls shaving their legs.  Really, what 8-10 year old needs to start shaving?  Not that the book said it that way, I just wish they had a bigger emphasis on talking to your parent about it first, rather than a small mention in a side column.  I've already talked to my daughter about shaving, though, so she understands this part doesn't apply to her.  I just don't want her to make the same mistake I did and start shaving too soon when there's no need.  Other than that, this book comes highly recommended!!
summary: Excellent Book!  Just one little thing, though...

reviewText: I gave this book to my daughter as she was turning 10.  She was starting to show signs of growing up and another mom of an adult daughter recommended The Care And Keeping of You.  It was a great way for an opened ended dialog to begin and blossom.  I am a very open mom wanting communication to happen at my daughter's pace and by both of us reading this book separately that is exactly what happened.  I am pleased with my purchase and my daughter is growing up at her pace while I assist her in awe of the fantastic lady she is becoming!
this was just what i was looking for . my granddaughter is 11 and it had the right  amount of information in the book . i did not want a book that was to sexual. i was a great conversation starter.
This book addresses the uncomfortable situations one stumbles into with puberty, my daughter is no where near it, nor would I just hand her the book, but it is a good guideline for me to teach her.
Girls should know what to expect from their bodies; How to be socially acceptable; the importance of cleanliness and good health.
This book tells about all the big girl stuff that you might encounter. It's been very helpful to my and if your a girl growing up I think you will find this book just as helpful as I did.

My daughter has been asking a lot of questions lately, so this book (recommended by a friend) was a great resource for her. She reads it almost every day, and she feels very "grown up" with it. The book handles subjects very well. I read through it first to be sure there was nothing that I was uncomfortable with. I highly recommend.

I got this book for my 10 yr old daughter. She LOVES it and has read it twice. American girl seems to get everything right. I know it has made my daughter more comfortable and confident with the changes in her body. I will be getting the next book as well. I recommend this book to EVERYONE with young girls, you just can't do it better.

I got this for my 7 y/o.  I read through it before giving it to her so I was prepared for questions.  There was a section about body size that I didn't love (we focus on health and strength, not fat or skinny) but other than that, it had great, age appropriate information.  My daughter loves it and reads it over and over again.  I actually had to ask her to read something else.  She also started asking more questions and is excited about getting older and the new things her body will go through on her journey to "becoming a mommy."  In a year or so, we'll definitely get the follow up!

I am very happy with my purchase. The book is in great condition and my granddaughter will absolutely love it. Very good explanations and will help her and her mommy a lot. Thank you for your fast delivery and I am comp,telex satisfied
absolutely love this book. My niece was so excited about, that she kept talking about new things she learned to everyone she saw.
I think that it was good because it teaches you the basics of growing in to a woman. I would recommend this to girls around the world.

I just received this book for my 9 year old daughter.  I thought it was time to have the important discussion on how a girls body goes through changes, but I wanted a book that would help me guide her through the process. This book certainly fits the bill.  I don't think the illustrations in the book are graphic at all.  They are tasteful and appropriate for an age group of approximately 8 through 12.  I think it's important as parents to discuss these changes with our daughters.  It's not enough that she will learn this in school during Health class and I certainly wouldn't want her to be misinformed by classmates at school, much less, have to deal with this on her own.  I read through the book first so that my daughter and I could discuss the information provided in the book after she read each chapter.  It's a great way to keep an open line of communication.  I wish this book would have been available when I was young.  These types of topic were taboo in my household, so unfortunately, my mother and I could not discuss things such as puberty.  I did learn about puberty in Health class in the 4th grade and I turned out fine, however, I want to be there for my daughter through this important step in maturing in her life.
summary: Wish I had this book when I was a young girl!

reviewText: Ya, boys, I know, probably don't like this, well, girls, my friends, need this advice for when they're older. Great, interesting book. I wish it were longer. American Girl, I can't wait to read No. 2! I'm glad I'm prepared-periods and breasts are literally, well... periods sound embarrassing, but breasts, and Bering one step closer to bras, sounds exiting. Please write a number 3 A.G!

This book has helped me to answer many questions I was having a hard time answering for my daughter.  It has taken some of the burdon of "the talk" off both our shoulders and helps me to explain things in a way that my daughter can understand.  Will do business again.
This book was perfect for young girls.  My daughter loved it and it was not overwhelming for her.  It really helped her understand and helped her.  I highly recommend it for all young girls.

Another item from American Girl besides the dolls, and now a movie.  Highly recommend this book for any mom with a nine year old or older daughter.  Teaching her to care for her body, and also answering questions she is shy about asking herself opens the door for future exchanges between mother and daughter.  Reading book together also is an option. Can't go wrong with this book.

My friend Abby is having trouble, she wants to hang out with her cousin Emily who's 12 but Abby is ten and her sister is 13 and I'm 9 I try to cheer her up and give her advice but it always makes her sad. And I'm going threw puberty and she's not, I just wanna help her! I just don't know what to do I research stuff a lot that she has problems with, I need help to help her.

-Wanting help to help
My daughter had this book when she was younger so I decided to buy it for my 9yr.old niece. She has already learned so much from this book. It's a wonderful book for you girls!!
summary: I bought this for my niece.

reviewText: I have an 8 year old and 10 year old.  I have bought this book and the #2 book and love both.  These help keep the lines of communication open

I bought this because I bought the American Girl book "The Feelings Book" for my daughter when she was 7 and she loved it so very much (she keeps it up in her bunk bed with her at all times). This will be a present for her on her 9th birthday. It looks very straight forward and direct, which children need as kids are very literal. It goes over self care such as washing your face, cleaning your body (including armpits), a little on having your period, and that type of thing. I think it's very well-written and perfect for curious, developing children (especially kids who might be shy about speaking about it at first).

I make sure to give these types of books to my daughters to look through by themselves to begin with, then a few days later, ask to sit and read it with them. We read parts, some of my choosing and some of theirs. It makes it easy to open your child up to discussing difficult topics, and letting them look through the book in private allows them to get used to the book's contents without feeling put on the spot. I think it eases embarrassment and discomfort, if there is any on the topic(s).

Remember to listen to your child, and in sensitive situations like this, don't dominate with your knowledge or influence. Listen, and ask, "What do you think?" And before you say anything mom-ish or dad-ish, say, "Would you like advice?" or "Would you like to hear my opinion?" If they say no, hang onto that thought and bring it up again later (the next day, etc). The goal is to make your child comfortable with themselves, and with being able to come to you with questions about their developing lives and bodies, and if they think you'll talk all over them, they won't do it. So far, this is working well for me and my kids, and they feel very comfortable asking questions and talking about puberty with me and my husband/their dad.
I'm not sure if I am looking forward to having my period I'm a afraid of having my period in s

This helps girls understand what is happening and will happen in future to their bodies.  Such a great thing, I didn't get when I was a sprout.  It gives a girl some confidence and leaves her in the know!  Knowledge is confidence...lets help our girls grow up with the right info! :0)-
summary: A must have book for Girls 8 and up!

reviewText: I bought this book for my 14-year-old great-granddaughter who was having trouble with her relationships and family. Before presenting it to her, I read through it thoroughly, and was quite gratified with what I found. Valorie Schaefer has put together an excellent guide for pubescent girls (as I understand pubescence) and given them excellent advice in coping with modern life at this stage in their lives.

It was a little weird at first but after time and consideration it makes you feel better and more experienced.  I've been working up about what the future is like...but now I know and I'm not worried as much and I see what to do in terms of life and growing up...

This book was great. It touched on lots of subjects in a way that was informative and not embarrassing. I bought it for my daughter who is almost 9. I've had lots of conversations with her but thought the book would be helpful and it was. I would completely recommend this book to all those who have a little girl who may be approaching several changes in their body : )
summary: Perfect for girls who whose body's are about to change

reviewText: This book puts all of the aspects of being a blossoming young lady on a level that pre-teens can relate to without being embarrassed mom or dad! Very informative and really places importance on puberty and hygeine.
summary: Exactly what a pre-teen should read

reviewText: I wish the book was longer.  It was great advice and I will use it for a very long time.
This was a gift for my nine year old great-granddaughter. I am hoping she reads the book and uses the advice given.

OMG, this is the best book ever! It prompted so much conversation and curiousity for my seven year old daughter. Some of the body changes she is currently experiencing and she actually came to me and we talked about it. Now she understands what is happening to her body and why. This book removed the embarrassment. She loves her body and now she can't wait for breasts. Lol. She said mommy I have little popcorns now. lol... In a few more years I plan to purchase part 2 of this book. I reviewed it and its not appropriate for now.
summary: One of the best books ever for a maturing little girl

reviewText: I bought this book for my Granddaughter. Her Mother said it is excellent.  As yet have not read the other two books
My daughter loves this book. She's constantly referring to it, and keeps asking me for the next in the series.

This is a wonderful introduction to the body talk conversation. I started this book with my 8 year old, which seemed to be good timing for some of the topics, too early for others. I would rather I talked to her before the things happened or before her friends told her the wrong information. I would recommend this book, but not book 2.

I read this book and then my daughter and I read some parts of this book together. It was very informative and very easy reading for her. It helped me explain a period easily. She asked questions as we read, and the book seemed to answer most of them better than I would have done alone. I think about the talk my mother had with me when I was young and I am so relieved to have found this book! The basic illustrations helped her understand much better. I like the way the book includes every aspect of body care from washing hair to changes in breast size. She read the book by herself after we had our talk, and she shared what she learned about herself. She is not shy about the information with me or her aunt or her grandmothers, which is fantastic.
summary: Great for young girls curious about puberty

reviewText: My daughter is only in 3rd grade and is already starting puberty. Getting this book was the best thing I could do for her. She refused to use a razor on her armpits until reading the chapter about cleanliness. She loves it and it made her realize their are other girls her age going through the same body changes. Thanks Valorie Schaefer!

My 9 year old loved reading this together. It was the information without information overload for this particular age. It was also written in a way that made her excited about the future changes, not worried or scared. Great choice!!

10yo daughter loves it, so I love it.  She is an avid reader, loves to study things, think them over on her own, then come to me, so I knew this would be a good format for her to start with.  Now she feels informed, brought info to me and asked if I knew all this stuff, asked questions.  It opened up a good conversation for us with no stress or discomfort.  We will definitely get Book 2 when she is ready for it.
summary: Great book for girls who like to read more than talk

reviewText: This book has lots of answers to questions that girls are just too embarrassed to ask . This book deserves more than 5 stars .

I had bought the original for my daughter right before this came out.  She is only 8 so I had hoped they took out the slightly graphic tampon insertion info, but they didn't.  They did take out the portion on self-harm and eating disorders.  If you own the original, no need to buy this one, just buy the book for older girls.
This  book is awesome  I may be ten but it never to late to get this book . Who's gonna buy the care and keeping of you 2. I know I am!
I loved this book it helps me understand changes and make me feel comfortable about puberty helps me understand stay strong and don't back down

My almost 9 year old really liked this book. We had discussed changes, but she wanted her own reference book. This book builds trust by starting with more basics, like taking care of teeth, hair, skin.
Well written and an easy topical read for young girls.  I bought it for two girls aged 9 and 11 and they really like how much they were able to learn about themselves in this book.
This was a great way to introduce the "talk" to my daughter.  This book covered things I hadn't really thought of.  GREAT BUY!

I AM THE GRANMOTHER OF A 10 YEAR OLD GIRL, HER MOTHER REALLY LIKED IT!
ANOTHER 9 YEAR OLD SISTER WILL BE READY TO READ IT SOON.
This book is a great resource for our school nurse and elementary school teachers.  It is straight-forward and easy to read.

My daughters found the book intriguing and read them from front to back in no time.  Written in an easy-to-read fashion with clear explanations.  Highly recommend this to use as an intro to growing up.
I will definitely buy this for my daughter for her 9th, possibly even her 8th, birthday. It's upbeat and positive, but also accurate and thorough. I wish I'd had something like this when I was a kid.

This was a good book but I'm curious as to why the book I received doesn't have the same cover as what is shown? I see another customer added their image and it is like mine - without the 1. Very strange.

What a wonderful book. Tastefully written and infirmative, without telling my 9 year old things she didn't need to know yet, such as sex. I would recommend this book to anyone who needs a little extra help starting the puberty talk with their daughter!

I  bought this book for my 10 year old daughter who is going through puberty right now. I had already discuss the topics that is in the book with her already, but I wanted her to have a book of her own, that she could read any time she felt like it.  My daughter loves the book and she keeps it net to her bed.

The book discusses periods and what do used when the time of the month arrives. Things like pads and tampons and the proper way to use them. It also discusses how to keep your body clean, the right type of foods to put in your body, how you need to exercise, how you need to get enough sleep, body development and body image.
My daughter LOVES this book. And I agree its really well done. it's funny and cute with awesome pictures and the rhyming is done really well.
This book is such a sweet goodnight story, we read it several times a week. Well illustrated, cute descriptions of how animals and their babies kiss goodnight and beautiful rhythm/rhymes.
Gave this with the Plush Peek-a-boo Elephant for a baby shower.  Cute Stories.
Very sweet book.....
cute book

So disappointed!  How could these books be best sellers?  They are terrible!  I have to edit every line as a read out loud!  As many other reviewers have commented the series is notable for bad grammar, bad behavior, and inappropriate language. Also just a strange representation of a kindergartner. My daughter was in kindergarten last year and she did not use this terrible "baby talk" nonsense language. Junie doesnt know the name of her teacher and just calls her "Mrs." Every kid in kindergarten knows the name of their teacher! Its as if the person who wrote these books has never met a 5 year old.  Please stay away from these books! Beverly Cleary's Ramona series is so much better. It's an old series but thoughtfully written with complex, charming, funny characters and a great interpretation of what it is like to be a kid in kindergarten, first grade, etc. and to be in a family.  My daughter has asked me to read the entire series 3 times.  Go with that instead.
summary: So disappointed! How could these books be best sellers

reviewText: great
Junie B. is hilarious!

The Junie B Jones books are wonderful for little kids! They give real life kid experiences with a funny point of view. It's so nice to have funny books that kids can totally relate to.  My niece just started reading chapter books in school so I got her this set and she loves it! It's great to see her sitting on the couch reading with a smile on her face and the occasional giggle.
My grandchild loved this book.

I didn't think to read the reviews as I'd heard others speak positively about these books. Big mistake. The writing is horrible (yes, I understand that they are meant to be from the voice of a kindergartner), and the language and behavior of Junie is just plain mean. This is what teachers are using in classrooms? Ridiculous. Sure, the kids might find them funny, but there are so many other books out there more deserving of your time and money. I threw these in the trash. Literally.
Purchased as a gift for my "Junie B. Jones" aged great niece.
